reviews.review: The only way to cross the creek. Catch an Abra across the creek for 1AED and travel like the locals, great city views especially at night

Must do. Wonderful informal evening dinner with volunteer hosts who are happy to share information on their culture and insights into family life.
Lots of laughs along the way and chance to try on local costumes.

Great Cultural Lunch. It was our fist visit to a cultural center, and I need to say that experience we had was absolutely wonderful. All the people who are working here really putting their soul in what they are doing, and you can learn a lot about the hospitality and the local culture. We took our family who were visiting us for the first time in Dubai-and they really enjoy the atmosphere, the idea and the concept. I really need to say thank you to all the people who are working here and make it such a great place. All of them go above the line.This is a good place to visit if you want to learn about local culture, there is no wrong questions you can ask and you can expand your knowledge about UAE.

An experience for all first time visitors to Dubai.. This was our second visit to Dubai and we wished we had visited this centre on our first visit. Great guides, excellent presentations and a lovely introduction to the food of the middle east.Kid and elderly visitor friendly

An interesting overview of the local religion and culture. If you're visiting the Middle East for the first time and would like to be able those burning questions about Islam and the local culture then this is the ideal trip for you. Suitable for families and all ages.
Had an iftar there, cultural experience!. We were in Dubai during ramadan, and celebrated an Iftar there. It was definitely very interesting and we learned a lot about the culture.

History. Certainly one thing you need to do to see where Dubai originated from otherwise all you see is the wealth and huge buildings. You need to see the grass roots of the country and how people actually used to live before they became so wealthy

Immerse yourself in the culture. We truly enjoyed the warm, friendly, welcoming volunteers and staff. We learned so much and we all thoroughly enjoyed the experience and felt very comfortable asking questions about the local culture and religion. The food and hospitality were wonderful. I will be bringing all my guests here when they visit. Be sure to know exactly where you are going before you hop in a taxi, have the map on your phone ready as I was surprised none of the taxi drivers we spoke to knew where it was located and be sure to carve out several hours for the tour of the Mosque, etc. since we only had enough time for the educational luncheon. Also be sure to call in advance to reserve your seating for the luncheon or breakfast. Enjoy!

Ancient Royal dubai. Beautiful and antique villas with equally antique furniture and decor in the villa from the moment you enter to the rooftop as well. The food that is served here is like a royal meal. Also the kahwa and the dates served in the beginning is awesome. The camels in this area take you to all the alleys and around the area. And the beautiful mosque surely gives you a purely cultural visit with the backdrop of the creek with all the Abra and yatch around. A must visit here to have a feel of the ancient dubai.

Wonderful authentic experience. Loved every minute of this experience. My 16 and 11 year old were as entertained as I by our wonderful guides Rashid and Colleen. All staff and volunteers very friendly and so welcoming. Tour very informative and lots of laughs very relaxed and was only 3 others on tour so time for questions. I learnt a lot about Emerati tradition, history and Muslim traditions. Specially prepared Emerati feast for lunch probably some of the best food in Dubai. Hospitality beautiful. We did the morning tour then the lunch. The mosque so beautiful. Dressing in traditional clothes great fun and a way to see what it is like. A tip on getting there... Like going anywhere in Dubai make sure you know exactly where you are going as taxi drivers not likely to know. We got the metro red line from Mall of the Emerites then got off at BurJurman station to change to green line to get to Al Fahidi stop. Then take the south exit and walk pretty much straight ahead for 10 minutes. Or just get a cab from the start but I really like the metro here. The app MapsMe works a treat. This is a must do in Dubai.

A Must Do. I took the Heritage Tour through Bastikaya with a guide from SMCC. In September, it is still a little warm to do this, but I would do it again. To see how they constructed the "wind houses" and did the layout of the town to take advantage of the wind and to allow for privacy. The most important part of the experience were the explanations of the guide and her ability to answer our questions, even those that were somewhat sensitive politically.We ended by having tea and dates in the SMCC building with time for more questions.

You must visit when travelling in Dubai. Really impressive!Dubai has not so many good sites for cultural experience. However, I spend a very good lunch time in SMCCU.For people in east Asia, Muslim in middle east is really Mysterious. I have many questions about the religion and araibic culture when travelling in Dubai and I got answers here. Staff here is really open minded and with warm hospitality.They are conversational and humorous to answer all kind of questions. Food is yummy especially be with some stories and cultural explanations. It really changes my point of view to Muslims. Highly recommended!!!!

A fabulous introduction to the UAE and its customs.. I visited the Centre as part of a work related orientation programme. It was excellent. The Centre itself was very interesting, I learnt about why houses are built the way they are, the history of the region,it's plans for the future and its customs. We visited the Mosque and had breakfast too. The guide was extremely knowledgeable and answered all our questions in a clear and helpful manner. If you are new to the region and want to learn about it, I strongly recommend a visit.

Great place to visit for everyone interested in the Emirati culture. The team at the SMCCU is very kind and open for any questions. Recommended for everyone who is interested in the Arab/Emirati culture, Dubai and the UAE. You will learn a lot from the nice team there.

A must for first-time tourists to a Muslim Country. What a great way to spend a dinner with locals who will discuss the customs and traditions of Emiratis and the Arab culture. The hosts were friendly and polite and answered all of your questions. Lovely way to spend the night. The area is quite nice to go for a walk and explore.

Excellent. This is an excellent informative tour . The guides are very helpful and express there culture slowly and precisely so you understand . The lunch is an array of local dishes and the flavours are amazing . Well worth a couple of hours out of the sunshine

Incredible experience and knowledgable tour of Dubai history. Well maintainedCental Air ConditionedFood and soveigners to buyartifacts, and history and groth of Dubai projected beautifulyIt was a good refresher and adds to your knowledgeWell located in city limits

Fantastic, very interesting talk, wonderful people. We visited and had an Emirati breakfast. The food, all of which is traditional local cuisine, was delicious and worth the visit alone. But the highlight was the accompanying talk. Local people (and ex-pats) hosted a short talk and then long question and answer session, where nothing was off-limits. Questions included life in the city, life in the country (UAE), local traditions and customs, and muslim life. Really interesting, eye-opening and informative.

Informative experience. Attended the breakfast session at SMCCU in order to learn more about the Islamic/Emirati culture. Even though i have been living in dubai for 5 years, this was the first time i visited the SMCCU. When planning your trip, you have to take into account that breakfast, brunch, lunch and dinner is not served everyday. Each have specific days and times they take place, thus if you decide to just swing by for a spur of the moment visit you might end up being too late or too early... It is best to call in advance or go to the website and confirm times (and availability). Prices vary depending on the meal you attend and breakfast is priced at 80aed per person. You can also book private meals at a time of your choosing (minimum 10 pax). The main Emirati presenter was well spoken (english) and he had a good sense of humor (but obviously my interpretation and your interpretation of 'good sense of humor' might differ). There were two young gentleman and to ladies that assisted him with explanations/demonstrations. A wide range of topics were covered in the roughly 45minute long session. At the end of this session you can help yourself to a traditional breakfast. The food is by no means five star quality (but at 80aed you get way better than what you pay for!!!), but it is very tasty, traditional and more than enough for everyone (at the end of the session they provide take away containers if you feel like taking food home with you). There was no specific order except for ladies first, luckily we were a small group of only about 10 pax, otherwise if might have been a bit chaotic. I would suggest maybe starting at one point or doing section by section. During and after breakfast participants are encouraged to ask any and as many questions as they like. The presenter was very open and honest in his replies... But he did do a very good job of not answering certain questions by steering off topic. This was most likely done in order to avoid tension or arguments. Common sense is important... The idea is to have an open/pleasant discussion and learn about the culture, not create tension or argue! This will ruin the experience for the other participants. (Like i have read in some other reviews, luckily no such issues during my experience). The whole experience was about 1h25m long and i learned a lot. I would highly recommend this experience to anyone and everyone!

Arabic Culture. We walked through narrow alleyways and street through to the Dubai Museum. Dubai Museum inside the storied Al Fahidi Fort – built in 1787, it is the oldest building still standinghad lunch at the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding. This was opened back in 1998 to for the visitors to have a greater understanding of the UAE culture. The host was open to answer any questions fired at him & was well read man

A must for all new visitors to Dubai!. We attended the cultural meal and Q&A in August of 2016. All of my questions were answered and we had an excellent Emirati meal. When I first got to Dubai, I was pretty much clueless about the culture so I recommend this to anyone that doesn't know much that wants to learn and taste some good food. We also got to try on the local attire.

Very interesting and welcoming to Western Visitors. A must do.. This centre is a "must visit" for first timers to Dubai. The visit lasts two hours during which time you eat very well and discuss with Emeratis ALL aspects of their religion and culture in a surprisingly open and frank atmosphere. No subject is off limits and so differences between cultures and religions can be explored in a very mature, respectful and relaxed way. I learned lots and really enjoyed the food !

very eye opening. learned lots of stuff as to why arabs do the things they do, like wearing burkha, and other cultural things. I would highly recommend this place. the tour includes traditional meal and the speaker is great and very normal. lots of good q and a.

Heritage and Culture. Im extremely pleased to have been given a chance to visit SMCCU. I have been a Dubai resident for 9years and this is the first time Ive been in this place. Ive heard about it before and some of my friends have visited the center but I havent really had the chance to experience it for myself until now.Upon stepping in the vicinity of the center, ypu will immediately feel the difference between the new Dubai and the old one, and its what ypu would have thought it would been (minus the a/c inside the center- thank goodnes for that!). As I have travelled a lot outside Dubai, I appreciate the history, culture and architecture a city has to offer. Being in the center made me feel like a tourist! :D you get the feel of the arabian hospitality through the casual talks with your guide, the food that you get served with and everything about the center makes you really feel that you are having an arabian experience.Needless to say I wish I had known about this so I could have taken my friends who were visiting me from other countries and have shown them on of the many unique experiences that Dubai has to offer.Must do while in Dubai.. together with a desert safari and a falcon show!

Emirati Cultural Heritage demystified!. If you ever wanted to find out how possibly the youngest of the Arabic nation came into existence, its culture and heritage - this is the place where it all began.Right in the middle of a busy cosmopolis is a gem left untouched and conserved. It was a shame that on the day we visited, the traditional meal was cancelled; The tour talk by our guide was very detailed and informative.The opportunity to explore the place on your own takes you back in time and you begin to appreciate the humble emirati roots!I'd say this place should be amongst the top items on your places to visit in Dubai!

Not quite a tour - more a talk inside. We learned a lot on this visit but it's not quite a tour. A tour implies walking round and looking at different things. This is more a talk in the main area of the mosque. However, the staff were excellent, the food lovely and the brief very interesting.
cultural. Its a fantastic opportunity to get to know Islamic culture and religion ..Worth a visit .Great for history lovers

Culture & History of Dubai & Seven Emirates decodified. This is a tour your will enjoy if you are interested in history & cultures of various civilizations. You will see a typical Arab household, the ventilation system, the courtyard & the jaalis as they used to be in historical days.You can also taste coffee & dates as an important custom of Arab Culture. Half a day well spent in SMCCU

"Historical Place". I visit last year with some of my friends from Abudhabi, it was a great experience because when I was there I feel like I'm 200 years behind...! We got some rotties and some sweets I don't remember the name but it's really unforgettable moment.

A nice place to meet emirati culture. This cultural centre offers hiking, cultural visits and cuisine, with local guides, connoisseurs of traditions, culture and religion, of the Emirates. It is necessary to book by phone. The prices for the different activities are reasonable. The atmosphere is relaxed and the hosts are friendly and available to answer any question.The traditional lunch or dinner in a typical house of the United Arab Emirates is excellent. The group of people who attend, is often from different continents, cultures and religions. All ready to learn and share knowledge. "Open doors, open minds" is the motto.

Definitely a must for anyone wanting to experience Emirati culture. This had been my second time to experience a cultural meal with SMCCU and they never fail to disappoint! From the food to the interaction with local volunteers, it really helps people to understand the Emirati culture and way of life. High recommended for anyone visiting or even living in Dubai!!!

A very worthy attempt to provide cultural insight into the region, but..... I, for most part found this tour to be very interesting and well presented. I felt that the presenter did a good job to explain aspects of Islam in a way that was entertaining and lighthearted up to a point. While we were in the mosque, I posed a question asking the presenter whether Sunni and Shi'a Muslims attended the same mosques during prayer services. The answer that I received was that they do and it was only because of President G.W. Bush's decision to intervene in the Middle East was when the friction between the Shi'a and Sunni Muslims started. I was not in favor of the U.S. invasion of Iraq nor quite a number of President Bush's foreign policies, but to be told that a centuries-old disagreement between the Shi'a and Sunni Muslims occurred as the result of President Bush's invasion of Iraq and was the root cause of the turmoil between the two sects undermined the presenter's good faith efforts to inform and to provide cultural understanding, which was very disappointing.

Iftar meal during Ramadan . We enjoyed a wonderful evening learning about Ramadan and eating a fabulous Iftar meal. There were many volunteers who were very willing to answer any questions about the local culture. We were also brought to a mosque where we were explained the rituals, prayers, etc. I would highly recommend this experience. I am also quite confident that any meal would be of equal value. We just happened to hit it during Ramadan.

Must stop. If this is your first time visiting the area, and you're not familiar with the culture, or have many preconceptions about their lifestyle make sure you include a visit to the SMCCU! I'm glad this was my very first stop on the way, because thanks to their hospitality and open mind I was able to maximize my experience in the UAE! Thank you. I am definitely coming back!
Book the Cultural Meals!. We're glad we booked the cultural meal. We learned so many things about the Emirati people that were very interesting. Suggest to book in advance, online.

Very relaxed and informative tour and brunch. My mum was visiting so I wanted to show her some more historical, cultural elements of Dubai. I booked us the Heritage Tour (9am-10:30am) and Cultural Brunch (10:30am-12pm). The tour was very informative - it was fascinating to hear about traditional building materials, construction and design, and the two local hosts (one male, one female) were very knowledgeable but also very relaxed and friendly, happy to go "off script" and talk about Emirati culture and life in Dubai in general. The food at the brunch was very nice (and filling!) - I was particularly happy to see that they package the leftovers and distribute them to workers, as there was a lot left after we all ate our fill! I volunteered to be dressed in local ladies' attire, and to hear about the origins of some of their clothes and customs was very interesting. The hosts were also very forthright and honest in answering our questions, which I really appreciated. I would definitely recommend!TIP: parking around the area can be difficult to come by (we were dropped off by my husband). The closest metro station is Al Fahidi, which is about a 300m walk away (walk straight down Al Musalla Rd - take Exit 3 or 4 from the metro station).

Pleasant suprise. I will be honest, I wasn't looking forward to this but once I got there I found it really informative. The Arabic breakfast that was provided was really tasty and the staff were pleasant. The talk was really informative and was an honest, positive portrayal of Islam. There was an opportunity to ask questions at the end and trust the German to preach about war and refugees! The irony!
Classy Culture. This is a great way to find out about the beginnings of Dubai with great mock ups of old Dubai and the lifestyle. A lovely gift shop as well.
such a surprise. what lovely way to learn and understand the culture and ways of life of the UAE. we stumbled upon this place and we will be bringing back the

Brilliant Iftar and educational evening. This is the second time I went to this Iftar evening and it was stronger even in the second year. The speaker was clear, well-informed and acknowledged those areas where he was not entirely sure of the right answer. He spoke nostalgically of decades ago in the UAE and how Dubai has changed over the years. He explained the different dishes to us, how they are made and what they are made us. They talked through the words int eh prayer and what they mean. After breaking fast, they pray and then invite the guests to eat. We were then taken to the mosque where there is further explanation about prayer. You are then taken back to main family eating area for dessert. This is well worth the trip to Deira area - I highly recommend it to anyone.
Worth it for an intro. Not ground breaking - but on the other it might be worth if for a brief, yet canned view into Islam.

Good Museum. It was great sharing experience in seeing the museum and learning about UAE and Dubai.
One should must visit if they are interested in history.

Just an old house with photo's. Just an old house with photo's of the Sheikh's. No other information so this attraction is disappointing, it is also very hot if you visit in the summer and there is nowhere to cool off.

Ifthar. My family had our first Ifthar experience here. It was a great place to learn about Emirati and Muslim culture and have a good meal. We brought our three young kids and they had a room connected for them to play in. We were able to dress the kids up in traditional attire and they loved it! If you're in Dubai during Ramadan this is a must do!

Worth a Visit. If you want to learn a little about the history and culture of the area then this visit is a must. Staff all very knowledgeable, friendly and helpful. Hot to wander around at mid dayWorth pre-booking for lunch which was a very tasty enjoyable meal of local cuisine so a pleasurable eye opener.

Not to be missed. This was an amazing experience. We went to the Sunday lunch at 1:00pm. Staff were fantastic making you very welcom. We experienced an authentic lunch, which was very tasty and plenty of it. Even offered a box to take food home. Then a very interest talk about there cultural. Putting on the Abaya, Niqab , Burqa and Gafaaz for women and Kandura and Agal for men was very interesting.

A great opportunity to get a glimpse of what Dubai used to be like. This is one of the few opportunities you will get to see what Dubai was like when it was still known as the Trucial states and in the early days of the Emirates.
Traditional. very nice place to visit to experience UAE heritage and traditions. They also serve local buffet to showcase local dishes. A good experience for a new visitor to UAE.
Very interesting opportunity to really know Emirates culture. Very good opportunity to look from a closer perspective to the culture, food and habits of Dubai, directly with the help of locals.
Great Information into the UAE history. This shows great insight into how the UAE was a few decades ago. Really informative and links with the Heritage locations in the immediate area.

Most interesting thing I saw in Dubai. This was the current sheikh's father's home. Situated on the Dubai Creek and left more or less as it was when he still lived there, it is a fascinating step back in time. There is a great collection of old photographs of the people and the place pre-oil. Needless to say, I was the only person visiting as there are no shops there! You can easily get there by metro or tour bus and it is extremely cheap, I think less than $5.

Fascinating Insight. I usually research destinations quite throughly before I visit, but I have to confess, I knew very little about Dubai's history. This place gives a fascinating insight into how Dubai came to be the city it is today and the history of the Emirates in general. I really enjoyed my visit and the views - go as it gets close to sunset and look over Dubai Creek.

The best thng to do in Dubai, especially if you have visitors coming!. This is an absolute must, whether you are a Resident, or even just a short term visitor.I have been 3 times now, and learn new things each time.I would recommend doing the tour first, followed by the lunch.That gives you a few hours of real education, entertainment, and a great overall experience.I also did the Iftar last Ramadan which was fantastic.This really opens your eyes to the local and Regional culture, in an environment where it is easy to ask questions without the risk of offending anybody.It helps to eradicate so many negative perceptions of the Middle East and Emirati's.It really is an absolute "must do". I will be taking all future visitors, friends, family here when they come to visit me in Dubai.Everyone I know that has been here has only had positive things to say about it.If you want to make a day of it, you are close by to the Dubai Museum and the Souks as well.It is the kind of thing you can do several times as well, so a great option if you are a Resident and you need some ideas to entertain your visitors!

Do the cultural breakfast. One of the highlights of our trip to Dubai! We booked online which was easy. Breakfast is normally on Wed. from 10a-1130a and costs 80 AED. It's a bit hard to find but the old town area it's in is really cool so you won't mid walking around. You'll sit on the floor with other tourists and just talk, ask questions and eat breakfast. It's a simple breakfast but very tasty. It's a great way to talk with locals and get a true understanding of their way of life.
Very good lesson. With the intro from Tracy ( a British Londoner who converted to Moslim after marry to an Arabic man for 23 yrs !), we got a very good impression of this city and the culture.

Dont waste time going to this place. You will end up coming to this place anyway if you went to see OLD Dubai as the boat will take you from one side to the other side of Dubai Market where this centre is. You can get Taxi from this centre to rush back to your other activities after getting bored in Old Dubai

Really good experience. We visited the centre for a lunch and talk. The food was delicious and the hosts were funny and informative, willing to answer a multitude of questions with humour and understanding. I thoroughly enjoyed it and would not hesitate to recommend to people that wish to obtain a deeper understanding of Dubai and its people.

Interesting visit . Not so easy to find but when you do it is worth the effort. A very open and honest attraction whereby you are given a your of the history and background to Islam and gain access to mosque. Any questions you have are answered and you come away feeling you have experienced a little bit of the history of old Dubai as well.
Great place. Awesome place for understanding Arabian culture worth spending few hours of the day. Best for people loving culture and history

Insite to the Dubai Culture . We did a morning Heritage tour. It was something I was really looking forward to as I am fascinated in how other cultures live their lives. We started with an Arabic coffee and food ceremony with Emirates dressed in their cultural wear. The entire tour was extremely relaxed and relied mostly on questions asked by attendees. We would have preferred more information fed to us then having to ask for it. It was an interesting experience but you will get much more out of it by asking the right questions. Tour went for 1.5 hours and is accessible by train. We went to the Souqs a cross the river straight after.

Best place to interact with a local emirati. I had an amazing experience at the Centre, and was totally overwhelmed by the hospitality of the hosts. I joined a Heritage Tour (which included a tour of the Al Fahidi historical district and inside a mosque) followed by a Cultural Meal (we ate so much and even had take-aways!) on a Saturday morning. It was very enlightening to chat with the local emirati hosts who are all volunteers. I learnt so much about their cultures and history. They were genuinely open to sharing their cultures with us, and assured us to "take as many photos or videos, and ask any questions you want". A morning at this Centre is better than any visit to the usual sights, buildings or malls.
Enlightening. Had lunch at the Centre. Great opportunity to learn about customs and religion. Hosts relatively forthcoming, but politically correct. Tasty lunch.

Cultural Understanding. If you guys are wondering as to all the aspects of Muslim ways, this activity will make you mesmerize even more by hearing and feeling and tasting how it is to be a muslim. Is a one of the best way to be in touch with arab world. highly recommend to try this.

It is a perfect place to learn Arab cultural. We booked a traditional breakfast at the center. The breakfast was fair but the presentation and discussion helped us to a better understanding of Arab cultural. After breakfast we walked around the heritage area, it was a wonderful four hours experience.

An unforgettable experience!. It was the most beautiful experience lived in Dubai!Besides the delicious food served at lunch time , I learned so much about the history, traditions , occupations and about the life of today's inhabitants of the Emirates!All questions asked were answered very serious, even if some were said in a joking tone. I always repeat this experience and I'm sure it would be many questions asked and responses received!

Interesting, good start for a first visit to Dubai. Set amongst a cluster of a few minor galleries and specialized museums (art & coins) as well as some government offices & workshops (calligraphy) and a lovely (exterior) mosque near the Creek in Bur Dubai, this modest site provided some very enlightening information about Islam, about the country of and people in Dubai, the local food and customs and more. Our session was lead by a pair of traditionally dressed young people: a college woman and high school man. They brought enthusiasm, openness and knowledge as well as a moderate dose of national pride to the encounter. We learned a variety of social and religious (Islamic) details and nuances. The presenters and we visitors all sat on the floor with a magnificent variety of traditional breakfast items set out in the middle of our U-shaped formation.The presentation probably went about 45 mins. before we were invited to, without any suggested order of approach, dig in. This made for a somewhat chaotic few moments, but courtesy won out as people attempted to take samplings and then move on without knocking each other over or causing plates of food to be upended.We found the experience worthwhile and would recommend it as an early part of your first visit to Dubai. As for the cost, we paid $22/ea for the 10 AM breakfast session; so perhaps is not for people on a really tight budget, but nonetheless, it would be money well spent for any newcomer. BTW, the session was done in English.
Breakfast at SMC for Cultural Understanding. Keep an open mind when visiting this attraction.Interesting albeit skewed.Food was genuine.Hospitality was sincere.

wonderful surprise, a must try. I am very happy to have made the decision to try the cultural meal. I took my family for the Tuesday lunch (1pm). It was perfect timing as we spent the morning in the other side of the creek. We then rode an Abra (1 aed per person) to the Textile Souk and from there walked some distance to the Bastakiya Quarters... WARNING We went in April (not the height of summer) and the walk from the Textile Souk to the Al Fahidi District was a killer in the heat. However, you will pass by the Dubai Museum and while your time away in and around the Bastakiya.The volunteer speaker was a middle-aged man (forgot his name) and he was quite enthusiastic. He told us to ask anything under the sun and some of us did. A lady asked him about the multi-wives they were allowed and then asked personally whether he himself had more than 1 wife... Everyone laughed and he was open enough with it. The topics ranged from the inane, the mundane and to the controversial. The main dishes weren't excellent (chicken biryani was the best), but the bread ball (?) with the date sauce was a big hit.The lunch was 1.5 hours, which was a good length, esp with the discussions going around.

Wonderful experience!. We were a party of 8 which included seniors and teenagers and our first time in Dubai. This visit was just a great learning experience for all. I am not Muslim and learned a complete appreciation for the culture. I felt like I had been invited in to their home. It so happened to be my mother's birthday. They were so incredibly welcoming and helped us celebrate. My mom said it was the best birthday ever! I would recommend visiting as early in your trip as possible as it will give you a better understanding. Thank You so much for making our visit unforgettable!!
The best thing I did . This was great the best tour I did the hole time i was in Dubai! I could not recommend it more! Also you can ask any questions and they will explain the best they can !!

Well worth a visit. I have done the cultural tour brunch and tour of the mosque. Each time we had guides (who are volunteers) who were knowledgeable, informed and definitely seemed willing to give honest answers from their point of view rather than give answers that "toed the party line" Last time we were there the guides were a 23year old girl who was going to a public university and an 18 year old man who was at a private school. Both were very good and it was very interesting to talk about life in the UAE from their different and similar points of view. If you want to know about life in Dubai now I would definitely recommend the centre.
Cultural introduction to local Emirates. What a nice experience. Three Emirate gentlemen lead a discussion with our work group, and introduced us to local culture, food and hospitality.

The Best Experience in Dubai. I lived in Dubai for two years and came here three or four times. Even though I consider myself culturally aware, I still learned so much about Muslim and Arabic culture that I was oblivious to every single time I visited. Every time we had visitors in Dubai we made sure to bring our guests here for the Heritage Village tour and the cultural lunch, and every time they were very impressed and said that this was one of the best parts of their trip. Dhalia is usually the host/speaker at the events, and you should definitely try to go on a day that she is there. She is amazing! She's well spoken, patient and knows her history. The answers she gives are backed up with her extensive cultural and historical knowledge. She even challenges her guests to try to ask a question she has never heard! You can ask anything at all that you want. Not to mention, the food is delicious and all you can eat! :)
Nice dinner and learning. We all enjoyed this dinner and cultural discussion. Good food and learned a lot about local culture. Set in an historic village that has lots of nice buildings.

A nice educational experience. I really enjoyed visiting this set of museums, and I learned a good amount from watching the different videos on the history of cultural elements (the history of horses and camels in Emirati culture), and I enjoyed going through exhibits and reading the small information plaques by each display.

Informative . My boyfriends family from Italy came to visit and so we decided to bring them here (and also for ourselves) to know more about Islam culture. Very informative and would highly recommend to take a visit here especially those expats that are living in a muslim country. Food are okay. Must try!
Center for cultural awareness and culture. Great place to know about Islam, UAE culturety, do's and don'ts. You can also try typical Emirati breakfast or lunch (you have to book in advance).

loved this... One of the highlights of our trip. We did the cultural breakfast. Very informative and the speaker was great. The food was interesting to try.. even the kids enjoyed some of it... fantasic old village to walk around after ith lovely galleries, etc
highly recommended if You are not familiar with Islamic culture. This is a great opportunity to get to know the Islamic culture and religion. Beautiful Mosque, fantastic lecture.

A brilliant place for dialogue and learning. A beautifully restored house in a heritage park of historic buildings in the Al Fahidi district is the home of the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding. This unique encounter allows visitors to dialogue with university educated Emiratis, all of whom speak perfect English. A traditional brunch or lunch is served in an interior courtyard decorated with Arab antiques while visitors and host discuss history, politics, contemporary culture and religion. The local hosts are friendly, articulate and welcoming but it is necessary to book in advance as these sessions are popular. I return to this place every time I am in Dubai and always depart enriched by my experiences and my encounters with articulate and interesting local guides.
History comes alive. Good for history and are/culture lover. Good center to understand history of dubai. guided heritage tour is good.

Fantastic cultural tour. Highly recommended tour to anyone in the area, for AED$75 the Heritage tour was well worth the time and money. Our host was a young Emirati woman, well educated and a great communicator. The most valuable part of the tour was just hearing her speak about the culture, politics and religion of her country, let alone the tour of the surrounding buildings and mosque. I'll definitely be back to conduct one of the food based tours!

SMCC breakfast. Amazing experience, we had a brilliant hostess who was eloquent, knowledgable and entertaining. I thoroughly enjoyed the food and the whole cultural experience and would definitely urge people to visit.

Well worth visit. Especially worthwhile for those want to learn a bit about Emerati culture and history. Everything is so new in the UAE and opportunities to talk to native Emeratis are rare so this small place is welcome.

Gain a better understanding. We had breakfast here. Which was unexpected. The young girl explained how the food was prepared and eaten and its cultural significance. She explained a lot about their culture and you felt you could ask any questions. Gave me a much better understanding..

So interesting!. I've been to some cultural meals and they have been so interesting for a foreign person like me: habits and traditions we don't understand are easily explained and the food they offer is exquisite

Perhaps your only opportunity to meet an actual Emerati!. It's a rare sighting indeed to meet and speak to an Emerati, a minority group within their own country! It is possible to visit Dubai and never get any insight into the culture preceding the boom times, which were not so long ago. I found. It fascinating to learn about the Bedouin culture as well.This was my third visit over three years and would recommend it to any traveler in Dubai who has ANY interest in the people and the culture. The leaders are very open to questions, even the touchy ones, which my travel companion asked, to my chagrin.And for the reviewers who complained about the food?! Are they kidding! It's meant to be a cultural experience (see title of attraction above) if you are confused about that then life must be a mystery to you, everyday. I always have enjoyed the offerings myself, but they are not meant to be the centerpiece,

Absolutely superb. Informative, interactive, fun, educational!. I wanted to go last year but ran out of time so booked online in advance for my 2016 visit. 10 minute walk from Al Fahidi metro station on the green line. Very informative, history of UAE & Dubai, tribes, religion, coffee, treaties, trade, culture everything and anything was explained and discussed openly . The host was scintillating, helpful, knowledgeable, funny and welcoming. The lunch we booked was nice. We had traditional coffee and dates, curry, rice, chicken, veal, desserts then tea. We were there for over 2 hours and it's great value for money. Highly recommended.
quick cheap background on UAE and Dubai. quick and cheap history of UAE and Dubai. In old town near river. can pair with souk across the river.

Nice place to visit and understand the history of Dubai. If you drive there, be advised that the best parking area is located in front of Al Fahid runabout. A few steps away you will find the Building 26 ( all them are numbered what make it easy to find each of them ). There you will get a lto of information about the history of Dubai and also a map that will help you walk through the tiny streets that link all those small places where one day Dubai started. There are some souvenirs and local products stores where you will find exotic oils, perfumes and so on. Dubai museum is just two blocks away and also wotrh a visit

An Informative Visit.. We visited here during our stay in Dubai and were really glad we did. Everyone gathered for the 10.00am talk and were introduced to a lovely lady who spent the next hour with us explaining about Islam and some of the myths that exist. Most of the time was spent in the Mosque which was beautiful and we learnt a great deal. We then had the opportunity to ask any questions. An excellent morning and well worth a visit.

Culturally Correct. We visited the Al Fahidi Cultural district. We were greeted by a very articulate and knowledgeable tour guide. He imparted cultural, architectural, environmental and religious information. He certainly knew how to keep his audience entertained.Anyone can join the tour, facilitated by the ministry of cultural affairs. The buildings were beautifully constructed and amazingly well restored and preserved. The entire complex was absolutely clean and fresh, straight out of a story book. I was very impressed. At the end of the tour, we were invited to share some Arabic coffee and dates. A truly wonderful experience.

Essential history and traditions. With New Dubai being energetically built up the creek this is an essential opportunity to learn about the unique history and traditons of Old Dubai. It puts the whole country in persepective as well as allowing you some cultural awareness. We enjoyed it, but visiting once is more than enough.

Opening minds. Don't miss meeting Nasif if you are in Dubai and he is available for a discussion. The mission here is to uncover assumptions and look at them in the light. It will make everything else you do richer. It's a profound experience as you can ask about anything as it is all game for discussion within these doors. Love this place.

Great breakfast. Especially the way the world is right now, I think this was an excellent way to bring the different worlds and religions a little bit closer. It was a very refreshing morning, great food and some good conversations. After breakfast, take a walk around the neighborhood. Very interesting to see how they used to live. there are also some nice art galleries and restaurants.

A fascinating cultural experience. While wandering around the site we were lucky enough to stumble upon Dahlia, who suggested we came to the cultural talk and lunch she was leading. We found it an incredibly edifying experience. She spoke about the background to Islam - the customs, the dress and how it fits with modern life of an Amerati (native of the United Arab Emirates). We had a long question and answer session both during and after lunch and were told no question would be off limits.The lunch was also excellent - different curries and a dessert of the local baby dumplings doused in a date syrup. We had been served the local Arab coffee and told it was impolite not to drink it!We now understand much more about the Amerati and their Muslim way of life.

Good idea, need to improve the implementation. First of all we were lost in the complex were the center is located and in consequence we arrived 15 min late. The center is in a nice pedestrian area called Al Fahidi, full of "historical" houses (they don't have more than 70 years...), however they don't have even 1 indication about where they are!! We drove crazy trying to find it, and when finally we gave up, the center suddenly appears!! We did 2 activities, the Heritage Tour (1.5 hour, 65AED) and the Brunch (2 hours, 100EAD). The heritage tour, consist on 30 min of answering our questions about culture, religion, history, etc... and 1 hour walk arround the disctirc and finally 30 min in a mosk talking more in depth about religion. The quality of this tour depends in a big part on the people from the group, the type of questions they do and how long are the answer of the guide. In my case, our group didn't do many questions so there were a lot of moment of silence...The brunch last 2 hours and is all the time in the center. The food was amazing (really, one of the best I tried in Dubai) and they provide you some tuppers if you want to take with you. During the brunch, the sessions consits on the same, just asking questions. The problem here is that we were in the previous tours and most of the questions were the same. In that case the group asked for more questions but at the end it was more of the same.Among this 2 activities, I recommend to attend just to the brunch (or any of the Cultural Meals).

Great Emirati Breakfast. I attended the breakfast on 15-Feb. Great and plentiful selection of food. Leftovers were available for participants with containers provided. Wonderful presentation, in perfect English. If using Metro exit at the Al Fahidi station and walk north (towards the creek).

Understanding the Culture and History !!!. We went to this centre on 04th Feb 2016, it is located along the Creek and the nearest metro stations Al Fahidi and Al Ras are almost 1km from this place, this is the place where we can understand the development of Dubai/ Emirates from olden times to up to date.Must visit for all age groups to have a Cultural and Historical understanding of Emirates.
Nice way to learn. This is a good way to learn more about Dubai and its history. It may be a bit hot, but you learn a lot and the rest of your stay in Dubai will leave you even more impressed.

Good insight into the historical and cultural background of Dubai. I went there with my daughter who lives in Dubai and wanted to help me understand the cultural and historical heritage of the area. We visited the site in a group and were allocated a very well informed and versatile guide. He told us about the beginning of the settlement starting with the bedouins of the desert who traveled for days to come to the creek in Dubai for water, showed us what he called the first natural air conditioning system in a dwelling up to the modern day architectural landmarks that everybody knows. What was remarkable about this guide, apart from his impressive knowledge of his subject, was that he was willing to answer any question about some sensitive issues with humour and frankness. During our visit to the mosque he explained why the men worship on one side and the women are on the other side and many other questions as well as providing some very interesting facts about the healing properties of camel milk. After the tour we were given a sample of Arab hospitality when we were invited in a large room, where we sat on comfortable cushions, were treated to strong coffee, sweets and dates and more friendly banter from our guide. Although the price of the tickets was not cheap, I would recommend this visit to everybody who wants to get a glimpse into the history and culture of Dubai.

Centre for Culture. Went here for a cultural lunch - they also do breakfasts and dinners. Was 90dirums but good value for money. The food was excellent and varied and we sampled various drinks too. The host was a young girl who was still at university but spoke clearly and knowledgeably. We were invited to ask any questions and lots were asked plus we were given a demonstration of how the abaya is worn and the traditions and misconceptions around it. A real flavour of life as an Emirati. The experience lasted over an hour and a half so only take children who are prepared to sit and listen and who will try food that is "different" to their norm (rice with chicken, rice with veal, vegetable and chicken curry then their dough balls with date syrup.)

Good way to learn . If you have any questions about Dubai or the Muslim faith this is an excellent place to visit.You can ask anything to the tour guide who enjoys talking about the UAE and religion with all his heart.Very beautiful. Very traditional. Great place to visit without the tourist hype.

Helpful for booking mosque visits and local Emirati cultural tours. We visited to find out how to plan our visit to Jumeirah mosque and to find out what other programs they offer - walks, Emirati traditional meals and visits

Absolutely Amazing Experience!. So far I have experienced 2 of the product which SMCCU provides- Jumeirah Mosque Tour and the Cultural Lunch, and both of their products are more than amazing !The guides who were giving the talk are extremely knowledgeable and are willing to answer any question! The topics covered are quite curious and reveal common misconception about Muslim culture and traditions and in particular live in Dubai (and UAE) and local people customs and way of live.I will definitely come again!A++++

Humorous, frank, and open discussion.. Our host guiding us through this cultural experience was absolutely superb. He challenged us to ask questions about anything to do with their culture and religion. He addressed all the questions in a frank, open and quite often humorous discussion. A typical question was why did the muslim women have to cover themselves in black.He said that it was a choice by the women as a matter of modesty. You couldn't see through the black, and that contrary to opinion, it wasn't hot.There were many questions such as this and he addressed them all without reservation.

Great Experience with Cultural Meal. The SMCCU is a great option for those that want to immerse themselves in the local culture a bit more. Since Emiratis make up such a minority among the total population of Dubai, it was nice to be able to speak to people about how they are working to preserve their heritage. Excellent food and goes a long way to bridge the gap that many Westerners have with *true* Middle Eastern culture.

Dubai is different - go!. We attended the presentation, and the lunch too. You get a little history, experience a bit of the mosque, have many of your culture questions answered, learn something about the food, and have a good lunch.

An informative and non-judgemental way to understand Emirati culture. If you are looking to explore Emirati culture, religion and life then the Centre will give you the opportunity to do so in an open way. Visit a mosque and share a meal with your guide (ours was Nasif Kayed) with the opportunity to ask any question you wish on any aspect of Emirati life. Nasif was entertaining, open and knowledgeable. If only there were more like him then the world would be a much better place. Plus the meal was plentiful and tasty too!

Breakfast visit provides a different way to engage with the city. Traditional food and an opportunity to ask questions about Dubai, the UAE, Islamic culture and practice or anything else that you are interested in. Food was delicious and the information illuminating and well-presented. I'd definitely recommend this for anyone looking to have some sort of connection to local culture. They only do the breakfasts certain days of the week so make sure you look at the website for specifics.

Informative and full of culture. At this center you learn a lot about the last great Sheikh Mohammed. How he and his family lived when he was alive. They provide a few personal items like a car, stuffed animals (real ones), as well as other items freom his home. If you want, you can watch a video about his life and some of the important things he's done for UAE. You learn about how he got his name the "father" Its pretty cool.

Understand Emirates Culture. SMCCU conducts cultural tours for everyone. It is a must visit place of one wants to understand the local Emirati culture. A must visit place to understand Old Dubai with cultural insights.

The best experience we had in Dubai!. I would recommend this as a first stop when you get to Dubai, whether you're travelling as a family, couple, group, or alone. I would also recommend it for ALL expats in the country.We did this on our second trip to Dubai and felt that it provided a completely different perspective on life in Dubai and all those things that some westerners or perhaps non-Muslims assume about what we see and hear about the UAE.The host was very informative and the food was delicious. The time went very quickly! Our two children (aged 6 and 8) were free and the meal was substantial. After lunch we were able to walk to the Old Souk, which is around the corner.
Great. What a contrast with the rest of the city! If you love histoty, make sure to visit it! Just amazing what these people achieved in such a short period of time!

Very Ordinary Food. We booked for the lunch and it cost 90aed. There were 2 Emirati having lunch with us, talking about its culture. What I don't like about this is the food. They are very ordinary food with very dry rice and few variety. I agree with the earlier review that this was good for the soul and way better than wandering aimlessly in malls, but I really they served better food.

Cultural Tour - Donald Trump Should Do This. Very low key affair, consisting of a small group of about 25 people taken on a tour of the heritage area in Al Fahidi and concluding with a sit down and a coffee. It was a very simple format but having a knowledgeable guide to explain some of the history, customs and religious practices of Dubai was a privilege - she clearly loved her job and answered all of the questions with insight and enthusiasm. Much better for the soul than wandering aimlessly around a mall. Highly recommended.

Best place to experience UAE culture. I've been three times to the Emirati lunch. It's usually a very popular experience so I recommend booking in advance. Purely on the food it is very good value and there is plenty to of Emirati food to eat in a Majlis environment. The real highlight however are the Emirati speakers who share their views on Emirati culture and Islam. It is conducted in a very open, good natured and welcoming manner and questions are completely encouraged. The speakers all have excellent English. For many expats and tourists there is very limited opportunity to socialise and mix with the local population so this is an invaluable insight into their lives and how they view the UAE and their culture in a wider context. Highly recommended if you've come to the UAE for something other than sun and malls.

Not what I was expecting. Was expecting to learn more about the culture and history of the Emerati but only heard about their costume and the main reason for their costume was only fashion. Food wasn't as good as I expected as well.

Great place to get to know the local culture. It is definitely top on the list of must does in Dubai.We took with pleasure part in two events1) cultural lunch2) visit in the villageIn my opinion, the lunch is the better one. The lunch is moderated by two local young students (one 19 another 24). As their motto: open doors, open minds. You are encouraged to ask questions (any questions, though almost all questions are still not critical).It is one of the unique opportunities to meet real UAE people, which is not very common in Dubai. In each of the two events we had visitors, who are expatriates living in Dubai. You can tell, as they ask many inside questions. So I think it is great idea to have this NPO for better understanding.

Fascinating Cultural tour back in time. This is not your usual Museum experience We started by a tour of the traditional restored village Our guide Dahlia discussed the architecture, the living condition of the time Very knowledgeable and discuss a great length what was life in Dubai when it was only a pearl diving and fishing village It was very interesting to hear her talk of the life of their ancestors and the harsh condition of what was the desert life with bare minimum Dahlia is a passionate guide when talking about her country and her culture with a good sense of humor It is accessible by Metro but quite a walk to Al Baskatiya you pass by Dubai Museum We stayed for the cultural lunch for a very interesting discussion Their philosophy is Open Door Open minds and quite frankly we had another understanding of the UAE after our visit Strongly recommend if you have a day to really understand the UAE culture p.s I asked Dahlia the meaning of the 4 colors of the UAE flag she could not answer me however I got my answer at the Jumeirah Mosque !!!

Fun and educational. The Sheikh Mohammed Center for Cultural Understanding is located close to the old Creek District in Dubai.Parking is available onsite, but remember to buy a parking ticket when you do park.Tickets can be purchased at the door or online.The Center offers both tours, luncheons, breakfasts as well as onsite mini museums, all centered around the way Dubai was before it developed into the metropolis we know now.All buildings are authentic, albeit restored.I personally had a super experience here and thoroughly enjoyed the walking tour as well as the luncheon.Very fun and educational - a glimpse in the past.
Relax and Have a Look Around. Take your time and read the exhibits, photos, whatever is available. Excellent way to pass time, shoot photos and consider life in Dubai pre-oil.
Old Dubai. This is a great place to visit if you are interested in what Dubai used to be like before all the skyscrapers! A great cultural learning experience.

We went for an authentic Iftar. Far too few Western expats go and find out a little about where they are living or about the cultural customs. We attended an educational Iftar and Mosque visit during Ramadan and it was fascinating. The local volunteers were charming and so proud of their heritage. Everyone should go at least once.

Best place in Dubai to get a feeling of Emirati Culture. I went there a couple of times, I also take any of my visiting friends there. They have good restaurants overlooking the creek, they even have special lunches where a local Emirati sits with the group and tell them about the culture & serve traditional Emirati food. Worth the visit.

Exceptionally Informative. I participated in both the walking tour and the cultural lunch. The young woman who lead the events was very open and informative. I both learned more about both Dubai's and my own culture. It was fascinating to hear about how Dubai is responding to very rapid economic development. The point she made about Western dress in Dubai and muslim attire in the United States made me reconsider some of my preconceptions. Visiting the mosque on the walking tour was very interesting and the cultural meal was delicious. I would highly recommend participating in one or more of the Center's activities.

Interesting Discussion. We attended the Saturday morning brunch and enjoyed the overall experience. The discussion leader was a young Emirati woman who was very open to questions although some of the answers were a little questionable. For instance, when asked why the Abaya is black she suggested that scientific studies had proven that the black material actually makes the person cooler. But other than this odd response the event offers a rare opportunity to interact with local Emiratis.

A great stop in Old Dubai. The center is a great place to visit while in Old Dubai. I missed the classes, but the staff allowed me to walk through and see the center. The roof had great views as well.

Gathering Over Food Fosters Understanding, I'd Say. Operating under the philosophy and motto “Open Doors. Open Minds,” the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding strives to raise awareness and demystify the local culture, customs and religion of the United Arab Emirates. [Source: the Centre's website].This center offers many lectures and exhibits about the UAE, Islam, and history of the area. I attended the lunch, which is offered twice a week. Be sure to check the Centre's website for times of tours, lectures, and meals. The highlight of the meal was listening to a young Emirati woman explain various customs and being able to ask any sort of question during an open Q&A session. She asked for a female volunteer from the lunch attendees to use as a "model" for the various styles that Middle Eastern women wear the robe and headscarf (so, if there is a female in your group, be sure to have her raise her hand quickly so that your family or friends will have an unforgettable experience).The lunch itself was good, but not remarkable. That said, experiencing a meal opens up conversation among the Centre's staff, as well as fellow travelers.This Centre for Cultural Understanding is the only reason to go to the Bastakia (also spelled Bastakiya) quarter.

Informative Discussion over Lunch. We went on a tour of the Jumeriah mosque using a guide from the Centre for Cultural Understanding. She was excellent and explained the foundation of the Islamic religion and what happens in the Mosque. We then went to a cultural lunch at the Centre. The host was informative but have a clear goal to dispel many of the myths people have regarding the Arab culture and Islam. Unfortunately some of the explanations seemed like propaganda and not truth. I would have had more respect if he had bluntly told the truth about their culture instead of offering excuses that made no sense. He highlighted all that Arabs had done that the world did not give them credit for. The meal was tasty and I enjoyed the diverse group of people dining with us. I would recommend this if they was more truth and less propaganda and excuses. We left with slightly more understanding but more annoyance at their perceived arrogance.

Not bad, but slightly tarnished by rain. My third and final exposure to Islam came in the form of what was supposed to be a cultural walk but due to torrential rain became a bit of a chat over dates and Arabic coffee. We ventured out to the nearby Mosque where a few of my outstanding questions about the religion were answered but it sort of fizzled out towards the end, as a university tour arrived and there was something about filming going on. Bit ramshackle but interesting enough.
Cultural visit. This government run institution gives good insight of Islam and UAE culture. Meal is included in the lecture/tour. You mustbook the tour in advanced. Such an enriching experience.

Just... weird. I understand the premise behind the Sheikh Mohammed Centre, but I really don't think that what we experienced met that objective. For all of our experiences in Dubai, this one stands out as the weirdest and most eccentric afternoon we had. I should add that it was entertaining...To start off, we were treated (indoctrinated?) to an unscheduled presentation by the Dubai tourist police for a good 45min (during our 90min lunch) about the new smartphone app that the police have set up for tourists in emergencies. This presentation included anecdotes, stories about the police officer's travels in Australia, and a fixation on the new 'supercar' used by the police. Upon completion of this eccentric presentation, the police decided to award one of the lunch's participants with a free trip to Zanzibar (no joke) once the group awkardly fumbled its way through a weird competition to name important elements that a tourist city needs (like... police!).After this weird experience, we began our conversation (for cultural understanding) with one person asking about local racism and another person asking about the high number of deaths of foreign workers. Our hostess quickly became irritated and uncomfortable and after that, our 'conversation' deteriorated to a decent amount of argumentation between the hostess and the parts of the group. She was certainly friendly and outgoing though - and provided interesting insights into the city, local culture, and geopolitics.Overall, I hope your experience doesn't involve unsolicited propaganda from the local police, but we still had a pretty good time just taking in the spectacle before us. However, for the amount of money they charged us, it was a bit much. Certainly, as was made clear to us, this experience is made or broken by the group of people that attends; be forewarned.Also, I should add that the food was fairly forgettable.

Hi light of my holiday. Had the most fantastic time at the Cultural brunch we visited in October, the two Emirati hosts were excellent, answering all our question very openly. The food and drinks served were delicious, and there was plenty to go round. It was a bit tricky to find the centre, the taxi driver didn't seem to know where to drop us off, he eventually left us at the museum but we then had to double back on ourselves to get to the cultural centre. Tip, leave yourself enough time to get there. Would highly recommend, we will definitely go back.

This Really Is A Must. In the middle east for the first time? This is a great place to start. Sheikh "Mo" as he is called, has truly brought to life the culture of his country for tourists and locals alike to better understand and explore.

A must visit place for trip to Dubai for all the art and coffee lovers. Al Fahidi district is a very good place to go to for browsing some beautiful art galleries. There is even a coffee museum here that serves authentic Arabic, Ethiopian and Turkish coffee.

Open doors open minds - Experience Emirati Culture. This is a wonderful place to visit. You can make your reservation on line and by email. The cultural Heritage tours are most days of the week , not Fridays.Dduring the morning the walk includes a stroll around the Al Fahidi Historic District, we visit the Diwan mosque and we are given head scarfs for the ladies and Everyone takes there shoes off before entering the mosque. We then have sone questions and answers, and also back at the cultural centre where we have arabic coffee, water and dates. I also had a cultural Emirati meal there costing 80AED each,well worth it, and once again questions and answers. The young emirati women and voluntary workers, most are pretty, and intellectual and very informative. I personally was quite amazed at the openness of these young ladies and certainly do not appear intimidated by the questions asked. Wallid the Director enjoys his role explaining the emirati culture. I think for the price and the experience this is a must experience when visiting Dubai.

A must for those visiting one of the Emirates for the first time. If this is your first visit to any of the Emirates then it is a must. The visit will include a brief history of Dubai and its culture, the reason behind some of their customs. When visiting the Mosque, women will be provided with pashminas (for women to cover their heads) and Abayas (for those wearing shorts), men don´t have any problem. As I had never been inside one I found it very interesting especially to see the different prayer timetables displayed on a led board. The visit provided me with a great deal of information on the Emirati culture and even though I heard “more questions, more questions?”, I realized this was a time to listen.
cultural lunch or dinner. This centre offers all information you need about islamic culture, and if it is first time for you to come to UAE you should not miss a cultural lunch or dinner.

Best part of my trip. This place is amazing. I went in a group of people and we were shown how to use cultural dress and were encouraged to ask even the most uncomfortable questions. This trip was so eye opening and shattered so many false stereotypes before the rest of my adventure and I cannot recommend it enough!

Definitely a Must! (for tourist & residents). Whenever I have visitors in town, I take them for the breakfast, and it's absolutely wonder each time! This is a great opportunity to get informative knowledge on the UAE culture and the chance to ask any questions. The breakfast is very tasty and it's set in a very relaxed atmosphere.Truly, I highly recommend attending the breakfast if you can as it gives valuable insight on the people of the region. :0)
Do the cultural breakfast. The cultural breakfast was truly amazing, we had the Emirati culture beautiful explained by a staff. I strongly recommend this place.

Highly recommend. Have been to Dubai many times but this was my first time at the Centre for Cultural Understanding. We did the tour and then the lunch. Our guide was brilliant............informative and highly amusing. This experience gives a marvellous insight to the religion and culture. I would highly recommend to anyone visiting Dubai

Very informative. We attended a talk by Tracey from the centre at the Jumeirah mosque which was both informative and entertaining. I know they also run a number of tours and activities which we would definitely have attended if we had more time.
Travellers must visit to experience the culture. A guide is essential to understand the culture in this part of the world. Make sure you leave enough time to complete the tour of the area.
Museum. This Museum centre is located right in the dubai old city , few 100 meters away from Dubai Creek... It represents the rich cultural heritage of UAE.
Recommended. We really liked it. We walked in the rooms, we read the captions, we went in the prayer room.We bought a kids book about the Middle East lifestyle and history.
Dubai History. A must visit for anyone who is interested in history of Dubai.Have to comment the curators for painstakingly keeping everything intact.

A must visit in Dubai. The SMCCU is a fantastic centre that offers a variety of cultural programmes. I really recommend the cultural breakfast which allows you to try real Emirati food (something not readily available in Dubai, surprisingly!) and ask all the questions you ever had about Dubai, it's people and culture in a very open minded environment. I always try and send visitors here when they are in Dubai to open their eyes to more than the malls and skyscrapers, but it also has some great educational sessions for those wanting to deepen their knowledge on local customs.

A must for visitors. Visited for 'Cultural Breakfast', 'Lunch' and now 'Brunch' - always a suggested location for our friends and family visitors to Dubai. relaxed atmospjere for a light 'local' meal and informal discussion with Emirati locals regarding - well, regarding any topic you wish to discuss. Accepting of any questions - with apparent open responses - by charismatic and humourous guides. They emulate their own mission statement "Open Doors, Open Minds"
Nice Understanding about he earlier UAE life.. I visited on the mid day of my first day in dubai, tour the place and understand the culture a little bit of it.

Very Informative!! Worth while trip if your new to Dubai/UAE!! Make sure you have a taxi that knows where they are going. A very comfortable setting to learn about the culture of UAE and also welcomed to ask any questions. Learned a lot by doing this and would recommend it to anyone visiting Dubai/UAE for the firsts time.

Great food and good insight into Arabic culture. When we went to Dubai to visit family, I had heard all about the brunches laid on at the various luxury hotels. This brunch was very different, but I had a great time in all honesty. The food was really yummy and, in the process, we got to learn a little bit more about the Arabic way of life! It costs a fraction of the crazy money these hotels are charging for the boozy brunches...and you're not left with a stonking hangover as a result.
Definetly worthit!. If you wish to learn more about the country, go to their breakfast, lunch, dinner! Great atmosphere and very interesting. Thumbs up!

LOVED IT. Culture, Food and History.. This is definitely a must visit if you're wanting to learn more about the Emirati culture, try out the local breakfast and learn more about this fascinating culture and the lifestyle in Dubai. I tried every signature dish, tea and coffee while also learning things that I didn't know. This is what makes travel meaningful, connecting with the locals and getting a taste of their lifestyle and heritage. It was truly a fascinating experience.
A must!. Loved it! Everything, the setting, the host, the talk, the food, I recommend to every traveler coming to Dubai, and I hope they make the same in other countries.

Interesting place to visit. It's nice to visit here and see a bit about the history of Dubai, though compared to the modern fast pasted impressiveness and scale of the rest of Dubai, this does show the humble origins of the city and that being said it can feel a little lethargic at times. Nonetheless it is professionally run and worth a visit.

an interesting traditional lunch. nice experience done with family and friends. We went for the traditional lunch and there was a young lady explaining all the traditions and answering all our question. Very interesting.

Excellent insight. We had booked this activity prior to heading to Dubai after seeing it on a TV program in the UK. It is important that you book as spaces are limited. It is located in Bur Dubai and there is an abra station nearby which will take you across as we had to walk some distance to find a taxi after the lunch ended. The price was 180 dhm for 2 people for lunch. This gave you an insight into life in an emirati home. The staff were very knowledgeable and very passionate. Well worth the money an excellent insight a must when visiting Dubai

Insight into life in Dubai. I went as part of a prearranged group. It was just lunch, Arabian style. And we had an Emirati person give us a talk on living in Dubai and the Emirati Culture. The food was amazing and the speaker was charasmatic and funny. It was a very informative and enjoyable experience.

Get To Know Emirati at Sheikh Mohammad Centre Cultural Dubai. If you're ooking for the place where you can get information about Emirates People (Emirati), this is the place. It's like a cultural centre, private and managed by individual.
You can experienced the food of Emirati, culture and Q and A session with the host.

Very interesting. This talk was really good and i learnt a lot, really cheap aswell. 'Tracey' is really informative and will answer loads of questions for everyone. I would like to go back and do the cultural dinner next time and the walk around but we didnt have enough time to do everything.
Great perspectives. Loved hearing the story of Islam, and being in a Mosque. Don't try the Camel's Milk Latte in the gift shop, yuck.

Interesting . The meeting with Emirati and his colleagues was certainly interesting. The food was amazing and the cultural debate highly engaging. Though I disagree with some of his points, I can certainly appreciate his point of view.

Take water. It was the hottest day in August Dubai had experienced so I was so happy I had taken my water bottle.
The staff are so nice. They are really proud of their culture and background,
Its obviously not an ancient city, very new in fact but they are clinging to the memories of the old ways.
well worth a visit.

Very informative. The Centre does a number of tours, etc. I did the visit to the Jumeirah mosque (the only one in Dubai open to non Muslims) which is done at 10am each day and costs AED10 and so my score / review is based on that tour only. The presenter was lovely and her talk very informative. She explained to us the different areas of the mosque, what happens during the prayers and then talked about the teaching pillars of the Islam religion and how it is practiced in Dubai. Following on from this there was time for questions. Her presentation style was very good and she made the talk very interesting and she was very patient in answering all the questions (including those which unfortunately displayed a degree of ignorance / lack of understanding of other cultures). I would recommend it to anyone who wants to get an understanding of Islam.
Culture and Heritage. This is a beautiful place to know about rich culture and heritage about UAE. A must visit place for everyone who visits the country

What should be the first stop for all UAE visitors. The SMCCU is an amazing hidden treasure that has many informative and enjoyable experiences available at what amounts to peanuts. It is a beautiful stop that I recommend to anyone and everyone who visits the UAE as it lifts the veil and helps expats understand more of the local culture and religion. Run by passionate people, you can go on cultural tours, have cultural lunches, both of which allow the curious to delve into what makes Dubai Dubai. I love this place
Interesting. Dubai is not an ancient city, but they did a nice job representing the culture, how Dubai came to be.
Love this attraction. Great attractions. Very interesting. Bring a water bottle. Even better if you have a group or guide that is knowledgeable about the culture.

Food and Fun. For smaller groups, the Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashed Centre for Cultural Understanding shall be a better option for one interacts directly with a local and can have any of her questions about culture answered in this situation. The Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashed Centre for Cultural Understanding truly does give you an insight into the culture that defines the Emirates, one that they take pride in for all the right reasons. At the same time it allows you to indulge in delicacies you are going to recall for days after your return home and crave weeks, even months later at a much cheaper rate. So make sure you have your bookings in place and prepare yourself for a meal of indulgence.

Knowledge and culture. A very informative session into the culture and history of the local Emiratis. You can also dine for breakfast or dinner and try the traditional cuisine. Some visits include a trip to the mosque. All questions are welcomed. Brilliant for visitors or expats who are new to Dubai.
Insightful!. My husband and I took a tour of this facility on our trip to Dubai and enjoyed gaining more insight regarding the Emirate culture. It was very hot but overall an enjoyable experience.

Most interesting activity in Dubai . The one thing I wanted to do while in Dubai was to get a better level of understanding of the culture and customs of the UAE. Arriving and finding a disappointing variety of options to achieve this, I zeroed in on the Centre for Cultural Understanding. I went to the centre randomly one afternoon not understanding their structure and scheduling. With the kind advice of the staff, I made a reservation to return the following morning to attend a proper orientation. So, BE ADVISED, plan ahead and contact the centre to find out their schedule. My only criticism are.... There was no standardized information given. It was a question and answer format; so the only information we received in the group discussion was in response to questions posed by the group. Also, I felt like the tour leader was giving a lot of personal opinions as opposed to hard facts. Still, I felt like I left with a much better understanding of Emirati life and culture.

Cultural Experience. The traditional lunch was a real eye opener with a very knowledgeable guide, Nassir. He explained the difference between religious actions and cultural actions and dispelled many myths that is perceived by the foreigner. It was very entertaining with an open floor for Q&A. I would recommend this tour for everybody that has time in Dubai. We were give a traditional Emirati scrumptious spread.
