Traditional Iftar experience - fantastic!. We have attended a traditional Iftar with a dialogue with local volounteers and large group of local expats and tourists. It was great to familiarize with the culture in more unofficial and relaxed way, people could ask questions and get some answers. We have also been taken to the Mosque before the prayers for a further gathering followed by a traditional dessert. It was very beneficial and we enjoyed it a lot. I do highly recommend to everyone who visits Dubai.... Great work by the SMCCU volounteers !!!!

Perfect beginning for a trip to the Emirati. One of the highlights of my trip, loved it and recommend everybody a visit for better understanding their culture and history.It was well organized, informative, ready to answer sll the quedtions, funny and the food delicious! Grateful for the experience!

a must vist place to learn the UAE culture and traditions. its a beautiful centre by the ruler of Dubai, mostly targeting the foreigner who would like to know about our traditions.. everything is taught from the basis of eating to greeting.. I think there's also always free Emirati breakfast served in a tradiotional sitting manner on the floor. beautiful.............
cultural center. good place.. get to know about local culture .. tourist place.. must visit place for a vacation in dubai..

Would have been nice to go inside. Went to visit and was told that we couldn't go in as the was a private event, however we could go and wait outside for an hour and come back but would only have a couple of hours till it was closed again for another private function. Suggestions, either close for 1-3pm and do private functions then or close on a particular day for private functions. Not very welcoming especially in 40+ heat!

If you love history, ancient structure must visit!. Must see place if you love history! an amazing experience to look in Dubai History very well preserved and nice way to learn about culture of dubai or i would say Gulf culture! `

Eye-opener to Emirati history and culture. This is one of my favorite "things-to-do" in Dubai! First we went on a small-group tour of the Old Quarter (Bastakia), where our guide explained the whys and hows of the traditional houses--why there's a small doorway (privacy for the women) within a big doorway (big enough for camels to enter) to the houses and how air vents cool the buildings in the olden days of no airconditioning. We then went to a mosque and our guide spoke of the Muslim faith. We also had our lunch there. This was our best Middle Eastern themed meal for the whole trip (the ones we had at our desert safari and dhow cruise did not compare at all). We had salad, stew, pastry and Turkish coffee, all cooked so well. But the best and most interesting part was everyone got to ask questions they had about Emirati culture, and our guide gave her answers and opinions. She was really funny, upfront, not all all dogmatic.

An absolute must for all visitors to Dubai- Culturally enriching experience. Attended the Ramadan 101 session which was very well organised and informative about the do's and don'ts during the month of Ramadan.I went a second time for an evening iftar. This was a very informative and culturally enriching experience. Well organised and attended. Make sure you book your tickets in advance. I would highly recommend this as a must for all who come to Dubai. Kudos to the organisers and support staff who execute their program very effectively. Like the positive way of showcasing islam and culture.

An essential stop to learn all about the Dubai culture.. Great place to spend a few hours. Our family did the lunch which was very good value for money and the talk was very interesting - allowed us to ask lots of questions....
Good for cultural understanding!. Worth spend a morning listening to an orientation of local custom & culture while enjoying traditional meal & tea. Feel relax overall in the old part of the city.

Informative Discussion and Great Food. We attended this 1:00pm lunch/lecture on August 2nd. We booked it through Expedia at a reasonable price for three of us. However, I later found out that my 9 year old could attend free of charge so make sure you indicate this if you have children and are booking through Expedia. The Center is located in a large complex of buildings. Our taxi driver did not know the exact location and dropped us off on the other side of the complex. While trying to find the location we ran into other attendees doing the same. The location is along the road. There is a small parking lot in front of the building and the Center name on the outside of the building so keep your eyes open as you drive there. The building number is 26 and all of the buildings are numbered so walk in the direction of the buildings in the 20's and you should find it shortly. There were about 12 people attending this lecture. We all sat on pillows. We chose to sit a little back of the group due to our 9 year olds' limited attention span. However, he paid attention throughout the entire lecture and meal. The meal was delicious with a good variety including a meat stew, rice dishes, salad, dates and dessert. Drinks provided included Arabic coffee, tea and water. At the end of the discussion we could take food with us in provided containers. As we finished eating, the lecturer, an Emerati college student, allowed us to ask any questions we wanted about the Emirates and Islam. She was more than willing to give us her honest perspective as she answered. The entire visit lasted from 1:00pm to 2:30pm.There were clean, Western style toilets available and the sitting area is air-conditioned. I definitely recommend this experience while in Dubai. It provides a nice counterweight to the malls and other attractions for which Dubai is better known for.

Old City Tour and Heritage Tour: very Enlightening. we booked the morning tour of the Old City with Dahlia as our guide. she was very open and allowed us to raise even culturally sensitive questions. we enjoyed the morning tour that we also stayed for the food tasting experience where we were served traditional Emirati Cuisine while we discussed about culture, politics, current events, etc. it was a very enlightening experience especially with the local culture being so reserve, it allowed us great insight into the way the arab culture is and have corrected a lot of misconceptions about their culture. Dahlia definitely impressed us with her knowledge about the western world and how foreigners view their culture. it proved that women from their culture are very brilliant and well-respected.

An interesting few hours. I joined the SMCCU for both the tour and brunch whilst in Dubai. The tour was very interesting but I was a bit disappointed with the brunch. The food was great but there were far too many people there and the same information was repeated from the tour. I'd suggest doing either the tour or the bunch.

Get an understanding of local culture and customs. Great place for visitors looking to get a deeper understanding of the norms, and the reasoning behind the norms, of local UAE and Middle Eastern culture. I took my grandparents here, was hugely insightful to them. Conducted as a Q&A with some local youths, and then followed up with some traditional food.

Little like a baptist preacher. I thought this would be one of our tirp highlights. Nothing could have been further from happening. We arrived for an Iftar dinner which was PACKED. There wasn't enough seating and when the meal was served the staff is suppose to engage with the audience for 1:1 conversation to help you understand their culture. No one ever approached us because there wasn't enough staff for the number of people. The centers founder liked to hear himself talk so he constantly sounded like a baptist preacher --- while he shared good information his delivery made you lose interest. I wouldn't ever do this again. I suggest people opt for a "personal tour guide" or gain their experience through another service.

You will learn a lot. A friend suggested we visit this place and am really glad we did. They feed you local food, but also explain the Muslim religion to tourists, including a visit to the Mosque. I felt like I gained a new perspective and they are open to all kinds of questions. I certainly didn't agree with everything, but it was educational. They use humor to help explain their views. Excellent.

Informative & Very Welcoming. We truly lucked out and were allowed in at the very last minute without a reservation, having had no luck over the phone since it was Ramadan, a very busy time. We found the main speaker funny and entertaining. A delicious feast was shared by all and a visit inside the mosque. Q&A session afterwards. I recommend it for newcomers and visitors to the UAE.

A beautiful evening sharing Iftar.. We attend an Iftar here during Ramadan and it was a fantastic experience and I thoroughly recommend this to both visitors and expats. It was lovely to share the evening with local Emirati's who were only to happy to answer any of our questions and share their knowledge with us. It was a very insightful evening and I came away with a much better understanding of the local customs and also of the Islamic religion. Thank you to all the volunteers at the centre for making these evenings possible.
A little bit of history. This was a wonderful place to visit. Highly recommend going here when in the area, people are friendly.

Go! Interesting place to learn in the midst of many shopping malls.. We had a wonderful time there and learned a lot about Muslim religion. We we able to go into the mosque and also view the old buildings on the grounds.

Ramadan Iftar. We took our two children along to the cultural Iftar held during Ramadan. All of us found the evening very enlightening. Volunteers were very friendly and welcoming, food was interesting and authentic, and being able to sit and watch the call to prayer from within the mosque was an incredibly special experience. We learnt a lot about the Emirati culture and religion and gained an insight into Ramadan. Wear sandals if possible as you need to take shoes on and off frequently. The rooms were air conditioned so it was a cool evening activity for the hot Summer months. It was lovely that there was no charge for the children. Approximately 15 minute walk from closest metro station. Well worth the visit.

Must visit place. SMCCU is the best venue to understand the UAE Culture abd Heritage. Its located in the heart of old city Bastakiya. The leader or the guides gives you a live speech and you can raise your questions to them, they answer you in a very clear and polite way. And don't miss to book for cultural lunch or breakfast awesome experience of emiratis food. Great 100 % you love this place.

Muslim evening. We went to the evening dinner there. It was a bit expensive but very interesting. We sat on cushions and helped ourselves to a buffet meal on the floor in the middle. A young Moslem women chatted about her lifestyle and answered everyone's questions in a very casual atmosphere. The food was fine but the chat was the highlight.

Worth a look - don't get too excited.. As you should more than likely expect, with Dubai being so young, this lovely little quaint museum is small, welcoming, slightly interesting but an event done within half hour tops before boredom kicks in.I feel bad saying this - I really did have a nice time reading about culture etc and if you take a walk around the surrounding areas you will find yourself in some lovely little art galleries and market stalls.
A taste of Emirati lifestyle. great insight to the emirati food and culture. very friendly and knowledgeable hosts. and yum food.. got to take a doggy bag home with delicious leftovers

Very interesting. I visited during Ramadan so the itinery may well be different from the rest of the year.I visited as part of a large group from work as we wanted to understand more about the community in which we worked. There was a short introduction from the centre manager followed by breaking fast with dates and water before those fasting went to pray. This was followed by a feast of Arabic food - some traditional local dishes included - while a number of Emirati volunteers joined us, giving a great opportunity to ask questions.After food we went to the mosque nearby and were given a short but interesting talk on mosques and religions before watching the call to prayer. Then it was back for deserts and tea.I would recommend this to anyone visiting Dubai form outside of the region and especially to anyone living in Dubai.

Ramadan Iftar tour. I took an Iftar tour during Ramadan last year. The talk was informative, highly amusing and surprising as they get down to answering any kind of question you have, contentious or otherwise. They tell you about Islam, about Emirati life about why fasting is important during Ramadan and the effects it has. The tour of the mosque was also fascinating as I have never been in one. While we were there the man came in to deliver the call to prayer. Brilliant.

Well worth the visit. A visit to this centre, and the accompanying mosque, is well worth it.The presentation was by a very knowledgeable and professional lady.The content of the presentation was most interesting. The insight into Islam was most valuable. The tolerance and understanding which such a visit can engender is of great benefit.

A must do for visitors and locals. Would recommend for all visitors to Dubai to learn all about the local culture and the opportunity to ask all the burning questions you may have ! I have visited a few times now and you also get the chance to try the authentic food and traditions.

Learn about Arabia. A must for the first time visitor to understand not only about Islam but the cultural heritage of the UAE. The SMCCU provides tours and lectures on the UAE and other aspects of living now and in the past within the UAE

A Dubai MUST.. This is easily a hidden gem in Dubai. We have so many questions for people who live in the Emirates but who do you ask? SMCCH! Go for a meal, ask your questions and make new friends. The entire staff are like you long lost friends, make the time and go!

A Hidden Gem for Cultural Tourists. If you are a cultural tourist, this centre is a hidden Dubai gem, somewhat overshadowed by the towering presence of Burj Khalifa or Dubai Mall. If shopping isn't your forte and you would like to understand more about the Middle East, whether its religious or cultural facets, you must not miss all the activities offered by this centre. For a start, you can visit a mosque and have all the internal workings explained. Next, you can join in for a cultural breakfast or lunch - an authentic Emirati meal- which even the expats living in Dubai don't get. To top it all, the centre's openness is reflected in the Q&A during and after the meal in which all your questions, whether it be a taboo subject or not, will be answered by a friendly and knowledgeable guide. And the price for all these events is less than a modest meal in a Dubai hotel. Bookings are essential. My advice - book before you fly because even Dubai residents go there often.

Unique and worthwhile experience. My wife and I experienced the Iftar last night and thoroughly enjoyed the night. It was laid back, informative and interesting. The experience in the Mosque is highly recommended for westerners and the food and presenters were excellent. The only slight spoilers were several presenting staff had strong north american accents (which was explained adequately) and we also left feeling that it was a little too one sided about how wonderful islam and the emirates are. Don't get me wrong about the accents - I find american accents very easy on the ear but we weren't expecting it for this experience. Also, whilst the one sidedness was obvious, pride in their heritage, religion and current state of the Emirates was also uplifting.We learned a lot and that's what they're about. Enjoyable and excellent value.Highly recommended.

A Cultural Attraction.... In contrast to all the other fake attractions that the Government built (that lacked originality and sense) this one its by far the best and the most interesting. A cultural center built by the Ruler of Dubai to "educate" (in some sense) and share the traditions of the Emirate to the foreigners and tourists. Don't get me wrong, I liked the visit and I think its something very intelligent to do something like to mix the touristic part of Dubai but at the same time explaining a lot of the typical doubts and prejudices that foreigners have regarding the Middle East. The visit its totally honest and with no themes or topics restrictions and for a lot of people its a pleasant visit. In my opinion, is not an attraction for everyone and its directed to an audience that looks more for a cultural understanding of the area. The guides and the locals involve are very nice and very open, so if you are truly interested, pay a visit for sure.TIP: if this is in your list, make the reservation in advance cause the spots are limited...

my visit to SMCC. great place to hear about arabic culture and origins of lot of things for people doesnt know much about islamic and arab traditions delivered in simpe nice organised way - sometimes lunch is served if not arabic coffee and dates is amust there and all should taste

Fabulous iftar at SMCCU. We attended the iftar meal at the Center and had a great experience. We were really not sure what to expect, but not only was the food delicious - the staff went out of their way to really explain the experience and answer individual questions. The setting in historic Al Fahidi is great and a highlight was also the trip to the local mosque (just around the corner from where we ate) and the conversation there. This is a wonderful resource for residents and visitors to Dubai. One recommendation - if you are going to iftar, try to fast that day - it makes the experience much more meaningful and understandable.

Very Interesting. I really enjoyed my time here - it was very interesting. It was an open floor concept, where they welcome what ever questions you have. Gave us all a much better insight to the Muslim way of life.

Learn the traditions and religion information. A place to learn about the local culture and what is Islam. The conductors are so professional and have a vast knowledge to give you A-Z information. Have a traditional meal with them to wind up your experience.

Visiting a Mosque. The Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding sponsors public tours of the Jumeirah Mosque each morning. Guests need to be modestly dressed (long sleeves and pants or a long skirt on women and long pants on men). The mosque will provide a head covering for women. We spent over an hour with a fully-covered Muslim docent from England who shared with us information about Islam, prayer ritual, and clothing traditions for men and women in Dubai. It was a fascinating morning and well worth the time and small cost.

Dubai and its History. An interesting place to visit, as it is in Bastakiya, which is where the old style houses have been maintained. It gives you a glimpse into the architecture of this region, as well as the lifestyle. The courtyard space is lovely to experience, for a meal and to relax. If there are any lectures of tours, its worth staying and getting to know about the culture and traditions. The Heritage tour is quite nice to take.

Historial. Everyone should find out a little more about the countries they are visiting. We went to this museum and it was really informative and interesting. Dubai has come such a long way and is not just what we know now.

Very Educational but not child friendly. I booked a cultural breakfast 2 months in advance mentioning explicitly that we would be 3 adults and 2 children. I was told this was fine and that children were fine to come. When we arrived we were told that a film crew would be filming and that because we had children we would have to sit in the back corner behind the film crew of put our children in a room by themselves. I was bitterly disappointed that we were not told this when we booked. I would have chosen a different day. We ended up sitting in the back corner. We did not feel that we were part of or included in the event. The speaker was terrific and very open and informative. He really opened everyones every to Arabic culture. It was a huge shame we couldn't be more involved. The breakfast was traditional Arabic food - very nice. It was served way way after our arrival - after the speaker had finished speaking. We were all starving by then. I advise you to have a small breakfast before you go to tide you over. Also double check if it is OK to bring children and where you will be able to sit.

For all who want to know more about Islam and its implementation into daily life of Muslims. What a great idea to open the SMCCU in Dubai thanks to HH Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktum. I have attended several lectures, dinners, Iftars and discussion-events there. It gives non-Muslims a deep insight about Islam and the Arab culture. A must to visit in Dubai!

Heritage Tour and Brunch. We went on the Heritage Tour, followed by the brunch. Both included very similar topics of information. In the tour, we visited the mosque and town, during the brunch, we got to enjoy a bountiful table of local fare. Food was excellent and plentiful. The 2 young Emirates that guided us also answered a variety of questions freely, but also skillfully evaded some questions as well by changing the subject. They were gracious and personably.

One of the best experiences in Dubai. This is a must do in Dubai. This was the best experience for me.You are taken into a room that is set up with traditional cushions and rugs. We had a young lady for our speaker and I couldn't stop listening to her. The time is set up as a question and answer session and you can ask any question. Our group asked mainly questions surrounding women in Arab culture. What I heard completely changed my perspective and it shows how misguided our media is about the Arab culture.We also got to try traditional Middle Eastern Food - YUM! and each dish was explained to us.Out of everything in Dubai this was the most memorable and eye opening experience.

A must do in Dubai. I am glad I made the reservation for lunch at this place. We learned many things from their culture and the country and the food was great. I felt that some of the things they said weren't completely truthful when they responded to a question regarding migrant workers, but I am sure it's because they want to show the tourists only the positive side of their country. I recommend it!!
Excellent experience. Went on the heritage tour. Led by 2 young Emiratis. Were very happy to answer any questions. Gave a great insight into the local culture. Highly recommended

An eye-opener seminar... It was a such an honor to listen to Mr. Naseem who provided us with a deep knowledge of Emirati culture in a very comfortable way. The place really take you back to the old dubai. The people are very accomodating. They offered us water and arabic coffee and of course the information that is very helpful having been in dubai for years.

Superb introduction to local life. First of all I should mention that SMCCU offers a wide range of different activities and this review is for their cultural breakfast that they do twice (?) a week. The breakfast is a great way to start your visit to Dubai. People gather for a relaxed breakfast with a local who will answer any question you might have about local customs, culture, religion, etc.. For us no question was off limits and people asked about dating, marriage, families, clothing, politics, food, traditions, islam and many more. Basically you can have all your questions about Dubai/UAE answered before you even see it. In addition you'll have a chance to eat local food (and take some with you if there are leftovers) and try local coffee. You'll get to know a bit about local cuisine in the process. Although the food isn't the highlight of the experience you still have plenty of choices and even people not used to Middle Eastern food will find things to savour.All in all it's well worth spending those two hours enjoying your breakfast and getting to know local culture. Afterwards you can have a stroll in the Bastakia quarter and head to nearby Dubai Creek and cross it with abra (boat) to visit gold souk (market).

A must for everyone!. I think that every visitor of Dubai, ignorant of religion or not, should see this place. It was truly fascinating and debunked sooo many myths about Islam. With their motto being "Open door, open minds" our guide insisted that we could ask her whatever we wanted. For a start, they never chopped hands off in Dubai! My dad lied to me all those years ago. And did you know that women covering their faces has nothing to do with religion and in fact developed because Mohammed's wives (yes, plural!) covered their faces in order to be anonymous in their day to day life. They were married to an extremely important person and were highly regarded and so what they wore became fashionable! The polygamy was also explained brilliantly and left us all nodding are heads in agreement; back in a time when men made money and women stayed at home it was a means to allow rich men to take care of more women during dire times! It is an extremely rare practice nowadays and not allowed in many Muslim countries. Again my dad lied to me all those years ago... What really tickled me was the fact that there are laws in Dubai preventing women from covering their faces in certain work places. In a Muslim country! And England pussy foot around the idea when it became an issue in schools. It was informative and I did not feel at all preached at. I could write an entire essay on the things I learnt and that is without even mentioning the food. The morning tour came with a sit down Arabic coffee with sweet sticky dates. The lunch talk came with an entire feast. It is worth the money just for the meal! Two massive trays of "Machbus"(the local equivalent to a Biryani) were the main dishes. One chicken and one veal. Machbus is quite probably the front runner for National Dish if the UAE were ever to choose one. These were accompanied by two pots of lamb curry and two of vegetable curry. All of it not too dissimilar to Indian food. My favourite! The dessert, gladly, was different; round balls of fried dough with date syrup. This place genuinely makes the top spot on my list of things to do in Dubai.

Helping us bridge the cultural gap in the Emirates. We had a wonderful experience visiting the Sheikh Mohammed Center for Cultural Understanding. They made us feel very at home. Served us a beautiful meal. Most important of all they went out of their way to let us know that we could ask them any questions.Our host Yasmeen, was an excellent speaker and was able to help us bridge the cultural gap by answering our questions and describing life in the Emirates. A wonderful place! I hope other countries open centers like this for tourists.

Highlight of the trip. The people here were great, giving us a great understanding and insights into why Emiraties do things a certain way, even if they appear odd at first. Very open to questions of any kind, and left a very memorable experience. Try to do both the Heritage Tour and Lunch.

One of the few places that has a bit of history. definately worth a visit, one of the few places that has a bit of history and is not just shiny and new in the genital measuring size contest. After reading the Sheiks book, Their thinking, whilst not revolutionary, is pretty damn forward thinking.

Good Experience. Loved the food and experience. Easy trip out by private transfer. We wont on a public holiday so alcohol was not served at dinner but to be honest this was not a big deal. Like the open night eating under the stars.

This place is a must visit if you come to Dubai!. This place gives you an introduction to the UAE, Islam and Middle Eastern Culture. Therefore, this place is a must to visit, go through the tour with a guide, listening the lecture explain the Culture with the opportunity to make questions. It's a unforgettable experience!

Very interesting tour. This is a must do in Dubai and it dispels a lot of myths about Islam and the Middle Eastern way of life. Our tour guide was a Londoner who married and now lives in Dubai. She was funny and informative. She held a Q & A session once she had told us all about Islam and she enlightened us about a lot of myths surrounding the way of life and religion of the people from Middle Eastern countries.

Good local cuisine..... I went last night with barely any expectation but it turns out to be good food with Q&A; even though I live here I know a lot but still good to deal with an Emirati Speaker (Yasmin) and get more info....recommended if you are on visit! :)

Must Go Place When In Dubai!. When visitors come to Dubai, this is the second place I take them after a visit to the Jumeirah Mosque. You sit, enjoy fabulous local food and interact with Emirati people. They will answer any questions you have about the culture, family lifestyle, etc. Changes your whole perspective of the people and it's leaders.

Eye Opener. Highly recommend this place. They do breakfast, lunch and dinner. It is a place for Cultural understanding for all those who have no idea on why certain customs are followed in the Arab World.

Amazing a MUST DO for vistor. Really Happy about our visit, It help us understand more about Emirati culture. The Emirati peoples working there a really Nice, The food was really good, a Feel like home. We recommend this place for a any Dubai visitor

Perspective . We went and had a great meal and a good speaker. Provides a perspective that you normally don't find in the U.S. Highly recommend visiting. Make sure to make reservations prior to visiting.

A must visit. This is a great place to find out about the culture and religion of The Emirates. In articular their association with Jumeirah Mosque allows unique access with the guide, Nasif, providing entertaining education.
Good Food. Went here as part of a school trip to learn more about local culture. Food was really enjoyable. Our guide was very welcoming, and he spoke good English.

Eye opening - but take some things with a pinch of salt. Great opportunity to see another more authentic side of Dubai. The tour around the old town with Emirati guides gave insight into the city's history as a hub for pearl divers. Great opportunity to eat the local food and ask the guides open questions about Emirati culture. However, do take some of their responses with a pinch of salt. When talking about the abaya and things such as whether or not Dubai has a free press, the answers started to feel a bit like propaganda (on the latter issue, what we were told was plainly a white wash). Still, overall very enjoyable and worthwhile.

Eye opening and intersting tour.. I really enjoyed the tour we took, our guide was very knowledgeable and open for us to ask any questions we had. She took us across the creek and showed us around the souks. This was great as we knew where to go back later in the week. We learned a lot about the UAE culture, however some of the things she mentioned felt like they were embellished a bit (for example she was adamant the Abaya was not a hot article of clothing, however later in the week some of our students had to wear an Abaya at the Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi and were almost fainting from the heat). The lunch we had was fantastic and so cultural! I recommend this tour however be open minded that some of the things are embellished.

Cultural understanding at Sheik Mohammed.. The center for mutual understanding brings the world closer together. We are not very far from our belive.. But all religion have some small groups that try to make unstability to a region.

A very educational experience even for a Muslim traveler.. We enjoyed our day trip at the Sheikh Mohammed Centre of Cultural Understanding. Our guide was very informational and I'm glad that I booked the tour through the cultural centre. It's very easy for someone to self guide the Old Dubai tour; however, you won't be receiving any of education items that the guide from the Cultural Centre share with the tourists. So it's highly recommended.

Highly recommend the tour. I really enjoyed the guided tour of the historical re-creation of this old city. The tour was given by very knowledgeable students. It was the highlight of my trip to Dubai. The tour guides are very patient, answer any question you wish to ask related to Islam, the city and the mosque. Don't miss this if you love history or want to take a deeper dive into Dubai.
A must-do for any tourist. This is a fantastic way to learn a little about Emirati culture and food. I recommend it to every visitor.

A Highlight of Our Trip. This was definitely one of our most memorable experiences in Dubai. We chose the lunch, which was delicious, but the Q & A period was what made it so special. Our "host" made it very clear that no question was too stupid, and she was very gracious in dealing with (what we thought were) stupid questions. We learned so much about Islam and the Emirati culture in those 2 hours! Thank you, SMCCU, for doing all that you do!

Must do if you are even a little curious. The center itself has very little there. If you're expecting an interpretive center, this is not how it is set up. More importantly, it hosts programs to enhance understanding. I attended the heritage walking tour and, in the past, the mosque tour. I can't recommend them enough. In today's political climate, the work they do is critically important and something there isn't enough of.

Interesting. We just stumbled across this last time we were in Dubai. Really interesting, lots of alley ways to wander, little shops, old houses. Next time I would get a tour because there is no information to read

You should attend while in Dubai. The SMCCU is close to the Creek and it is well worth visiting. A fantastic lunch is provided and our hostess was very open about Islam and no question would go unanswered! What she explained is nothing like we hear from our politicians or the press. I will not say too much more for you should experience it for yourself! We were not disappointed with her answers to our questions .

A must if you visit Dubai. We visited as a group for a cultural breakfast. Delicious food, our host was relaxed, informative and all questions were on limits. Try to get the boss Mr Nayef as his performance is like a top-rate comedian. Very funny man, but with a serious message about the UAE and countering some of the Western prejudices that exist about the country.

An absolute must when in Dubai. Me and my boyfriend went here for a cultural dinner in the evening, and I have to say we had really no big expectations about it. More like that we'd get an insight in the Arabic culture, and could ask questions about their life. Well, it went over all our expectations. The meal was really big and so good. We were free to eat all we could, and all we wanted of the things that were served. There was fish, lamb, beef, rice, salad, stew, dessert, dates, arabic coffee, tea, water, sodapops. Yeah all you can wish for. In the end you can even take the leftovers with you back home. Then we had great discussions with our hosts, and it was such a fun time. We laughed a lot this evening, and got really good service. After this evening, we both got a lot more of respect for the islamic culture. It is just too bad how they always show it in the media in the western world, because our impression of it is now really beautiful. We absolutely recommend it to anyone that goes to Dubai. Their motto is "Open doors, open minds". Big and worthful words. Always when you asked a question you got a comprehensive and informative answer in return. This is absolutely a must to do, and it is quite cheap. 100 AED pro person did we pay, and here you really get value for your money.

Educational and entertaining. Our gent was quite funny and made his points through humor and fast paced banter. It really was not interactive as he had quickfire answers. But the food, banter and education were terrific,

learning about another culture. Had breakfast at the Dubai Cultural center- which was traditional Arab food and delicious! Learned a lot about the culture and dress of the region.All questions are answered.Book ahead as it is always limited to a small group and books up fast

Should be a first stop for everyone visiting Dubai!. We visited here with a hope and expectation that we would get a better understanding of Emirate culture and Islam. We were assured that no question would too silly or offensive which meant all sorts of questions were asked and answered with honesty and transparency.We attended the cultural lunch which was delicious and plentiful. We learned so much and are ready to continue exploring this amazing Emirate with a better understanding of what is religious and what is cultural.

Truly Dubai. This is a great place to visit and learn more about the culture and people of this fantastic Emirate. You can stop by for a coffee morning and a chat, or have a guided tour around the oldest part of Dubai, the newly restored Bastakia area.

GREAT PLACE FOR REAL INFORMATION ABOUT ARABIC / EMIRATI CULTURE. GO HERE! Every American - or westerner/European should visit Sheikh Mohammed's Center for Cultural Understanding. While the attraction is more cerebral than tactile where you have to read and observe and think rather than have video and "tourist attraction" walk you through this quiet place, the experience is superb. The Arabic / Emirati culture is ancient and rich and peaceful. Sadly, it has gotten a bad wrap from extremists and the media. The Cultural Center shows you how innovative and resilient the nomadic people were, and when you meet the local artists, the tour guides and the staff at the Center, you suddenly see a warm and proud people who want you to feel comfortable and welcome. Every American needs to experience this hospitality. Go here first. It's filled with local art, paintings, pottery, leather work... all very affordable and one-of-a-kind. You want to get a taste of the REAL middle east? This is it. Safe, informative, welcoming and extremely educational. Visit the Mosque, ask any - ANY - question about Islam, Arab life, why women wear burkas - nothing is off limits. My tour guide, Manal was a matter-of-fact, informative, beautiful young woman with a nice sense of humor. She wore traditional dress and explained its heritage [not-religious connected at all]. Great place.

Best thing we did in Dubai!. Dahlia was an amazing tour guide, explaining history, culture, religion, and answering any and all questions. We learned so much, and had so many misconceptions corrected. Also, book the lunch which features great food and mor opportunity to ask questions.

A keyhole look into the past.. Wonderful! I would recommend this tour for Day 1 of your visit to Dubai if you can arrange it. I really enjoyed the opportunity to have a professionally guided tour from Arabian Adventures through this excellent heritage village. We were lucky to have a personal tour with a explanation of all that we viewed on a one on one basis. It was a peaceful and cool walk through history and such a contrast to everything else we were seeing around us in modern Dubai. A must for all visitors to Dubai to give you a sense of the past and the beginnings of this area. Highly Recommended.

disgusting cold breakfast and a haughty, condescending host. First off, I am no fan of Islam, but I went there (part of my job to get to know Dubai) hoping to learn something I didn't know before. Instead I was served a disgustingly cold breakfast, and what's worse, being subject to almost an hour of "enlightening" discussion about Islam by someone truly arrogant and full of himself. A lot of poorly conceived humour and I went away feeling even worse about the religion than ever before.
Well worth a visit. A fantastic insight into Emirati culture. We thoroughly enjoyed the afternoon. We visited during Ramadan and learned a lot.
History. This visit reveals some history of Dubai and how some of the early culture has sustained until the present day.

Excellent, open dialogue. I went to the morning tour of the old village and mosque led by Dahlia, a lovely college student who is so outgoing and knowledgeable. We walked the village, toured a traditional home of the past, visited the mosque, and ended the tour with coffee and dates back at the centre while we asked copious questions about dating life, women in the workplace, Islam, college life, etc. Dahlia was engaging and personable and we loved her candor! It was very interesting hearing from someone of her age how culture is changing here in the Middle East as well as the politics of the past vs the future. The tour was so good that I decided to stay for the lunch and open dialogue session. The experience was superb! Great conversation, engaging Q&A time, fabulous lunch, people from all over the world. Great setting in the beautiful lunch room of the centre. You can take pictures freely without worrying about violating cultural norms and you can ask just about anything you want to know. It was also really helpful to see the various men's and women's clothing types and styles with explanations of how they originated.

Great promotion of Dubai. Went to the SMCCU as a part of the Seawings Lifestyle Heritage Tour. Had a great meal and enjoyed an intelligent, thoughtful engagement with two young Emirati people who were willing to answer any questions the group asked, A truly excellent experience,.
Educating. very interesting, a well delivered presentation, giving one much to think about.It was intersting to hear about Islam from a female perspective.

A fun and very informative experience. If you want to know what Islam is truly about, you need to visit the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding. Gregarious guides will answer any question you have honestly and openly, serve fabulous Arabic coffee, and if you take the lunch option, a beautiful Arabic meal. After the talk, you go on a walking tour of the old part of Dubai, learn about the architecture, building methods, and end in a truly beautiful mosque. This is a MUST SEE if you are visiting Dubai. Don't miss out.

Surprisingly excellent. The tour is really nothing special. You see some buildings and learn about how they designed the buildings to be wind tunnels.The best part was the question answer period with our guide. It was refreshing to get a different view point about Islam other than from ISIS. Our guide was very open and willingly to answer questions. "No, I do not want to be a second wife, but if I was living in Syria with no men, then yes, I would demand that a man marry me and protect me." We learned about the custom of wearing the full body covering. I am not sure how your tour will go, but I would heartily recommend this.

The very very best for a cultural lunch or breakfast. If there is one thing I would do in Dubai, it's the cultural breakfast at the SMCCU. I lived in Dubai for 3 years and there were 2 things I always showed visitors and which I never ever got tired of: the desert and the cultural breakfast. (the rest I tried to delegate!)At the cultural breakfast or lunch you have one of the few opportunities of actually meeting Emiratis. They are just amazing - intelligent, charming, excellent presentators and have a great & often unexpected sense of humor. You can ask any question you wish, even those you'd think are politically incorrect or even taboo, like women's rights, religion, freedom of speech, multiple mariages etc. In fact, the more questions you ask the funner it gets - it's an interactive experience. If you are lucky, as I have been, the place isn't too crowded and a real discussion gets under way. Ah yes, and the food is delicious ...

Traditional taste of Arabic Culture. Seeing and understanding how their residentials have evolved and the life style was a good experience. But there were nobody arround as a guide when we were wandering arround.

GREAT GREAT GREAT!!!. I lovedd this day soo much!! The explanantions, the food, the enviroment, the sweet lady informing us. They even gave me a Qoran for free when I asked for more information as I was interested to keep learming about the religion. Great and diffferent day, I totally recommend it!

Book a lunch or breakfast here. We popped in for a look around as we followed a walk recommended by national geographical. There was no charge to look around and the lady on the desk asked if we would be joining them for lunch. It was 90 Dirham per person and we would have liked to have experienced the traditional Arabic food which was just being laid out in the centre of a room surrounded by comfortable cushions. Although it all looked very inviting we had a dinner cruise booked for the evening so had to decline the offer as we would never have done justice to 2 meals in a day. It is on our list of things to do next time we are in Dubai.

Cultural breakfast. We booked in for the cultural breakfast. On arrival we were told there was an English film crew that would be taping that day. It was ok. We did have to sit at the back as they would not allow children around the main area. The food was different and very good. The speaker was excellent. Went into great detail of what we were eating and why. Talked about the clothes worn by the men and women. Answered not only the questions by the people with the TV show but other questions put by the paying visitors.

You must stop here-best experience ever!!!. We booked a dinner in SMCCU. It was an amazing experience!!! We tried a traditional arabic food, coffe,tea and learn so much about culture and people life in UAE. I recommend everyone, you find free time to stop here and experience it.

A wonderful experience. I spent a morning here exploring cultural history. Our guide, Dalia, was amazing. We explored the traditional houses of the area and discussed the rapid progress which has taken place in the Emirates. I'd read a lot of history of the area, so it was wonderful to see it in person, and I highly recommend taking time to visit.

Weekly breakfast. The weekly breakfast is an interesting experience and a good opportunity to learn more about traditional bedouin food and islam. The setting and offering are very humble (the bedouins did not have much to eat!) so go there open minded and learn a few things for an hour or so.

Warm welcome to Dubai. This centre is a great introduction to the history and culture of the UAE. The facilitator actively encouraged discussion and made everyone feel welcome while talking about historical and contemporary religious beliefs and culture. It really helped to put things into perspective and encourage an appreciation of difference.
The food was also delicious and very filling!

Fantastic Iftar experience. We went for an iftar (dinner during ramadan). This was a very interesting experience with the Emirati guys telling the history and the cultural heritage of Emirati people plus a visit to a nearby mosque. Highly recommended experience!
SMCCU. For the first time visitor to Dubai, it is a great way to gain an understanding into the cultural aspects of the Middle East and how Islam is an integral part of their way of life.
Breakfast with the Arabs. Great place to also learn about the culture of Arabs and respect each other, enjoying good breakfast and quality time debating about your thoughts of Arabic cullture..

A must for anyone visiting Dubai. A fantastic couple of hours.
You sit and have an Arabic breakfast followed by a very informative, interesting, entertaining and funny talk about the cultures/dress/religion etc of UAE.
The girl we had was brilliant and fun and really enlightened us on all the misconceptions you may have.

Nice Tour and Brunch. I had a nice time listening to the tour Guide Yasmin, and after the heritage tour and a visit to the mosque, we had the heritage brunch which was great too. this is a must to visit in order to get familiar to the local Emarati heritage and life style especially that it carry the name of Shiek Mohammed Bin Rashid who is responsible for the progress witnessed in Dubai

Cultural understanding - not to miss!. My wife and I visited the SMCCU for the tour, the mosque visit, an lunch. Without a doubt this was a highlight of our family visit to Dubai. The tour was very interesting, the mosque visit also, and the not very large group learned so much. Afterwards we had Arabic coffee and dates.After some time on our own, we had a delicious lunch, different biryanis, salad, different curries, plus flour balls as 'desert'. Both the tour leader and the lunch 'leader' were delightful, knowledgeable and friendly Emirati ladies, who answered all questions,
Great tour. We had a very interesting tour guide who provided an excellent introduction to the Muslim faith and Arabic culture. She made the visit great.

Awesome lunch 'n' learn. I had difficulty finding this place, as the the locals I've asked never heard of this place, so they pointed me in the wrong direction, and basically I took a 'scenic' route which took me more than an hour to find, but luckily I left 3 hrs early anticipating of getting lost, which I did. But, it is really a 5 minute walk from Dubai Creek. After getting off the abra (water taxi), make a left and walk along the waterfront past the souks. Food seemed like home-cooked meals, which I was looking forward to: Started off with dates and Arabic coffee. Main course consisted of chicken and lamb biriyani (similar to Indian dish), salad, vegetarian and chicken curry. Dessert was ligamat: deep fried flour balls served with date syrup. There were plenty of leftovers to take home. We all ate Arabian style: shoes off and sat on the floor to eat. Topics discussed: clothing, food, tradition, marriage and dating. It was an open forum and people were encouraged to ask any kind of questions. I even got to try on the Abayah (long, black garment that covers from shoulders down to the feet) with the veil. The shop had the coolest souvenir I got from this trip which is a Western/Arabic calendar with the paintings from students all over Dubai for only 3 USD. Afterwards, take a walk around the Bastakiya area and browse through the shops. Also try a date camel milkshake at one of the cafes. Quite delicious and not too sweet.

Breakfast Presentation. This experience was amazing. I really enjoyed getting to know more about the Muslim culture. I did their cultural breakfast on 2/9/15 and walked away with way more than I thought. Our speaker was fantastic. She was great at demystifying the Muslim religion. She was willing to answer any and all questions and made the whole experience a delight. I would highly recommend anyone visit this Centre and be apart of their tours. Make sure you book in advance. However, I called the morning of and they said they still had space, but according to other reviews, this is not the norm.

Need a Reservation. I saw the sign for this Centre and as it had been recommended, I decided to pop in and see what it was about. The first words out of the lady's mouth was did I have a reservation. She was friendly overall, but since i didn't have one and was just interested in what the centre was about, the lady and her colleague were a little icy. So if you plan to go, call ahead.

Excellent Information!. My in-laws and I visited the Sheikh Mohammed Center for Cultural Understanding for their cultural breakfast on a weekday in late January, paying 80 AED per person (22 USD, 19 Euro), not including parking.There are a lot of positives for this place. First and foremost, it’s in a traditional Emirati house in the older part of town – if you want to see what life would have been like decades ago, this is one of the few places in town to do it. Second, during the meal, an Emirati woman explains various aspects of history and culture, answering all manner of questions from guests (including questions on family life, religion, customs, dress, politics, food, and so forth – nothing seems to be off-limits). Her information is absolutely outstanding and is forthright and honest. Third, the food is typical of what Emiratis would have eaten decades ago and is served in a traditional style. It’s not gourmet, but it’s authentic.There are only two negatives for this place. First, the hostess/guide seemed to be the only Emirati working at the SMCC (front desk staffed by a Westerner, food prepared and tea served by men who appeared to be Indian or Pakistani). It’s disappointing to see the “typical” Dubai approach – especially at somewhere dedicated to preserving and explaining local culture. Second, traffic is difficult in this part of the city and parking is nearly impossible. Even a nearby (30m) lot with a sign advertising public parking is not open to the public. I parked on a side street approximately 200m away.Overall, I think the Sheikh Mohammed Center is outstanding. Dubai is short on authentic cultural experiences and the information provided here is great. I’ve been here more than once and I strongly recommend this place to anyone who hasn’t been – residents or visitors. As a side note, the (very good) Dubai Museum is nearby and could be visited beforehand or afterward. I also recommend Sheikh Saeed’s house nearby as well.

Fantastic Experience . I absolutely loved this lunch. The food was delicious and there was more than enough for everyone. You could even take the left over food home. You can ask any questions you would like. The hosts are young and entertaining. 90 AED was worth it. Remember to book in advance so you don't miss out.

"Open doors" (after payment) and "Open mind" (from your side). I higly like Dubai but I would not recommend the events proposed despite you already have in mind to convert.This is in fact the goal behind all the (true) friendliness and all tours end in a mosque.The Creekside Tour for the price of AED 255 is rather expensive,just to see a mainly rebuilt quarter for tourists.One can easily visit the "al Fahidi" quarter on his own,going by metro.This would cost less than AED 30,coffee and crossing the Creek by Abra boat (AED 1!) included.Strolling around in town,keeping your eyes open,one gets a better impression of the culture of Dubai today and to know about the past,there is a museum in the Dubai Fort,beside of all what other serious sources tell about.

Loved every second of this.. Words can't tell how much I enjoyed this trip. I took the tour and lunch because I wanted to ask more questions, which she (our tour guide) answered very gracefully. Her name was Manal, and I will never forget her. She was so kind, elegant and welcoming, like every Middle Eastern person I've met in Dubai (being a Middle Eastern man myself).She explained the old Dubai, the tradition and the religion in such a beautiful way without being bias.While waiting for lunch I visited the souk where they sell different items. You could take the boat to go to the spice souk and gold souk.Lunch was great as well. We had a traditional meal, which was super delicious. I will definitely take all my friends here.Thumbs up to Manal for making my experience unforgettable!!

Just more propaganda!. We were looking forward to visiting this Centre very much thinking that the information provided would be non-propagandist and authentic. However, the guide provided virtually no information on the sights on the walking tour, was obviously very wealthy and spoilt (we heard all about her international education, driver and friends within the royal family). Much of the information provided on "Emirati muslims" was contradictory (such as we all pray 5x per day, when it was obvious from our time there that most didn't!), and she was very critical of Westerners. Give it a miss!

Welcoming and insightful.. Do visit the website to see the calendar of their events, I joined one tour of the old town and also went for the cultural lunch which has a Q and A session where the young lady explained many things including the role of women in Islam and marriage in Islam, she had a good sharp mind having graduated at the local university Both events excellent value and highly educational. Note to all of a European/ Western culture, please go with an open mind to any talks or Q&A and really listen.If you use a taxi, take a map with you, some people got dropped off at the Sheikh Mohammed law courts in the same area. Dubai museum and some souks are in walking distance, other heritage centers are close by, do your research beforehand and print out some maps.

Insightful. We went for the dinner that is hosted every Tuesday. Despite us turning up late, this was a great experiece and very insightful. There were only seven of us and Yasmine (the host) was great at answering all our questions....the arrival time was 7pm (we arrived at half past) and we ate/talked till almost 9. The food was fairly good...it is probably what you would find at a normal dinner in an Emirati household....nothing elaborate or fancy but nothing to complain about. Even as a UAE resident (or probably because of it), this session helped in understanding and appreciate the local culture. Go prepared to ask about all the things about the Emirati culture/rituals that you find strange and you will hear it from their point of view.

Q and A sessions. I was very excited about going to this. I even got to the area early and walked around. When you arrive you are asked to take off your shoes and you take a seat. You are served Arabian coffee and dates. We were then introduced to our presenters. Both of them were students. The main one talking was a young woman who was in college. The other was a sixteen year old boy. The main presenter was very capable. She answered all the questions asked and was very approachable and I didn't feel like she belittled or talked down to anyone in the slightest way. The problem that I had with the set up of the program was that it was all Q and A. I felt like there should have been some kind of presentation that would have given a better understanding of both Islam and of the Bedouins. As it were, it felt like you would have had to have a basic understanding of the religion and of the culture in Dubai. If I had known that, I would've done my research and came prepared. But because it was Q and A, there were a lot of awkward silences to begin with. I ended up asking questions just to get the conversation started. After the Q and A we went to the mosque and again it was just Q and A in the mosque. The whole thing lasts an hour and a half. I didn't do the brunch,but a lot of the group did. This is still a good experience, but I think it could be organized better so that people will come out with a better basic understanding of the religion. As it is now, I only feel slightly better about my knowledge.
A very rich history. The centre is well equipped with cultural and historic facilities. Well designed and educative especially to first time visitors of this beautiful city. Worth a visit.
Delve into Dubai's History.. Authentic displays and lots of information. Reasonably priced and easy to move through. We spent a lot of time here.

Emirates story told by Emiratis!. A trip to Dubai won't be complete without visiting SMCCU. An organic, wonderful opportunity to learn about the UAE culture, meet and interact with Emirati people and enjoy an authentic meal. This small country has achieved so much within the past few years and no one else can tell its story better than the Emiratis themselves. Strongly recommend!

Passionate Host and informative visit!. Located at the corner of the Bastakiya HIstoric Quarters, we were very curious about the Sheikh Mohammed Center for Cultural Understanding. For 90AED per person, we enjoyed a traditional lunch, which included a Question & Answer session regarding anything we wanted to talk about relating to UAE culture. This was followed by traditional arabic coffee (Qahwa) and dates.Thank you to our hostess was extremely passionate about her job, and humorous!

MUST. My family and I took this tour after being 20 days in the UAE. It was definitely worth it. Our guide was kind and open. I think it is an outstanding way of showing us their culture and history and for Muslims to open up and let us explore a little more about their culture. Some people might tell you that it is a brainwash, well it is absolutely not, you just have to go with an open mind. Dates and coffee were awesome.

Definitely worth a visit. If it is your first time to the middle east or into a Muslim country, this experience is an essential one. It helps grow an understanding and dispel a lot of the myths and wrong perceptions of the Muslim culture as well as the Arab and Emirati culture and history.Definitely make time to enjoy breakfast here, the speaker is very engaging, funny and friendly.

Breakfast and a Cultural Talk, Good value, Informative. At 70AED per person for traditional Aramic breakfast, cultural talk and Q & A. All aspects of this were interesting and an experience worth having. Followed by an independent walk around the Bastakiya Historic Quarter.

A must for all Dubai visitors!. I take all my visitors here and it has ways been a resounding success. It is a fabulous initiative and an institution of which Dubai should be very proud. All staff are fabulous. I've been for breakfast, lunch and Iftar. I think the young students that volunteer should really be commended for the open and honest approach they adopt. Thanks again!

Traditional lunch - excellent alternative experience to the glitz. Attended the lunch and cultural discussion. Found the Q&A format an excellent medium for the discussion. Which offered a informative but personal perspective to the audience's questions which were in large part somewhat skeptical of Islamic/ M.Eastern traditions, towards women in particular. The host was charming and charismatic, seemingly speaking from her own experiences and understandings of Emerati culture and Islam opposed to scripted or official sounding answers. The food was tasty and plentiful also. Highly recommend to all.

A great introduction to the history of the UAE. I attended the walking tour through the Al Fahidi district & followed that with a traditional lunch at the center. Our guide was wonderful, she was informative, funny & welcoming of any & all questions we had. i learned a lot about the UAE, how it was formed and how Dubai came to be what it is today. Many myths about their culture & religion I had were cleared away & I left having a new found respect & admiration for their history. I highly recommend all visitors to attend an event at the center.
Very interesting and unexpected. Thoroughly enjoyed the effort that was made to make us live and understand their ways of life. Highly recommended

if you want to know about islam. This is basically a center for islam with many facilities there that will make your life easier. It is not far from the station so it won't be tiring. Give it a visit if you want to learn more about culture.

good morning out. This centre is definitely worth visiting if you want to know a bit of the history of Dubai. It has a coffee museum, coin and stamp collections, mosque, as well as some small, hand craft shops. It is also a 5 minute walk from Dubai museum which is also a good place to find out about the history of the city. Beware though, a lot of the collections here are not open at the weekend (Friday and Saturday) and shut at 2.30 during the week.
Dont Miss It. Our group had a very lively and interesting discussion with a Islamic teacher about culture and religion, Middle East and U.S. The mosque is beautiful
Engaging. Really enjoyed the traditional lunch and talk about Arab culture and religion. Our host was very engaging!Nearby is the Souks and Dubai Museum so it's great spot to visit

Tour was very informative and entertaining. The tour guide was the head of the program and not the usual one but he was very good. He gave a very informative talk about the start of Dubai, the culture of Arabs, and some overall history of world culture/religion. I learned quite a few new things. By the end, it got a little preachy and tedious but it was overall pretty well delivered with some great humor along the way. I think for anyone new to the Middle East, it's a must do just to get some deeper understanding of what's around you.

Heritage Tour and Lunch. I struggled between three and four stars but from a personal experience settled on three. I think this is worth doing for many visitors of Dubai - not only for learning more about Dubai before the boom but also because it's a fantastic opportunity to have an open discussion about the culture. The tour itself was short but interesting and informative. There was a visit to a mosque though the gentleman gave more of a lecture on tolerance and openness instead of something more informational. The lunch was pretty good - and the discussion during and after quite good as well. The main dilemma with the discussion is that it is led by younger hosts - university/high school students. On one end you get a very refreshing and open discussion, on the other the level of knowledge is a little naive. There was a very lacking and misleading answer on the differences between Shunni and Shia (this is not an easy question, and the answer kind of devolved into a political polemic).However, the discussion is meant to be on understanding Emirati culture better and the experience definitely serves this purpose. Come with an open mind, and leave having learned more about a culture that many Westerners know little about.

Cultural breakfast - a must do in Dubai!. An expat friend living in Dubai recommended this to us and it ended up being my fav thing about our Dubai trip! We went to the breakfast which goes from 10am to 11.30am (approx) and cost AED80 per person (~AUD25). We booked ahead online, which I would recommend doing as the spots appear to fill up quickly. Our Emirate host was delightful as she introduced herself and walked us through the breakfast food we were about to eat, and then proceeded to take Q&A from the guests while we enjoyed the food. Their policy is "open doors, open minds" so all questions were on the table, even personal questions about marriage, clothes, religion. I was engaged throughout the entire experience and would say this is an absolute must for everyone visiting Dubai. So often we think of Dubai with it's glitz and glamour, and forget that there is such a rich culture and heritage existing in this cosmopolitan city too. This experience shows you a different side to Dubai and I would definitely do it again.

Cultural introduction into the ways of the Emirates.. If you're a cultural fiend like me you will definitely enjoy what this place has to offer. With a guided cultural and history walk through the Al Fahidi district (older district of Dubai), this is a great place to set the facts straight about the philosophical ways of the Emirates. You can soak in information from the knowledgeable and easy to understand English speaking guide, as well as the beautiful old constructs which have been restored to original perfection. After the wonderful tour, you can opt to have a cultural lunch back within the cool confines of the Centre. If you go with this option you'll find that you have an hour to walk around the district again and look at what the little boutique market stalls have to offer.The cultural lunch is again a good start to look into the traditional foods that are offered within the UAE. The portions are massive and everyone is guaranteed to be able to take some home with them, whereby the Centre kindly provides take-away boxes to do so. You enjoy your meal while further listening to cultural information about the UAE (some of which is understandably repeated from the historical tour).Overall this was a great way to learn about the UAE and the Emirate people and was well worth the money. The food was delicious and was great fun to be able to eat in a traditional manner.

Cultural breakfast is top of my tourist list for visiting friends. . It's a shame more people don't know about this. The cultural breakfast is really good for those people, visiting or living in the UAE, who just want to do something a bit different. My mother has done this on two consecutive visits! The food is nice, the atmosphere is lovely, it's friendly, not too impersonal and you can learn a thing or two. Yes, the answers to the questions during the open forum are answered in a very "well versed" manor, as is to be expected here. But there is a lot to learn and the hostesses are excellent. Take your kids, your parents and send your friends. It's a great value morning. Please please PLEASE remember where you are and what you are going to do..... Whilst the hosts show a blind eye to inappropriate dress, it's cringeworthy to see people in bare shoulders and short skirts/shorts. You will be sat on cushions, so think about what you're wearing!!!

Excellent guides. Great place to find out a little slice of history of Dubai. The guides speak excellent English and are very knowledgeable about how the UAE used to be. The Cultural breakfast is a very nice touch too.Highly recommended for all ages of travellers.
Fantastic!. I can't recommend this more highly, such a fantastic way to start our trip in Dubai - beautiful food, very informative and a must do for everybody.
CORE OF HISTORY. SMCCU is a perfect place to go and learn about what Dubai was like and its origin. The historical breakfast and the tours were amazing. Good history

Learning about the Emarati Culture. I enjoyed learning so much about the Emarati Culture and Islam religion. You can ask the host any question you like including personal questions about the culture and religion and she will answer you honestly.

Interesting to meet some locals and learn about islam. Perfect occasion to visit the bastakiya area with galleries and cafes. Emiratis students inform about the islam and talk about their habits to celebrate ramadan. We had a nice lunch together with local food and visited the mosque nearby.

Interact with Locals, Sort Of. We enjoyed our tour and lunch, billed as a chance to interact with locals. "Locals" turned out to be one young Emirati woman, extremely well spoken, who discussed a wide range of Dubai life from her point of view and put a rosy spin on everything. She was very entertaining, and we learned a tremendous amount even filtering out the slant. Given the difficulty short-time visitors have to interact with Emirati, this was extremely valuable. (Tip: For more local interaction, check out the Saturday bazaar at Wafi Mall, where mostly Emirati women sell their confections in 50+ booths. But the expats there will be chattier than the Emirati.)

Should be on every travellers itinerary. The opposite of a dull and predictable talk about Emirati culture, the breakfast session we experienced at SMCCU was entertaining, informative and incredibly engaging. Using humour and stories, our host had the audience in the palm of his hand! Breakfast was one of the most enjoyable and authentic in our whole time in Dubai. Highly recommended.

Most do. This was worth our time. Very interacting session. Food was great. Learnd a lot about the arabic culture from Seikh Mohammed. He is open and willing to share his opinion about almost everything in a very entertaining way.
worth the trip. we enjoyed this one, lots of little places to explore. Alcoves with suprises waiting for you great crafts

Very Memorable!. It was a very memorable experience for me to recommend it to any visiting friends and family to participate in their Brunch program!It is a very informative and educational session, it really is open door open minds as all sorts of questions, concerns, doubts, feedback are welcomed and accepted and answered until you are satisfied.It really helps you to understand the mentality and the phenomenon of the locals' thought processes, behaviors, and beliefs.For what we paid and what we got (food & knowledge) it was definitely a valuable experience that you will never forget!

Excellent. I cannot praise SMCCU Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding more. I have visited the center many times with groups of delegates who have attended my conferences. From the moment you experience first contact the center their staff who handle the reservation to the guides who show you around the center are extremely professional, polite and very friendly.I had had experiences with tourists and delegates who have asked the guides some controversial and small minded questions and the guides always answer pleasantly with a smile on their face.The food is delicious and the whole tour from start to finish is fabulous!! Keep up the good work!!

We understand better now. This place is part of the complex of old buildings in the Al Fahidi district, each of which is well worth a tour. We signed up, paid up, and thoroughly enjoyed the walking tour with our guide, a well-informed and committed college student, then joined her for a sit-down Q&A session over dates and Arabic coffee in the main sitting room. No subject or question was off-limits, as the point of it is to bring issues and questions to the surface. Because we were staying at the very-nearby XVA Art Hotel we were able to walk to this area in less than three minutes. Highly recommend both!

Wonderful place to take visitors!. I took 4 visitors to the Cultural Breakfast at the SMCCU for 70aed per person and was amazed! The setting is authentic (beside the creek and Dubai Museum) the host for the day who was a college student (emirate female) was both educated, knowledgeable, unfazed by the questions which varied in nosiness lol and had a great sense of humour! We were seated on huge cushions and served Arabic coffee and dates followed by a plentiful and delicious breakfast of varied Arabic foods (donuts and date syrup were beautiful) The host then welcomed ANY questions surrounding Arabic/Muslim/middle eastern traditions and answered with honest and well researched answers.If you have guests who have pre conceived ideas about any of the above THIS is the place to take them! We all left knowing our host country and the people in it so much better and full enough to go past lunch time!
Very, very interesting. Not so much a tour, but a 1 hour chat about the pillars of Islam and Islamic culture. Thoroughly enjoyable and very interesting.

The Sunday Lunch- Do it!. Its ideal to start your Old dubai exploration from the SMCCU.Its perfectly located just in the heart of the old town.I had the Sunday lunch here, while the food as such was not the greatest, but the atmosphere as such and listening to questions being asked from the guide made for an interesting hour. The dates and the Emirati Coffee helped.At 80 Dirhams its worth a visit to get a flavour of where you are and what can you expect. Plus with 35Degress outside, this is perfect way to go through the afternoon.The Guide gave a very genuine effort to engage and answer some very lame questions.I skipped the old town tour which at 200+ AED dint seem worth it , as most of it is just walking distance from here, and you can go ahead and experience it just as well, solo!Go for it.
Brunch with local flavour. Been to SMCCU thre times so far and love it everytime! The talks are funny and interesting and they put you at ease to query anything about Emirati culture.
Very good. It was an enriching experience. We love it. It is great to enjoy food and share oinions and clarify misunderstandings

Glimpse of the Old. I always wanted to take a glimpse of the history of dubaiPROS:- many stuff to see- a very photogenic place... (lots of photo op places)CONS:- we arrived on a date where there were lotsa areas closed off or being renovated- no guides to tell you to go where-signs are scarce as to where to direct you

Great Breakfast and Cultural Experience. My husband and two of our friends were only in Dubai for 2 full days. On our last day, we decided to go to the Cultural Breakfast. We did not know what to expect, but boy were we pleased that we went. Our guide was very knowledgeable in both Emirati culture, but also in other cultures of the world. He let our group of around 20 people, partake in the conversation, many times asking our thoughts. The food was plentiful and delicious- especially the dates! Very well worth visiting. Gives you different perspectives on culture and makes you think.

Highly recommended. It is not easy to find. Asking directions doesn't work well either as the local people don't seem to know where it is. But we did finally find it after walking in circles for an hour and it was well worth it. We attended a lunch in which a UAE citizen who works with the center joins the group to answer any questions you may have. Our traditional buffet lunch was hosted by a very articulate 20-year old college student. Nothing is off limits: politics, religion, the relative status and privileges of men versus women, sex, drugs--whatever members of the audience asks, your host was happy to discuss, fully, openly, honestly (at least her perspective of the issue) and articulately. The discussion was open, frank and with no sense of reluctance to discuss or embarrassment. A very fascinating and rewarding ninety minutes for anyone who wants to better understand the culture.

hard to find. We visited for the cultural meal. Having printed a Google map before we left the UK (no phone service in Dubai) we thought we would find the centre. We got lost, there weren't any street signs for the SMCCU and the people we asked hadn't heard of it. When we did arrived the evening was excellent. The host was very informative the food was plentiful and the other guest were all friendly. I would recommend it to anyone who wants to understand the culture of the country they are visiting.

Great value and interesting. We had the Heritage Tour followed by coffee and dates and I highly recommend it. The value for money was excellent, we learnt some history as well as some interesting facts or opinions from the point of view of a young Emirate woman. The tour includes visit to the mosque.
A Terrific Experience. Well worth visiting. Gives you a different perspective on what it means to be Muslim and what Islam is truly about.

We were disappointed. We did the Heritage Tour followed by lunch and to be honest we were disappointed with both.The friendly young lady doing the Q&A was giving a humourous very rosy picture of everything,mainly talking about her family and we could have had a similar conversation with a local in the Hotel or Shopping Mall.We were hoping for a deeper more honest conversation to learn about the Emirati culture.The food was mediocre and bland.
Friendly and informative. Delicious Arabic food for breakfast, with a relaxed and friendly chat about life in Dubai from a lovely young woman who studies womens rights and law.

Great experience for new "locals". SMCCU is a great place to visit for anyone interested to learn more about the local culture. Groups need to be booked in advance but single people can drop by during their opening hours.The experience includes Arabic coffee, dates and small talk with one of the centers inter cultural advisers in a traditional Arabic setting.
