In a very casual way the country's traditions and values are explained, free of ideology or opinionated statements. Anyone I have met at the center in the past was very welcoming, friendly and open for any kinds of questions. Any prejudice or stereo type one may have had about the Arabic culture might be cleared up after your visit. Worth the trip!An intercultural experience anyone moving to Dubai should definitely take the time for.Tip: Combine a visit at the center with a discovery tour through the Dubai Souqs, which are just on the other site of the Deira Creek (Abras are available for AED 1 / USD 0.27 to take you over the creek).
emirati culture. this is highly recommended. this is one way to learn the culture of the emiratis. the dates and coffee served were quite delicious

Open doors, open minds. The Emirati hosts present an honest view of Islam peppered with unique sense of humor, welcome questions and answers are given in simple English. Visit the Al Fahidi mosque during the guided Heritage tour (Fee AED 65). The Emirati lunch is also a good experience for AED 80. Check with the centre website for timings. The Jumeirah mosque guided tour for AED 10 is also a must do in Dubai.

Excellent experience. My husband and I went to an iftar at SMCCU during Ramadam 2014 and thoroughly enjoyed our experience. We learned so much about the Emirati culture and Islam. The presenter we had was hilarious and made it a relaxed, open forum to ask all those possibly culturally sensitive questions (why do woman wear black and men wear white?). It is a 'must do' for people visiting or living in the UAE. I will recommend it to any of our international visitors (we are from NZ).

Very good talk in the mosque. A chance to learn more about the Islamic world. Especially interesting to learn about emirati clothing and head coverings. Some explanations as to specific cultural customs in the UAE

Great insight. We visited and were only here for about 30 minutes. Was great to get an insight into the culture. Outside if you go round the back you can do a nice little walk round the last part of wall atanding and see inside some other rooms. SMCCU charge for a tour but we were able to navigate well on our own.

Great experience.. I learned a lot from the discussion during the cultural lunch I had with other tourists. A lot of my misconceptions about the Emirati culture have been clarified. I just want to say that the food was not great. It was not as flavorful as I expected but it's understandable. The full flavored dishes might shock foreigners. Beware of the Arabic coffee coz to me it tasted like burnt urine!

Informative with all questions answered.. We had an excellent young lady guide us through, she answered all our questions with grace and good humour. There were a couple of contradictions but she was only 20 and passionate about her homeland. Excellent food with tasty dishes freed.

True interactive session and great food too!. Our friend who lives in Dubai attended this session previously and found this very good. So he took us to a session Saturday morning. The presenter is a true Emirati lady who went to a local international school so she speaks American English. I saw someone said the session was from American in other review, but that person probably misunderstood from her American accent. It was not one way presentation but true interactive session, so the area of topics may vary depending on other people in the room. Our time, there was a very proactive American couple who live in Dubai and, it seems, they struggle to understand the culture they are in and asked many questions. The Emirati presenter was really good to manage those variety of attendees and ensured all had opportunities to ask their questions. E.g. why Emirati ladies covers their body and face, why polygamy is allowed, what Emirati wedding is like etc. It was also very interesting that questions asked by various attendees from many countries actually reflected their "stereotype" of Emirati and its culture. I too was one of them certainly, but I personally found more similarity between my oriental culture and Emirati culture through the session. This is much better choice than just go top of the tall building or huge shopping mall where you can have similar experience somewhere else.

Go if you want to learn emirati culture from Americans. Sad, but in such place we were expected to see local emirati host as mentioned in their brochures. But in fact we got to learn about emirati culture from an american lady wearing abaya..
Worth It!. For first timers to the region, this is an informative way to get to know the culture - as a long time resident, it was very interesting.

Very inspiring!. We have attended the Heritage Tour and stayed very impressed by the experience. The lecturer was one of the most interesting people I have ever met. He explained about their religion, habits and the history of Dubai in a fascinating way. It is a must to do in Dubai. Do not miss it!

Unique and Authentic Experience. A really unique experience, where you meet local Emiratis in a traditional home that is converted into this center, and speak with them about their culture, everyday life, as well as their perspective on anything you are curious of (politics, marriage, religion, etc). I would recommend this as the best activity in Dubai to any visitors.

Enlightening. We were so happy to learn more about Islam/Muslim culture at this location. Our minds opened up from this experience. While previously I questioned why women wear abayas and walk behind their husbands, I now understand. I encourage others to attend an event here.

Inspiring and interesting. We went on Tuesday morning for the question and answer session and the Gentleman who ran the session was both funny , informative and relevant and had so much charisma and charm whilst remaining humble. He clearly is a very intelligent and worldly man who is comfortable with Muslims and non Muslims. A great concept and would be my number one suggestion as a must do for all who visit Dubai as there is no talk about which religion is better and topics such as dress and customs are discussed in a very light hearted fashion

A nice way to learn!. Went with a group of 50. Our tour guide was funny and knowledgable. Had a great breakfast meal and learned about the culture and history of the UAE and Dubai. A must for all visitors.

Friendly and informative. The introduction and talk were well done -- very friendly, educational and easy to understand. The guide did a very good job of explaining some basics of Islam and there was a significant time allowed for Questions and Answers. The mosque is lovely, inside and out. Conservative dress is necessary; thankfully, they provided some local garments for tourists who showed up barely dressed for the beach...It is a great introduction to very general Muslim daily thought and practices, so if you are in Dubai for a couple of days, I highly recommend this place.

A must do for an authentic feel of the Emirates. Easily accessible by abra along the dubai creek and is located on the bur dubai side. This center is ideal if you have specific questions on ISlam and the bedouin way of life. Please book in advance on the website available on google and follow the timings and calendar events. My personal recommendation is to go for the cultural breakfast or lunch.... heritage walks are just a formality and you can easily do it yourself. The real treasure is to speak to the people directly.

if you want to know about ancient dubai. it was a perfect experience to know about dubai ...everything you want to know about Dubai and its culture this is the perfect place .if you are a first time traveller to daubai you should not miss this...

Always a pleasure to meet the gentleman. Beautiful old building in the old heart of old Dubai. Nice people who are willing to talk to you in a way you don't often meet. The traditional food is nice and it's a true experience for new bee's and visitors.

Too optimistic. I was a good expirience (and good food) to take part in a lunch there. The description of the Emirati life was interesting, but too rosy. Ask about diffrences of situation of citizens and residents and possibilities to become a citizen :)

Insight into Emirati Culture. This is in my opinion a must do when visiting Dubai You can ask any questions and your guides will answer honestly wether it is about religion , family matters or traditional dress I suggest including lunch in your tour as the food is excellent

Nice tour, good for asking/answering questions. This center was about a 10 minute walk from the metro...not sure I'd try driving unless familiar with the city. After a short question/answer session (dates and coffee/water) were given the chance to walk around an old section of town, and then visit a mosque. All in all, it was 90 minutes well spent.

cultural understanding 101. our speaker addressed some of the myths about Dubai then opened the floor to questions and even though one quest was very negative and was spoiling for an argument the host remained polite and gracious under fire. We wanted to know more about the Emirate people and, of course, the culture. We had buffet dinner consisting of the main dishes of the Emirate people.

Gave us a greater understanding. Spent a couple of hours here. Very interesting displays. Not an easy life! great area to have a look around the various souks.we caught the local boat over to he gold souk which was only a dirham each

A Must for the real traveller.. This is a real must, you will start to understand they way of Arabic life, living, culture. great insight and set in a perfect location, right on the edge of the creek. If you can take part in one of their cultural breakfasts. a real fasanating couple of hours.

Cultural Lunch. A great way to better understand the culture of Dubai and the Emirates. However, it is not easy to find the exact location. Difficult to find a taxi; have to walked for about 5 minutes and waves for ? minutes for a taxi to my hotel under a HOT HOT sun.

The Mosque tour. I did only the Mosque tour (although I am tempted by the other tours as well) and I must say that it was surprisingly good. The Mosque in itself is not impressive (small and modest building) but the moderator was great and explained very interesting things about Islam in general and in this region and UAE in particular. I would definitely recommend it not only to tourists but also to residents!
Book an activity. We wandered in and found there was not much to do or look at but if we had planned better and booked for a cultural lunch, they sound great with Q&A on Islamic culture.

Cultural Breakfast at the SMCCU the highlight of my stay in Dubai. This 2-hour experience offered the best insights into the culture of Dubai and the Emirates. Our "leaders" (two college age women) were informal, informative and accessible. The food was fine but secondary to the generous helping of intercultural understanding served.

The other Dubai. The Sheikh Mohamed Centre is a great place to learn something about Emirati culture and a good point of departure for discovering the city. I would recommend to take a short Heritage tour (including Mosque visit), or sign up for lunch or dinner in the centre. The people are very friendly and it's a great place to chat with people about Emirati culture - all questions are answered.

Enlightening. We were in Dubai for 4d and having seen this was no 1 on trip advisor decided to give it a go. We went for the breakfast session and dahlia was our host, an emirate student who is employed at the centre. She covered a host of subjects including Islam and Christianity, women in emirate society, marriage to name a few but all covered with a warmth and honesty that made it fascinating. We went with our two sons, 15 and 18 and they thoroughly enjoyed it even though a water park would be their normal preference!One thing to note, if going by taxi ask for 'the sheikhs house' as when we asked for the cultural centre drew a few puzzled expressions

A wonderful insight into Arab Culture. A great opportunity to get to know and understand the Arab Culture. This was my second visit. The staff are wonderful, educated, entertaining and open to any topic. The food is an experience of it's own. Open your mind and take a visit... it is well worth it!
I take a lunch. Great place to know Emirates culture. Good food. Nice people: very kindly and understanding. Also a good chance to meet other tourists for share experiences. Like it !!!

Great concept - highly recommended. We thoroughly enjoyed the heritage tour. Most of the time it was just a Q&A session, but as someone who is not familiar with Muslim or the way of life for Emirati's, this was the only opportunity to get those burning questions off your chest. At the same time I learnt things that I never thought about such as why the prayer times are so precise each day? Our host is a student who volunteers her time for this and she did an excellent job. She is passionate and delivered the session in a relaxed/westernised manner. In fact her answers were so logical that in some ways I found the truth hard to believe?! Well maybe that's just me. See for yourself...
Everyone should stop by this place. A great way to learn and openly discuss local culture of Dubai. Fabulous open minded staff and a great set up especially if you take the full tour.

The Arab Islamic culture for peace and Prosperity. Understanding the Arab islamic culture will give broader picture in strengthening world peace and harmony in the society.This initiative is great gathering for one world and one family of different culture and diversity.

Great to visit when in Old Dubai. Part of the Bastikaya area of traditional buildings in Bur Dubai. Traditional courtyard, enclosed and hosts Iftars and cultural education during Ramadan.Go and learn about Dubai as it once was and educate yourself on the cultural aspects of the UAE.
Great place to get cultural awareness of Emirati culture. Best done during winter if you plan to take the walking tour. Best way to get to know the local culture

Nice experience. Was really nice to have a conversation with someone who is a real Emirati (from UAE).The closest to the autentic UAE that I've been. You should be prepared to answer you unconvincingly to some controversial questions about Arab culture.
Dubai Culture. The cultural experience was diverse in all ways which gave us a true understanding of Dubai and surrounds

An iftar with some cultural food. Excellent, worth going at least once. It changes from the other Iftars which are like any other buffet, except you have to hurry up!! Try to fast on the day you go and don't rush on the date and water until when your host has invited you to do so! Good food and typical dishes.Helpful explanations and visit of the mosque, the hosts had a great sense of humour and we did not feel how fast time was flying.Thank you to all of the hosts for being so welcoming.
Excellent Cultural Experience. You go inside the mosque and the people are welcoming answering any question imaginable you have a muslims. The dress code is modest, but they will give you a covering.

Educational. A wonderful educational museum about history of Dubai. Various areas depicting life in the desert and progressing through to Dubai as it is today. No steps just ramps leading down to the lower floors.

Not the experience I had hoped for.. I have no doubt that this is a wonderful experience, if you got to have it at all! My husband and I had been in correspondence with the center before we left the U.S. to make sure we had a spot at the breakfast and walking tour. We left our hotel early to make the 9:00 am time. When we arrived at the center, we were told that when the weather is too hot, the breakfast and tour did not take place. We were further told we had contacted with the cancellation. When I checked my mail, the email was sent at 8:00 am, a time after we had already left our hotel to make the appointment. We were left very disappointed. Surely, if the summer months are too hot, then this is a known fact, and we could have been told this prior to the day of our tour! On a separate note, we tried to get information from the office staff, about what to do in the area, now that we were there without a plan. Let me say, I don't think it was the friendliest interaction I have ever had.With that said, I would certainly want to try this again - in the cooler months- as we feel we missed out on a wonderful cultural experience.
A wonderful experience. This was a wonderful experience as part of my induction into the region, organised by my Company. Recommended as a social experience too.

Authentic, Insightful. A must do for visits to Dubai. The only place where you can eat real Emirati food in a traditional setting in the Bastakiya, a beautiful part of old Dubai. Recommend especially the Ramadan iftar paired with a walking tour to the local mosque.

Dont miss!. This was absolutely the best thing we did in Dubai. Not only was it a beautiful spot that feels from the moment you step into it like your setback in time but the young people could not have been nicer. So often people of another culture especially when wrapped in webs feel so unapproachable. All of that washed away by the end of the evening. These dynamic teenagers and college students were willing and able to answer all the questions that we had.My two teenage girls especially were so impressed and absolutely loved the evening ..an absolute must !Super easy to step out in front of the building and get a taxi home as well.

Good Iftar. A very informative evening and Iftar was tasty and reasonably priced, my only thing is it went on a lot longer than we thought it would, near enough 10pm from 6.30pm, and a few too many people so we felt a bit like lotuses landing when the food was served. All in all a good evening for a one off night out. I wouldn't recommend it for kids though, there was one there and you get tell they were bored/needed attention etc.

Fun evening and great learning experience. This was one of the best things I've done in Dubai. It was a great opportunity to learn about Islam and Dubai and they staff were humorous and friendly. We went to an Iftar dinner to break the fast during Ramadan. The food was great. You can go to eat at fancy restaurants in Dubai but never really see re culture. This was an opportunity to really break those barriers and speak with local people.
something you should do. a briliant experience discovering this "new" world. We didn't expect anything like this and it was a real pleasure to visit this museum...come on just do it

this place should be mandatory for all visitors. Before I came here, I had been living in Dubai for several years, and I assumed I would already know most of the things I would be told.I was not bored at all! The staff are so honest and open, the audience are invited to throw any question about dubai, the middle east, religion etc etc, they create an atmosphere where people aren't afraid to ask anything, they talk about the history and culture, and really do teach you a lot (even if you've been here for a while).I think this place should be mandatory for all visitors, it really clears up a lot of ignorance and misunderstanding.

Excellent experience. The visit to SMCCU was one of the highlights of our trip around the world. A great opportunity to learn from the locals about their customs. The young girl who spoke to us told us we could ask her anything that we liked. She would be happy to answer anything that we asked. I would recommend to all who are interested in learning about Emirati customs and Islam itself.
Interesting and educational. It was 10 DHS to enter the SMCCU. It was a very worthwhile experience as you learned a lot about the Islam religion. The guides were very friendly and informative.

Very informative and well run. Went as a group of six for brunch session. Excellent time. very informative discussion, open and honest answers. Well presented.
Brunch was excellent and all the dihes tasty

Bastakiya Heritage Tour. We thoroughly enjoyed this tour. We had a young Emirate girl take us for a tour, including a visit to the mosque, then we had tea and dates over a discussion about her life, and what she expects from the future. No questions were out of bound and we learned so much. I would thoroughly recommend this.

Great way to learn about local culture, Islam. We attended a free tour of the mosque here, and found it very worth the time. It helped us understand the tenets of Islam and the local culture. We learned about the basic beliefs of Muslims, their prayer practices, some of the local history, among other things. I was wearing a head scarf, shirt, and capris (capris because it was well over 100 degrees outside!!) - and apparently, my capris were too revealing because they asked me to wear an abaya. Rather than take offense, it's just a great photo opp! Definitely recommend for travelers who love to learn about the places they're traveling to.

A must to all visitor of Dubai!. We tried the Cultural breakfast and was not disappointed - we learned so much about the UAE culture and tried the local breakfast spread. The host was so funny and articulate. Two thumbs up! definitely a must in your Dubai itinerary!

LOVED the LUNCH TOUR. My family and I went for the Tour and Lunch at the SMCCU. The tour around the center was okay, but we really enjoyed the Mosque visit. The best part of the trip was the lunch with the Emirati gentleman. He had such a great sense of humor and was willing to answer any question. I would recommend everyone to visit the place for a meal at least.

It's all about perspective!. I ended up in SMCCU through a friend who's living in Dubai and who has booked this "cultural tour". I went there with no expectations - just one more boring tour! When I arrived there I found two young Emirati talking to a big group of tourists in a "round table" kind of conversation. It was a really honest and personal witness about several social/political/religious issues and stereotypes. It was a very rewarding experience which gave me a whole new perspective about UAE and the Emirati people. We also went to the mosque and in the end we had a local lunch which was absolutely delicious. I would definitely recommend a visit to SMCCU.

Excellent and Informative!. We booked (at the last minute) a tour of the Al Fahidi District Heritage Tour and the traditional Emirati lunch for my friends and I visiting from Hawaii. I have lived in Dubai from 1993-2007 and thought I knew everything regarding the UAE.Our guide, Dahliah was young, smart, educated and passionate about her religion and more importantly her country, the UAE. As a media major, she really clarified and gave intelligent responses to many topics that were brought up by visitors who were seeking answers to things such as the marriage of 4 wives, why women cover, etc. I learned a whole lot more in those 3 hours than I have living the UAE for 15 years. A lot of what I thought I knew was really misguided information spread as rumors by the media. A must visit for ALL people visiting the Gulf and Middle East.

Good opportunity to learn more about the Emirati people. Me and my mum went on the Heritage Tour which typically includes a tour around the Al Fahidi Historic District, visit to the Diwan Mosque and then Q&A session in the SMCCU house with some Arabic tea / coffee and dates. However, as we went in June when the temperature was around 40 degrees+, we spent most of the time in the Diwan Mosque and SMCCU house with our guide telling us more about the Emirati and Muslim culture. Although the references / comparisons to the Christian faith were largely incorrect, it was still very interesting to understand more about the Muslim religion and to see what Dubai looked like before the skyscrapers! I should add that some Muslims may be offended by how liberal the guide can be when interpreting parts of the Qur'an. The other disclaimer is the guide will be English speaking, so I wouldn't recommend this tour if you find English difficult to understand.Dress code is casual and the guide will provide appropriate clothing for the mosque if necessary. Guests can also book to have lunch after the tour in the SMCCU house.

Recommended for those interested in appreciating another point of view. We have had little exposure to this religion and were pleasantly surprised by the experience. The visit was hosted by a lady with an English accent who obviously had a deep respect for her own beliefs and an understanding of the lack of knowledge of many of us.the explanations and information was easy to understand and the whole experience was fun as well. They had just introduced a cafe there but we were pressed for time - it looked interesting though

One of the best ways trying to understand this culture. Visited the centre and partook of the explanations given as well as answered many questions concerning the way of life of the locals and the religious practices observed. Gave a good insight into why they dressed and lived in this manner for centuries.

Worth a visit but could have been more engaging. 1st of all, my advice is go in the cooler months - Nov to March and 'book the tour', where you will learn about the Arab culture, their dress & you'll visit the mosque and gain understanding of what it means to the Muslim community.It's not a particularly large area and don't expect huge dominant buildings as you'd get in Europe for instance. Accept it for what it is.The young arab lady who showed us round was very friendly, though at certain stops when ppl started to ask questions, they were asked politely to save them for when we go inside for refreshments where she would answer them then. I felt by the time that part came people had lost the thread & some questions asked earlier, didn't come up again during this seated 'questions & answers' session. I also felt it was entirely inappropriate when an American women started asking questions about 'historical wars' and expected this young lady to furnish us all with political views. Of course she did the right thing & led the session back to what ..it should be about.. quite gracefully I thought! Go with the mindset of learning about the local culture & leave the political landscape at home, and you'll enjoy a pleasant morning.Tie the visit in with a boat trip over the waters to the gold souk or enjoy a wander around the busy Dubai Creek and make it a full day out.An added bonus for me after the cultural tour ended, was when we stumbled across a delightful restaurant inside the cultural area. This isn't signposted (or it wasn't), and after meandering around the narrow streets, we came across it unexpectedly, so watch out for this picturesqe & lovely little establishment. I don't even know its name!
Insightful Cultural Experience Great Arabian Experience. The host was amazing and his humour and knowledge exceptional. Would highly recommend this experience to all.

Learn more about the history and culture of UAE. SMCCU offers different kind of arrangements in one of the oldest part of Dubai, Bastikiya. I went to the cultural breakfast that was hosted by a lovely young Emirati woman. While eating a traditional breakfast, she told us about the religion, the history and the culture, telling us more about the clothing and social rules. It was all very interesting and she was very charismatic.As a new joiner to Dubai I can really recommend visiting SMCCU.

SMCCU - A MYST WHEN IN DUBAI. Wonderful to get to understand and partake in the Emirate culture. This centre is for exactly that purpose. You can book for cultural breakfast and dinners. It is always with education on the culture as well. You are free to ask any questions and you will be answered honestly and properly. Many time visiting a foreign country you do not get the privilege of meeting the "locals" and to see and experience their true culture. Here you can. After visiting the centre you can stroll through the Bastakia area which is the original settlement of the traders of Dubai.

Heritage Tour. My husband and I went on the Heritage Tour through SMCCU and had a wonderful experience. The guide was incredibly friendly and informative and was open to any and all questions. We learned so much about the culture and Islam. I had e-mailed the Centre in advance of booking anything to ask a few questions and they were extremely helpful and responsive. The guide also gave us very good directions on how to explore the gold and spice souks after our Heritage Tour. A must do while you are in Dubai.

A must do experience in Dubai. This was a first class experience and one that everyone should do while visiting Dubai. We did both the Heritage Walk and the Cultural lunch, both facilitated by Nasif - a very worldly Emirati whose English is near perfect, sense of humour excellent, and ability to put his audience at ease about asking what may be awkward questions about Islam. The walk is a slow paced amble taking in a number of close by sights and all are explained in Nasif's interesting style and his philosophical chat inside the beautiful mosque was worth the modest cost by itself - very simple, logical, well structured but highlighting how irrational the World has become. Lunch was again very light hearted (with some of the same jokes for the mostly different audience) and all are included in the discussion, including the little ones in the audience. Food was lightly spiced and very tasty - again, well worth the cost and time taken. Walk was 90+minutes and the lunch about the same or a little more.
very informative. Visited the mosque. Learnt a lot and very glad we did it.English lady told us about the mosque and Islam.Allowed any questions and answered them all

AMAZING. My mum and I visited the SMCCU last July and were blown away by our visit. The day consists of a traditional Arabic meal with a guest speaker who teaches you about the Arabic Culture. We learnt so much about the culture and loved the entire experience. The food was beautiful, and was plenty left over which we could bring home with us. We had the chance to dress up in the traditional Arabic dress, and try traditional Arabic tea - Karak. The centre is located in the old city of Dubai, and is quite difficult to find, but most taxi drivers will know where it is. Absolutely amazing experience and would recommend to everyone.

Wonderful cultural breakfast. Amazingly informative talk with delicious breakfast. I found out more about Emiratis and life in the Middle East during this breakfast talk than I have in 3 years of living in Dubai. A no-holds-barred discussion.

SMCCU Iftar. This was such a great evening and I would certainly recommend it if they repeat this ramadan. The voluteers are all local and very knowledgeable able their culture. This is a great opportunity for expats to understand local culture a little better in a relaxed atmosphere with great food! I have recommended it verbally to everyone I speak too!

Best thing I did in Dubai . I have been to Dubai before and did the usual tourist things, but only because I did not know about SMCCU. I found this place via TripAdvisor and booked the 1.5 hrs historic walking tour as well as the cultural lunch. Our guide, Nasif, was extremely knowledgeable and entertaining. He was willing to answer any questions and encouraged everyone to participate. Dubai has a rich culture and history, none of which I knew about before and this was the highlight of our visit this time. Lunch was equally interesting. The food was tasty, and gave us a feel for what traditional meals are like. Very interesting and I encourage everyone going to Dubai to pay them a visit. By train get off at Al fahidi station, otherwise you can take an Abbra from the gold souk over to the other side. If taking the train, the website gives walking instructions. About a 10min walk.

A worthwhile Learning Experience. We have visited Dubai several times but hadn't previously visited this Centre. We enjoyed the process and open communication and willingness to talk and discuss. Well worth the visit.

Superb. Great way to get an overview of Emirati life - especially the whole Islam culture. We went on a walking tour and then stayed on for the cultural brunch - it was really worthwhile and my visitors said it was the highlight of their trip - even the teenagers!

Do the Lunch with an Emirati. The Emiratis are not always that accessible, so this was a great opportunity to eat "local" food and ask questions. Would say it was somewhat biased but really enjoyed the museum to understand the history from pearl diving to oil and the present day. Definitely a must do!

Highlight of my visit. I was really impressed with the experience I had at the SMCCU. I combined the historic walking tour with the traditional lunch. There are a few options for tours and traditional food (brunch, lunch etc). Our guide was funny, informative and encouraged us to ask lots of questions, nothing was off limits. They also have traders in the historic village ( which is actually a restored traditional village, not a replica) so you can pick up a few souvenirs while you are there. The traditional lunch was tasty and they even offered take away containers if people wanted to take leftovers home (so great option if you are on a tight budget, two meals for the price of one!). Worth every cent of the admission price, this was a highlight of my 3 day stay in Dubai.

Tip top, best and most genuine thing in Dubai. I cannot recommend this place enough. Do it. I would have flown to Dubai just for this. Answers a lot of the questions you have about Muslim life in a non-confrontational manner. It has changed my perspective for the better.

Very educational and a must visit.... I had so many questions about Dubai but was afraid to ask a local Emirati just in case they find it offensive but after having visited SMCCU which was a great place indeed with an excellent educator, Mr. Nasif, all my questions were answered and I understand the Emirati culture better now which is very interesting, definitely an eye opener and very beautiful one too. In short, I highly recommend this place a visit whenever in Dubai but now that my family and I live here, I for one will definitely go back again for a visit and to be educated by the very cool Mr. Nasif...thanks and have a great one.

New to dubai - You should go here!. Great place for people new to Dubai or visiting for the first time. I went with a group of teachers, new to Dubai. The guy that was our guide was really funny and dispelled any pre-conceptions that we may have had about living in a Muslim country. The talks are informative but the hosts want you to ask any questions as they have an 'open doors, open minds' policy. You will be surprised at how much you learn and will have a brilliant time doing so!
FANTASTIC SUPPER.. Thoroughly recommended.Attended a supper here with our two children (14 and 16), who loved it. We'll be back.

A very nice experience. The lady who gave the talk was very entertaining and we were able to ask any questions we liked about family life and culture. We then had a traditional Arabic dinner, my daughter and I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I would recommend that you allow plenty of time (at least 1 1/2 hours to get across Dubai city for dinner at 7pm, it is rush hour.

Local host give personal perspective. We attended the brunch with our two children. While it was a little slow for them (ages 10 and 9), they did provide space for the kids to play while the adults listened to the discussion. Three young Emirate gave their personal perspectives on the culture - the young woman was particularly eloquent. They allowed for any question and nothing was taboo to discuss. The conversation was flowing so well the brunch lasted over two hours. Food was good - meal felt very authentic. I highly recommend this for real UAE culture exposure.

Cultural understanding? - more like waffle. The breakfast meal we attended was superb. Food could not be surpassed and was more than enough for all who attended. The elegant gent who spoke and flowed with cultural understanding was definitely elegant, but I found his answers to questions wandering and vague to say the least. His point of view I would say, but he is entitled to his opinion. Great for the food. Take the cultural understanding part with a bag of salt.

Excellent for school visits - book a private session.. I organise an annual school visit to Dubai and for the past four years, the SMCCU has been a staple of the trip. It is too easy to overlook the local culture in the face of the myriad opportunities for conspicuous consumption and a visit here is a super antidote.The tour of the Bastikiya neighbourhood is an eye-opener, and the guides (each time we've had a lovely lady show us around) give you a real insight into the history of the place. The trip to the local mosque also gives an opportunity for questions.The real joy though it the cultural lunch, where pupils have the chance to try some beautiful Emirati food and ask questions of local people, a chance which isn't readily available to tourists passing through. In the past years, we have had a selection of different hosts, from local students to the main chap (whose name I've forgotten) who is very entertaining).One piece of advice. In past years, we have booked a private session and lunch in the centre, which has been a fantastic opportunity to ask questions and enjoy the food This time, we attended the open lunch (this was our fault: the booking we had made wasn't for lunch, and the centre were super-helpful and flexible with a few hours notice to fit us in) which lacked the intimacy and openness of the private ones so I'd recommend a private talk, especially for groups.Nonetheless, a really worthwhile experience which I think everyone who goes to Dubai should have!

A must do during a visit to Dubai. We did the Heritage Tour and the Cultural Lunch. Communication with them during the booking process was excellent. The tour and lunch were very informative and we learned a lot. Since there are so few local people in Dubai, if it had not been for this experience I feel we would be missed so much and come and gone without really savoring the experience. A highlight for me was wearing a kebaya for demonstration purposes. It was more liberating that one could imagine! Reasonably priced. A day well spent!
Good for Culture Understanding. SMCCU wa very good as we got to enjoy the culture of the arabic people. It was nice to see how they prepare food and answer our questions about culture and islam

Overshadowed the Beautiful Culture. This wonderful cultural centre requires a highly elevated scholar to make tourist to understand the Balance of its wonderful culture, values and its indegenious people combined with worldly advancement - Having a teenage or a young individual who gave hap hazard statment to some of the questions sure was a disappointment. I was hoping to learn more about theirculture which I believe has lots to offer and educate the tourists, but unfortunately mediocracy overshadowed its rich culture.

she is from minnesota. An elegant woman descended the stair to our waiting area wrapped in her black gown. She not only was exquisitely informative but spoke in flawless Minnesota flavor speech. Yes she grew up not far from me in Minnesota. Amazingly small world

Must do while in Dubai. As an expat, this is one of the best places to go to actually learn about the local culture and to experience Dubai. The staff is extremely knowledgeable and friendly and willing to talk about anything. We went for the dinner tour--wow--it's yummy and a great price. Highly recommend going.
Best ever!!!!. This was the best thing we did in Dubai! Loved the meal, learning about the culture and religion. Had a fantastic time and enjoyed ever single second.

One of the beautiful place in Dubai!!!. Dubai has so much for intertaintment, but one of the beautiful historical place is Al Fahidi Historic District in Frinf of Seef Roundabout!!! If you visit this place you will definitely will found so much fun it is a great place!! You can found incredible hand made products, historical culture of UAE, deliciouse food and great hospitality!!! Recommend everyone to visit this wonderful place!!! I would go again, i'm pretty sure as i am very interested in Dubai , UAE hictorical culture!!! thanks for the intertainment!!!

A surprising way to better understand Dubai. This mini tour of the small historic section of Dubai and a frank question and answer session by a charming and articulate guide. Everything you ever wanted to know about the people, dress, religion but were afraid to ask...
so Interesting!. It is just so refreshing after The Malls, restaurants etc to find out a bt about real Dubai and its culture. Delightful experience, so glad we did it!

Highly recommended. If you you want to learn more about Dubai's development and arabic culture and food, this is the place.Reservations are key as not all tours and dining experiences are available everyday.The guide is a very knowledgable Emirati that covers diverse aspects of their history, culture and present social issues.

Charming and very educational. We chose to do the Old Dubai tour followed by coffee and also the typical Emirati lunch with talks about culture and everyday life in the Emirates. The booking process was easy, we phoned and checked the availability. The tour was nice and interesting thanks to our two guides. The lunch was delicious and we learned many things about local culture, religion, way of life and many other questions. It was a very pleasant experience and I highly recommend visiting the Centre instead of doing other, more touristy stuff. It was well worth it and pricewise very good value for money.

Wonderful tour!. This was a great way to start our trip getting to know the old Dubai and what life is like for traditional families in the area. Able to take lots of wonderful pictures and learn new things all at the same time. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and sweet, she answered everyones questions with grace. The dates and Arabic coffee after the tour was a nice touch. I would recommend this to anyone visiting Dubai!

Great Lunch & open Conversation with Emeratis. Visited SMCCU for Sunday lunch. It turned out the same as what I had expected it to be. Simply awesome!! They permit approx 50-60 people at one go & gathering is addressed by local Emerati sheikh. They take all the questions on the local culture & from their side also put a great amount of light on the same. Food is really awesome.

Very interesting, recommend everyone to go. Very informative session about Islamic religion and Arabian culture and the life of the Jumeirah Mosque.You can ask questions about religion and Arabian culture. For Muslims visitors however the sessions could have been more comprehensive.

Old arabia. Charaterful architecture abd furnishings,very friendly staff,fun filled lecture,free to ask any questions about habits,lifestyle and religion.many myths explained.food was nice,well made,not very exiting,desserts average typical arabic and emirati food

Can't Believe I Waited So Long. I've been in Dubai for three years now and have always meant to attend a meal here. Finally, after so long, I attended a Saturday brunch when friends and family were visiting. Our host, Dhalia, was charming, open and everything you could ever want in someone so willing to share her culture and religion with a group of curious tourists. She said she was open to talking about anything and everything and once others began to feel that was true, the floor was open for questions of all types. The meal was more than abundant and offered a taste of the variety found in local Emirati cuisine. Containers were even provided to take home left-overs! I am looking forward to attending another session when guests are in town and will make this a must-do for all future visitors. Thank you, SMCCU (and thank you Dhalia!).

Excellent place to learn about Arab culture. This is a must visit when visiting Dubai. Many people come to the Middle East with ridiculous preconceptions based on media they've consumed, but this is a chance to share a meal and learn more in a relaxed and friendly environment.

Great tour. Everyone should do this tour. The food they served for brunch was the way it is cooked and served in the average local home. The speaker was intelligent and he was entertaining. He welcomed any questions about any subjects and the visitors were happy to ask away. The visit to the mosque and Q&A session inside (as part of the heritage tour) was an eye opener for everyone in the group. Not much parking outside the building, those arriving by car need to allow some extra time finding a spot on a side street. Take coins for parking. 1hr 2 dhs, 2 hr 5 dhs, 3 hr 8 dhs, 4 hrs 10 dhs! Not many people have that many coins in their purses if they stay for the tour and brunch.

Fantastic. My only regret was not coming here sooner! Not only was it exciting to get here (had to take the Dubai Metro across all of Dubai), but the historic district in which SMCCU is located and the programs they offer are both fantastic. I went for the lunch program, where we were served dates, coffee, and traditional Emerati food. Definitely recommend for those who are visiting Dubai for the first time, or those who are not familiar with Arabic customs and traditions.

Th best Experience ever. This is the greatest centers where one can be able to cultural understanding because this center has been highly rated and termed as the best attraction ever in the world.My visit to SMCCU Sheikh Mohammed made my day to be of great importance.

A small bit of propaganda but well intentioned. For those unfamiliar with Islam, its customs and traditions, this is a must. We went to the luncheon session and thoroughly enjoyed all of it. For those familiar with the Middle East, and its "pluses and minuses" you will find the talks somewhat prejudicial but realize that and enjoy. Spend some time walking around the centre too.
Good Place to know more about Dubai. This Heritate centre adjacent to Dubai Museum will help in under standing culture , language of Emirathis.

Worth a visit. This is just the right place, to get to know a bit about Islam and life in Dubai really. The host was really friendly, funny and ready to answer all sorts of questions. All this while having a typical local meal that was just so delicious.

Simple Discussions.. As a self-proclaimed culture vulture, the Cultural Breakfast seemed to be like my type of activity. You get to ask questions about a society transforming quickly from isolated fishing villages to being one of the richest and most developed countries in the world. Instead of being open discussion about everything that you can't ask elsewhere, the conversation mostly centered around dress: a fairly simple topic. Development, tradition and identity were barely even mentioned, despite asking questions. Thus, I felt the discussion was a bit simple. What more, the host often denied a lot of the accusations usual made towards the headscarf, despite them not being raised directly. These defensive responses got weary after a while. I'm sure some of the other visitors got a lot out of it, but I didn't come away with anything I hadn't already read in the guidebook. I probably would have gotten more talking to a local at the mall.The good side, is that the food was pretty good. Chickpeas, vermicelli with saffron, local-style pancakes with date syrup. Yum! Plus they let you pack up whatever you want and take it home!

Communication is the key. This is a great centre to understand what the Emirati culture is all about. It is a 'warts and all' Q & A session where the hosts encourage you to ask questions you may have felt "un PC" to ask. You are hosted with a sumptuous brunch and then the Q&A session is moderated by a Sheikh and two late teenagers who give a frank and open opinion on their culture, life and our and their impressions of the Arab/Western world. It was a great way to learn and understand a little bit more and dispel some the sterotypes. Highly recommend this for anyone visiting the UAE.

That was the good for us. When we were there in Dubai we were very happy because we get the opportunity to know the different culture in Dubai.That was the unmemorable tour in a life time to our family..
Start your journey in Dubai from here. Funny and nice guide. All the information are presented in an easy way. Great Q&A session. The tour is a little too short though (Heritage tour).

More than a cultural visit is a brainwash. I was really looking forward to this visit to understand better how to see the multiple cultural differences vs western attitude. Never been more disappointes- I felt it was a brainwashing session. I will not express any further judgment but report some of the things said.The burka os a confortable way to dressCovering the face helps again sumIslamic banking is etter than normal bankingTerrorism is just a result of mediaMake up your own opinion...I really did not felt engaged in this discussion!
Fantastic experience.. We went with our 4 children and had the cultural lunch. Very interesting and the food was amazing. Well worth the visit!
It is a must do. For Non-Muslims, I recommend it a must do. You end up learning so much about a different culture in such a short time.Then proceed to the Jumeriah beach, which is a short walk away.

Cultural insight. While Dubai sells itself for its tallest, biggest, most expensive, largest and other superlatives, there is still a traditional culture there and if you want to learn anything about it, this is the place. The informative and fun-laden presentations while enjoying a traditional lunch provide great insights into the ways of life and thought of pre "World Hub" Dubai. Do keep in mind that the lunches are nearly always full, with limited capacity, so early booking is highly recommended. The entire neighborhood is about all that is left of "old" Dubai, with its adobe architecture, so well worth spending some time in.

A snapshot of Aribic living.. It was not very attractive if you just looking from outside. Once you enter the site, you will find a lot of things that we don't normally see in the US.Try to find the "air-conditioning system in the desert house". A very simple design but it does show how people trying their best to fight the desert heat.
Cultured. very good, must see, entire neghbourhood is worth watching, all the heritage preserved complete with old houses and all
Indispensable to understand UAE. Visit to the "old" Dubai and food of the lunch shared with other tourist and a local guide. Visit to the Mosque.

Atmospheric learning opportunity. Heritage walk by SMCCU is an excellent learning opportunity where you can learn about Islam, Emirati culture and traditions in a positive laid back atmosphere with very professional Emirati hosts. I would highly recommend it.

Excellent. I visited SMCCU to get a better idea of the Emirati culture and their food. My daughter and I attended their lunch, and I was not disappointed. The food was excellent and plentiful. They even asked people to take leftovers home. It was a warm and welcoming environment, and all my questions were answered without hesitation. I love Dubai and I travel here often to visit my daughter, but the experience at SMCCU was definitely an unforgettable highlight of my journey. Do yourself a favor and go. You will leave with a great understanding of their culture and religion. Next time I want to attend a breakfast or a dinner and take one of their guided tours. I looked around by myself, which was nice, but I like to hear more of the history.
Very interesting. Warm and friendly staff will tell u about the history of UAE during a delicious lunch. Reservation is essential.

Building a Cross-Cultural Understanding between Locals & Visitors. Located in a traditional wind tower house in the heart of Bastakiya in Bur Dubai, The SMCCU was established under the patronage of His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum in 1998, and is based in the traditional Bastakiya quarter of Bur Dubai. Operating under the banner of “Open Doors, Open Minds” the SMCCU strives to remove barriers between people of different nationalities and raise awareness of the local culture, customs and religion of the United Arab Emirates.

Insightful yet slightly irreverent glimpse into culture. We took the heritage tour and enjoyed the slightly self deprecating glimpse into Emerati culture. One has a sense that justification for the treatment of women in Emerati society is 'it has always been that way, so if it ain't broke don't fix it'. Thoughtful analysis quickly cuts holes in such thinking, but the notion that just because we are different does not mean such difference is inherently bad is a simple and compelling notion. We applaud the initiation of this program to help cut through annoying cross-cultural stereotypes, even if aspects of the guides commentary were a tad patronising in a well meaning way. We found the tour, commentary and ambience to be a helpful, at times amusing, but overall fascinating glimpse into aspects of Emerati culture. The 'open minds' mantra that surrounds this tour is a good enough basis to make the investment to go on the tour. Well worth it!
Great Morning. Very interesting and informative about the history of Dubai and it's culture. The tour guide was very good. Well worth the visit.
A must for every Dubai traveller. The info about the islamic religion and culture. Mosque presentation and the "workshop" organized perfectly.

Don`t miss this experience!!!. I think all the visitors must have this experience first, than visit Dubai. Near the museum in Dubai, can be combined and viewed in the same day. I think the taxi drivers don`t know where is SMCCU but if you say to them that you want to go in Bastaqia (museum quarter) they all know where to go. There ask where is SMCCU is not obvious as it is in one of the houses in the neighborhood, but you will find it. Try to get there with 30 minutes in advance. At SMCCU you can buy diferent packages (they all include a 30-60 minutes talk with a guide about the religion and traditions in dubai). I have buyed the Herritage Tour which is a walk by old quarter (Bastaqia) + mosque and a tea talk which lasts 90 minutes and costs 55 AED/person. You can find lot on informations on their website that you can find in the informations menu on tripadvisor.com (http://www.cultures.ae). Try to book in advance! Attention to the dress code, especially if you visit the mosque, hands and feet covered mostly women and head scarf. After the tours you can visit the quarter as long as you desire.Believe me, you have many misconceptions about Islam in general, so it would be good to do this tour, which besides will give you more information about the history of Dubai, will offer you lot of informations about their religion and traditions. Here you will find nice people who will not feel offended by any questions asked, so take advantage of this unique opportunity.

Understanding Dubai. I strongly recommend all tourists if they can to visit the Cultural Center. THhere are often too many misconceptions of Dubai, its people, and this region of the world. The people are warm, kind, and very friendly!
Cultural insights. Excellent first-hand info about islam and the history of Dubai - really informative and well-worth visiting.

Informative. Took visitors here to get some back ground info on the UAE, it's history and culture. We had the cultural lunch and it was indeed informative, although a bit too promotional and one-sided. I will however not hesitate to send visitors again, as it made a nice break in the Bastakya area and the lunch was authentic and nice.

A visit is a must. Could be seen as propaganda but this Centre allows the visitor to get an insight in to the Emerati culture and way of life. Particularly worth a visit is the Dinner with a chance to experience the local dishes as well as ask questions about the culture.

Eh…it's okay. There isn't really a lot of culture or written History in the UAE..this is pretty much it. So go, enjoy. But don't' expect a REAL cultural experience. I think you get a better feel for the country by visiting the desert- on a Friday- when the families go out for the weekend.
Wonderful Tour. This should be a must do for anyone visiting Dubai. We did both the morning tour and the lunch. Well worth the time and charges. It was our favorite excursion in Dubai!

One of the highlights of my recent visit.. I would highly recommend to anyone visiting the middle east for the first time. Their motto is "Open Minds, Open Doors". I truly didn't fully understand or appreciate the culure before visiting the centre. I especially liked our English Speaking guide. I participated in the ritual of washing feet, face, hands, and nose. The guide allowed everyone to ask questions and explained the five pillars of Islam.

Not enough time to see it all. We did a bus tour which our first stop was the Centre. It doesn't look much from ground level, but when you go underneath, it is huge. Sadly we only had a short time there as there was so much to see & read & take in. Definately a place I would go back to if we return to Dubai

good meals with friendly talks and open discussions. we took a chance and booked 2 meals and 2 walks with this group and had a fun and educational time with other travellers and the arabs from the centre. Very instructional in a friendly and open environment. Good food too.

Understanding the UAE Culture & History. A fascinating couple of hours touring this Centre and learning about the founding of DUBAI from the pearl diving Bedouins to today's richest city. The contrasts from the old to the new yet respecting heritage. Very informative for everyone on the tour.

A pleasant way to learn something about the people of the country you are visiting. Located in a refurbished old house.We went to a lunch, but you can go for breakfast too. You sit on cushions and help yourselves to a very generous lunch.The host is a charming and interesting man, who is very approchable and will answer any question that you ask. I never felt like I was being lectured to.The purpose of the place is to make you aware of the country's culture, and maybe lay aside any misconceptions tourists may have about Arab people and society. Really enjoyed it and would go again if in Dubai. Very informative

Very nice cultural visit. I went on the morning breakfast and was fascinated with the narration by Nasif. He is such an interesting guy and passionate about the history and culture of Dubai. It was very inexpensive and was the best value for money tour I went on in Dubai.

Jumeira mosque. Helped all of us to understand better the area and the culture of UAE.Very friendly and helpful staff, small fee for entrance, possible to take photos if you wish. Gorgeous building. Recommend a visit especially if you have children.

Lots of insight, no taboos. Do yourself a favour and go.. We went for the Ramadan evening and found the experience to be fun, informative and fascinating. A nice group, the host was excellent and had a great sense of humour. No questions were taboo, and all answers provided were sincere, honest and amusing - in some cases. Learned a lot and laughed a lot. Very beneficial experience.
Very interesting. Really enjoyed our visit. Nice to learn about different cultures. Very informative staff and very courteous

Jumeriah Mosque - A must do!. The cost to enter was 10AED (approximately $3 USD) for a 75 min presentation. Also, for women you must cover your hair with a scarf and they will provide them as loaners. Also, if you are fully covered arms/legs they will provide the Abaya as well. The presentation was great, very friendly host with a great personality. You are allowed to take pictures inside the mosque and encouraged to ask any questions you want. Their mission is to create more awareness and understanding to minimize misconceptions about their culture and their religion. As well, they provided a sample prayer of how they pray, the difference between men and women and why some separation, arranged marriages, men having multiple wives, etc. very informative and enlightening.
Very Enjoyable. We went form the Cultural Breakfast and found the experience to be fun, informative and fascinating. A nice group and the host was excellent and had a great sense of humour.

Cultural Communication. Both the morning talk on Islam in the Mosque and the Lunch ( very generous and tasty) at the Centre later were an important ( I feel essential)part of a trip to this part of the Middle East,

interesting. Interesting and low keyed tour of the small village around the Center and explanation of historical Arab life in the Dubai area, also discussion of current cultural mores and religion. Interesting two hours. Tour was led by a young Arab woman who was both polite and informative.

See some real culture!. A must-do! An authentic Emirati experience in the cultural heart of Dubai. You can choose a lunch or breakfast option, or simply a walk around the souks. Combine with a trip to the Creek, the souks and have plenty of loose changes with you for bartering!
Meet the real people of Dubai. The openness of the hostess, the quality of the authentic Emirati food and the opportunity to learn about life in the Emirates, should not be missed

A Wonderfully Traditional Iftar. We booked for a traditional Iftar meal with SMCCU during Ramadan. Part of the experience is a trip into the local Mosque which I found to be very interesting and special. Before and during the Iftar meal you are encouraged to ask questions about the traditional and modern Emirati lifestyle, as well as about the Arabic culture and Islam in general. No question was avoided by our very generous and welcoming volunteer hosts. The food was also amazing.I highly recommend a visit to the centre, and suggest booking for one of the meals on offer for a unique and lovely experience.

Definitely worth a visit. The centre should be a must for visitors that are truly interested in the Emirates' people. A unique insight into their culture and background with a peak at Islam the way it should be. If you have time while in Dubai it is a MUST visit.
Informative and interesting. A very entertaining and informative lunch, and great food. It was most appreciated and highly recommended. Excellent value.

A learning experience. We had the cultural breakfast during which you get to eat a typical Emerati breakfast and you learn about the culture. It was interesting, but you couldn't shake the feeling that it was a state funded promotional activity

Interesting, or isn't it?. It's interesting to do and you get to hear some nice facts about the history. The things that are interesting however, could be fit into a 15 minute walk. It's quite clear their process is well automated and controlled, so the whole experience didn't feel very natural to me.
An outstanding cultural experience at SMCCU. I was fortunate to participate in Saturday Brunch at the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding in Dubai recently and highy recommend it.
Jumeirah Mosque. We did the Jumeirah Mosque tour and can highly recommend the tour and talk. There is no need to book just arrive 15minutes before the start time.

I love it. it is the place to UNDERSTAND and ASK questions about EMIRATAS: from why they dress up like it to do you have the divorce?...The People are gentle friendly and competent. We got a 24 young lady (Deha?), university student on a voluntary job in the centre. She was GREAT!!I have been twice, also with her has a guide, and she is very INTELLIGENT, WELL MANNER and very much CONSCIOUS.Chose the tour and the brunch option ... it is SUPER NICE

Good educational tour about culture & religion. We took a Heritage Tour and walked around the block which included a visit to the local mosque. The guide spoke good English and gave her view of local people, culture and religion. A good tour to become more knowledgeable about Dubai & Islam.

A 'must do' for tourists and foreign residents..... We attended the 'Cultural Breakfast' on September 18th, 2013 from 10AM - 12 noon. An excellent experience!! The host (a lovely young lady) combined humor and facts to help the attendees understand about the UAE culture, Arab life, & Islam. There is a Q&A session before and after breakfast which is VERY informative and very entertaining. The time flew by and we could have stayed longer. Breakfast was good and they also provided containers so you could take the leftovers home!! The fee was 60AED per person and you really got value for this. Well worth it!To reach there, go to Al Fahidi Metro Station (Green line) and it's a short walk from there. Complete directions are on their website: http://www.cultures.ae/index.php/contactOverall, I would HIGHLY recommend this. It is great for tourists but also for those of us that live here in Dubai. I also think that you can go to either the breakfast or the lunch several times and it will always be informative as it will depend on who the host is and what questions that audience asks. Check out their 'Calendar of Events' on their website: http://www.cultures.ae/Certainly one of the top things to do when you are in Dubai!!!

Worth a visit. It was a bit hard to find (taxi driver couldn't find it). One of the opportunities to get some insight in the culture of Dubai, although sometimes we got the feeling that the answers were more politically correct than sincere.
Eat local food. Try out the local food here, other vice a classic tourist trap, but worth a visit around the different houses

culteraly awakening. If your stay in Dubai more then 3 days, then I definitely recommend you to visit SMCCU and share breakfast. Its a place where local, indigenous people of Dubai will tell you stories about past, great sense of humor, religious tolerance and you make ask any questions you want regarding culture of Emaratis, traditions, food etc. There is not much places in UAE where you can come that close to local culture. Kids and you will love the food.
Brilliant. A wonderful experience, the tour was very informative. The Iftar was well worth waiting for. Make sure you book in advance as it was very busy when we were there.
culturally enriching. Amazing experience, very worth wile doing it with my daughter,think everybody should do at least their breakfast! Openminded conversation,and very funny! The food is amazinggg!
Nice atraction. Nice atraction. The building is fantastic to look at from outside, the interior of the building was simply majestic.

Saturday brunch - A must if you want to experience the real emirate day life.. You don't have to pay a lot to have the best emirate experience you can hope for in Dubai. From the food to the presentation, this was by far the best "guided tour", if you like to call it, I have experienced till now. Bit hard to find though, so make sure you know exactly where it is before you go. Make sure to book also as it gets very busy and you might be left out although they do everything to accommodate. ;-)
SMCCU tour. Wonder tour and very informative! Reccomend to those seeking cultural and historic knowledge. Appropriate for all ages.

Recommended for every-one's "to do" list. The Iftar evening was the number one activity of our 4 days in Dubai. It being Ramadan and incredibly hot it was difficult to find things to do outside of the mall environment, but we were so glad that we were there during Ramadan time, we would not have wanted to miss this.It was wonderful to hear information being told in a light and even at times in a humorous way. The concept of being able to ask questions in your family group is fantastic, it really is a time for ‘everything you wanted to know but were afraid to ask’The food was fantastic and the best we had in Dubai. Maybe the centre can also think of doing cooking courses :-)The information about the clothing and customs was also really interesting.All in all a fantastic evening and one we shall not forget in a hurry.

Brilliant. We attended the Iftar tonight. The food was amazing, but better still was the program where we were given information as well as the opportunity to ask questions about the life of the Emirati and their faith and traditions. With only 3 days in Dubai we have tried to find such an activity and have been richly rewarded. Thank you to trip advisor for having this in your suggested activities!

Excellent centre and guide. To get the most from a visit to Dubai it is good to take a trip to this Centre and learn a little more about the country and it people. Well worth a visit especially for a sumptuous breakfast there!!

Best part of my trip to Dubai!. I learned so much during my breakfast at the SMCCU. The food was quite tasty, we were encouraged to ask any and all questions. I learned alot about the Emirate and Muslim culture and some misconceptions were corrected. I highly recommend this experience to people visiting Dubai! For only 60 dirham, it was a great deal. Simply reserve online and then you pay when you arrive at the center. Its easy to find, near Dubai Creek and the Dubai Museum.

Learn and understand the U.A.E. Interesting visit where you can understand the various cultures that live in Dubai and learn more about the culture, customs and religion of the United Arab Emirates.You can check the website for different programs or to book one of the cultural meals and experience a traditional Emirati breakfast or lunch.

Educational.. Being a family of teachers& also environmentalists, it was only natural to explore the Centre for Cultural Understanding. We were not disappointed with our visit, we did go back the following day to make sure we didn't miss anything. It was such a beautiful place we did tend to linger over certain things & didn't get to appreciate all on the first visit. The way that groups are shown & told about the different ways cultures manage to assimilate was most educational, it was an experience not to be missed..

Highly recommended. If you wish to broaden your perspective and understanding about Arabic and Muslim culture, then this is highly recommended. A most informative and entertaining event which the whole family can enjoy. Most visitors to this land do not truly experience local culture and hospitality, which is indeed unfortunate. A visit here will help to overcome this.
Unique and informative!. Well worth the visit to learn about Emirati history and culture. The mosque visit was very informative and the traditional meal is delicious.
Worth a visit at least once. Good information place to understand how the Arabs lived and their history. If you have time you can go there. By Skipping it you will not miss a lot
very good worth a visit. We did this as part of a city tour, well worth a visit and wish we had had a little longer there. It was interesting and told you some of the history of Dubai.

A Must Do in Dubai. Our tour of the Bastakiya Historic Quarter and Cultural Lunch were one of the highlights of a 6-week trip. We learned so much about Dubai history, Islamic culture, and enjoyed the food very much. Our guide was very open to all sorts of questions, and had complete answers. It was heartening to see more than 30 people there for lunch, in order to learn too. The center is only a few minutes walk from the Dubai Museum, so you can easily combine the 2 best real cultural experiences available.

Worth it! Just do it and get a taste of the real Dubai!. Loved this, loved the food, the open minded woman running the show and pretty much everything about it. It was a highlight for my partner and I and opened our eyes as to just how wrong we have it when forming opinions on the woman of the UAE

Walking Tour. I really enjoyed this walking tour. I found it interesting and informative. I especially liked going into the mosque and being given a little insight into Islam. I learnt quite a lot that I wasn’t aware of! Our guide was great and was happy to answer any questions we had.

Must do. Great way of getting to know more about UAE's tradition and culture. I attended the lunch, that is served in the premises of SMCCU in the Bastakiya quarter. There's a local person that talks about culture and tradition and after that there's an open Q&A, all in a very relaxed and informal setting.

Breakfast. We went to the breakfast on our first morning in Dubai which was a really interesting way to get to know a little about the culture. We were able to ask any questions we wanted of the Muslim ladies on the morning. You can't help feel it is a little politicised, (especially having had the same processed answers at Jumeirah Mosque) but well worthwhile.

Open minds at cultural meal. The breakfast with locals at the SMCCU was my highlight of our most recent visit to Dubai. I wish this concept was adopted in other countries, too.We were at least half an hour early, but could already enter the communal area where breakfast would be served. We received a very warm welcome by two local woman and a man. While the women explained their culture and answered questions (you can ask them anything), we were served coffee, followed by the meal and some tea. All dishes are Vegetarian-friendly and they tend to be sweet.The breakfast lasted two hours, but it depends on how much the visitors interact and ask questions. We were shown how women wear the traditional costume. You will learn so many interesting facts about food, clothes, marriage and living in Dubai.The only bit which I think should be changed is that the water is handed out in small containers - not very environmental-friendly.If you decide to visit, please be respectful and cover your cleavage, arms and legs. Not only will it keep you warm (I noticed two young girls in shorts and t-shirts shivering), but you will also feel more comfortable.

"A must do" for Dubai holidaymakers. A fabulous cultural experience, including food, history, understanding dress codes and the respect of family in the Middle East. Presented with humour and mutual respect of open doors and open minds, I came away feeling comfortable and honoured to have gained insight to an unknown and previously inexperienced culture. I have nothing but respect for what Shiekh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum has done for his people in the Emirates with his visionary projects.

Cultural enlightenment. Booked lunch at Drh 70 p.p. which provided ample of food but even more an excellent insight into the Arab culture and the why and how. Well prepared guide open to answer any question. Good way to get rid of prejudices and misguided opinions. Relaxed setting. Conversations in English with participants from all parts of the globe. Good way to meet fellow travelers. Stay in the quarter after the approx 2 h session to explore shops and galleries. Recommended for any visitor new to and curious about the Arab world.

A wonderful start to our Dubai visit. We started here by meeting two perceptive and highly intelligent Emirati ladies who introduced us to a traditional home, tokk us round the Bastakia quarter and visited a small local mosque. Nothing was too much trouble in explaining how life is organised in the UAE, how mosques work and what is important in Emirati culture. Over delicious Arabic coffee and dates our hostesses answered many questions openly and frankly and with a nice dash of humour. We warmed to them and to the many good things about local life and traditions and we enjoyed our 4 days in Dubai a lot more because we made this visit first.

Really worth a visit. What a fantastic centre! They are so welcoming and warm, and they really open the lid on Emirati life in the UAE. Their open doors policy is refreshing as you can ask any question you want, regardless of how silly it may seem (although expect a silly answer back). Well worth a visit!!!

Excellent everyone should visit!. Fantastic cultural lunch, very entertaining and educational. Our presenter had a great sense of humour and put everything into context which made it easy to understand. The food was delicious and plentiful with something to suit all tastes. We felt so welcome and comfortable. I think everyone should visit to see a different perspective on Islam.
Cultural centre. Was excellent and a really interesting place to visit. It's amazing to see the change in the country from pre to post oil discovery.

Wonderful Way to Build Relationships!. In my opinion The Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Centre for Islamic and Cultural Understanding and Education should be a ‘must see’ for everyone in the world, especially for Americans who hold a misunderstanding about Muslims and Islam! We chose to make reservation for both the morning tour of the Bastaklya Heritage Village and Mosque and lunch for a Q&A session at the Center with locals. Our guide was a charming young woman who provided much information and de-bunked many misconceptions about Muslims, Islam and especially women in Islam and how (or why) women dress the way they do. I personally believe everyone could expand their understanding and awareness through educational and cultural programs such as these.

Your Best Shot at a Real Emirati Breakfast - and wisdom, too!. If you want a real Emirati breakfast instead of a hotel breakfast, the SMCCU breakfast program is an absolute must. You'll be served authentic breakfast in a traditional setting, and it's positively delicious and exceptionally affordable. Food is served buffet-style, and boxing some up to take with you is encouraged by the host. For that reason alone, you should make sure this is part of your Dubai trip.Incredible breakfast aside, the other portion of the event that is perhaps equally exciting is that the breakfast is hosted by an Emirati who works with the SMCCU on their "Open Doors, Open Minds" project. He invites in a small group of Emiratis (when I visited, it was students from a tech school) who sit amongst the guests and join in a discussion about culture and tradition while breakfast is eaten. My only gripe, which is not preventing me from giving a five-star review, is that I had hoped the talk would highlight the differences between Emiratis and natives of neighboring countries. Instead, most of the discussion was taken up by tourists who wanted to know more about religious customs. My hoped-for Emirati 101 class wound up being an Islam 101 class (and I already knew the course material). The bottom line is that the breakfast is great, you'll have the opportunity to ask any questions you like about Emirati or Islamic culture, and for some of the Emiratis who are brought in to the program, you'll be the first Western person they've ever talked to or broken bread with. It's a wonderful experience and I was very pleased to have taken part in it.

This will change your opinion about Arab culture and what you may think about Muslims. I have visited the SMCCU many times and always find it rewarding. I go for the cultural breakfast which is worth the fee alone. However it is the relaxed atmosphere and candid approach, encouraging any questions that is the real reason to go. The welcome is warm and genuine; I've taken friends who are fairly allergic to 'cultural' experiences and they've not stopped talking about it. The Burj Khalifa is only one side of Dubai - this gives a glimpse into the lives of the people whose land it is.
