Can learn a little about Islam. I thought it was a worthwhile stop and taught me a little about Islam and some of the beliefs and customs. The speaker was maybe a little pushy and biased but it was still interesting.

So enjoyable.. A wonderful way to learn about the local traditions and food.I thoroughly enjoyed my visit here and would put it on a must do list. It's quite near the Dubai Museum and Textile Souk and a short abra ride across the creek to the Gold and Spice Souks.There is lunch or breakfast available depending on which day you go at a very minimal price.

Everyone visiting Dubai should add to their list of must-do's. The speakers are excellent, entertaining and make you very comfortable to ask any questions you might have about religion or customs. The food is also very good. We booked the Big Bus tour for two days. They have a stop at the museum and you can just walk back to the round-about and you will see it.

Rare place where they are open about religious and political discussion. The tour started off very well with all kinds of openness to questions, philosophies, ideas and discussions but towards the end it became more of a single view/showcase of one religion.The traditional food was great and the host Mr. Naseer was very good at hosting.Western travelers might enjoy it more as a learning of middle eastern culture and ideas.

Go for a meal - better value than Bastakiya Walking Tour - 60 mins. We did the walking tour, which was short & only covered a small area. We booked the breakfast on the morning of the tour, to be done after the walking tour. Most of the cultural information was given during the breakfast, which was excellent & held in a large room at the centre, decorated & furnished in traditional style.The food presentation was excellent & the breakfast dishes were delicious. Our group was not large so we were invited to take some food with us & given aluminium containers with lids & plastic bags. They also offer lunch & dinner experiences. The talk was interesting & we were encouraged to ask any questions we liked. Although we learnt a great deal, you felt that some religious practices were being justified by logical reasoning rather than by the real beliefs behind them. Nevertheless, it was very informative & provided a unique opportunity for developing insight into the local culture. I would recommend this as part of your itinerary. Hope this has been of assistance & adds to the enjoyment of your UAE travel experience.

Interesting. Really interesting once I was able to find out where I was going. I took the Big Bus and it just dropped me off - it took a bit of hunting from there to find what I was looking for. The photographs were the most interesting.

A must -a bit of Dubai culture and tradition!. Dubai is so glitz and glamour all the time, that visitors very often forget that is does have its own history and traditions prior to the boom and current modern metropolis status! If you plan to do ONE thing different during your time in Dubai, this is the right place for you. Centre for Cultural Understanding is government funded organisation, a kind of tourism organisation that promotes Emirati culture and traditions to visitors. They have different kinds of activities: you can choose among a traditional breakfast or lunch, a guided walking tour around Bastakiya (only area of Dubai more that 100 years old) or a guided visit to Jumeirah mosque, to name a few. On all tours/events/visits/lunch/breakfasts, they have professional and informative Emirati (English-speaking) guides who patiently explain and show traditional side of Emirati culture that you will not have a chance to see anywhere else unless an Emirati invites you to their home. And all is very reasonably priced: from a 3 euros (5 US dollars) guided visit to mosque and 7 euros (10 US$) 60 min guided walk around Bastakiya to 12 euros (18 US$) cultural breakfast (traditional food and 60 min chat)- they are all steals! In short - DO go on one of these tours (breakfast is my favourite, however they are all nice -I tried them all as I always take my visitors there), you will have fun and learn more about Dubai culture in an hour that you will in rest of your stay in Dubai!PS. Reservations are a must, so make sure you call them in advance - they are not so responsive over email. :(

Wonderful. This was my favorite day. We learned so much from Nassif our host for the morning. I felt like we had made a new friend. I could have stayed all day! The lunch was delicious too. Definitely this is a must for every Dubai visitor. Open your mind!!

If you only do 1 thing in Dubai. In a city that lacks 'authenticity' this is the one thing that you can do to find it.I did the cultural brunch. The meal itself was enjoyable but the best bit was the no holes barred discussion on Dubai life, culture and religion. I gained a lot of knowledge and now view the place differently. Worth doing

Eye opener for those who are keen to learn. We did a dinner and tour organised by SMCCU during Ramadan and what an experience it was! It is done by locals, who tell you a lot of interesting things about their culture, religion, and you can ask them any question you like and they will try to answer it! They are fun, friendly, and entertaining. Many know that locals don't tend to mix wit the expats so this is a great opportunity to meet them and speak to them. The dinner was delicious, too. It was one of the best experiences i've had in Dubai and would recommend to anyone living here or just visiting.
SMCCU. Helps understand we're it all began where it now and their future plans. The place is a bit small for the amount of tourists that were there

A bit of culture. Dubai is often seen as a place with little or no culture, a vist to the SMCCU and you will find that this is incorrect. The breakfast is a great opportunity to find out everything you want to know (e.g why do emirati women wear black?) and to experience the traditional food of the region. The opportunity to sit down with an emirati is rare and you will definitely learn something new.

Very informative Tour. We signed up for the Bastakiya Heritage Tour after reading all the good reviews for these. Without a doubt, this tour was very informative and insightful. The tour began inside the Jumeirah mosque with the tour leader explaining the function of the mosque and why Muslim people pray etc. His tour/speech was so amazing that I wished it could lasted more. I loved the way he answered the questions from the non-muslim participant in a very politically correct way. As a muslim myself, I found his answer to be very well replied. After which, we were led through the Bastakiya tour, with the tour leader explaining why the houses, road and infrastructure in Dubai were built in such a way. Afterwhich, we were gathered inside this small room which so called represent how the Arabians normal living room will normally look like. Inside this room, the shared with us some Arabic sweet delicacy and explained to us more about the Arabs culture, costume and etc. Thought the tour is only about 1 and half hour long, I find it to be very informative and I wish I could go for another round.

Small, but interesting. We went for the morning tour of the Bastakiya area. We arrived about 10 minutes late, but were permitted to join up with the group. We had been to the Dubai museum the night before, and a lot of the information given was very similar. However, we did learn a lot of interesting facts about the culture in the UAE from our guide. She was open to questions, and answered many, but would answer some with "we will discuss that in depth during the breakfast."The tour didn't last too long. There was a coin museum that we spent some time looking at. After that we went back inside for Arabic tea and dates. Again, many times they said that there would be detailed answers to questions during the breakfast. My friend and I had only signed up for the tour, so we missed out on some of those conversations afterwards. After our tour, we walked around on our own for a bit and stumbled upon a cafe, Basta Art Cafe. It was very cute, and almost felt like we were in a garden. The Lemon Mint juice was incredible. If you are in the area, you should definitely stop in to cool off after your tour.

Very interesting- worth a trip. If you're visiting Dubai or you're a resident, this is worth visiting. The lunch was OK (no bread sadly) and a lot of greasy food, but the talk was very interesting and informative

A Welcome break from the Malls........ With just 4 days in Dubai, I chose a Sunday (Easter Sunday) because of lunch but due to a private function, it was cancelled that day. So it was a pity that when starting the tour, lunch was available due to a cancellation - but we’d already made plans.However, a visit to the SMCCU was a welcome distraction or antidote to the rest of the city. An informative, & amusing at times, cultural tour with a visit to Jumeira Mosque, a short guide to the museum followed by tea & dates & a question/answer forum. One lasting memory………….not everyone are ‘oil-rich Arabs’

Wonderful lunch program. Had the opportunity to attend a cultural lunch program while visiting Dubai, and loved the experience. Tasting the variety of foods offered was great in and of itself, but the two women hosting the lunch really made the experience wonderful. They were very well-spoken, interacted with the attendees, and gave some good insights into aspects of culture and hospitality that I wouldn't have learned otherwise. Well worth the experience, and I hope to try a breakfast and/or tour program on future visits. Great way to learn about Emirati culture.

A Cultural Treat. It's easy to visit Dubai and get carried away by all the modern buildings and attractions, but visit to the Centre for Cultural Understanding was a highlight for us. We attended the breakfast, which was relaxed and informative, giving us an insight to life in Dubai behind the scenes. The Centre is only a short walk from the Dubai Museum and the Souks so you can combine a visit there after your breakfast.

Visited Jumeira Mosque. Joined the tour at 10 am. Very welcoming and informative. Open to all questions and answered with a pleasant sense of humour. Very detailed and we were very glad we went. Would highly recommend.

A must do if you are interested in the culture. Sitting on the pillowed floor, without my shoes, and listening to a local address religion, culture, traditions, the Dubai growth, the foods, the family, the clothing was just wonderful. I learned so much about humility and tolerance. There is a special breakfast or lunch with an Emirati. There is a cost and you should go with an open heart and mind. You will be amazed. Now, we had a terrific woman who encouraged us to ask all kinds of questions: Our group was mixed with local expats and tourists from all over. I´m not even sure everyone spoke English, but we all enjoyed the food and the demonstration on how to wear your dishdasha or abaya.And do take time to wander around the stores and buildings. You will be welcomed in to browse or shop.

Great intro to the culture of Dubai. It's a great morning visit. Wonderful staff, and a quick intro to the culture, religion etc. Someone very clearly explains the nuances of UAE culture and helps the non-initiated understand it from the local perspective.

Begin Your Journey Here!. My husband and I attended the cultural lunch on our 2nd day in Dubai. The food and hospitality was wonderful, but the highlight was really the conversation. There were no "off limit" topics. We discussed everything from food, gender roles, Islam, the economic growth in the UAE and more. As an American, it was a great way to start our vacation on a foundation of awareness and understanding instead of the stereotypes that flood us from Hollywood and the media.

Opened our eyes. I am so glad we attended the Centre, it was an extremely educational visit. We went for the lunch program, and the food was very good, but the presentation was excellent. Many myths were explained and overall it was an eye opening experience.

Great real experience in Dubai. This is one of my favourite thing to do in Dubai. I take all my visitors to Dubai here. What an amazing opportunity to get to ask any questions about emirati culture and lifestyle. The food is good as well. A fantastic way to dispel myths and really understand the place where we live.

Don't miss the Jumeriah Mosque tour. I very much enjoyed the Jumerian Mosque tour from the SMCCU. I felt so enlightened afterward! It was very informative without being preachy. I didn't feel like I was being talked down to nor did I feel that the subject matter was over my head. Very educational and probably the only cultural experience you'll have in Dubai, which is generally devoid of culture.
A must visit. Lovely way of getting acquainted with local culture and food! Great way to ask questions and have them answered too!
Cool authentic site. Great idea, easy to get to, and very calm atmosphere. No street sellers or interruptions. Just ability to stroll around and experience the old Dubai.
Excellent. Took 16 teenagers on a cricket trip, moaned all the way there..then just loved it. Brilliantly done, food amazing, nothing off limits. Such a good idea. Thank you

AN EYE OPENING EXPERIENCE. This is the only time you will be able to speak to an Emirati about their culture, country and faith.It is the most worthwhile hour you will spend in Dubai.Go and take your children ... learn about the culture and religion.I urge every one of my visitors to go and they always come back extremely pleased that they went.

First time to UAE? Do this first!. I'm so glad I listened to fellow TripAdvisor members. My girlfriend and I completed this on our first trip to Dubai.Our tour guides were both very well spoken in English and quite funny. Complete the morning session plus lunch, and don't be afraid to ask any questions that's on your mind.We covered dress codes, Muslim culture, the separation of men and women and more.Great morning and the Arab coffee and dates were delicious.
an interesting educational visit. A great place to learn about the culture and the people of the UAE. A must visit. This should be one of the first stops you make on your visit to Dubai.

A M U S T!. Fantastic and down-to-earth way to understand many things we, westeners do not comprhend. My family and I traveled a lot, and currently living in Turkey, this is a must for everyone visiting Dubai.

Building Bridges. A very useful experience, even for someone who has studied comparative religions. First timers to the ME/an Islamic country should make the time to participate. Helps break down the biases that the western media propagates. My experience was led by a British expat who had converted, which further helped the experience. Main drawback was that there was a small charge - given the wealth of the area, it should be free for foreigners/tourists.
outstanding. i am an atheist, but this was a very moving and spiritual experience. its a must . or visit the mosque school in jumeria. brilliant place.

Don't miss a visit to the SMCCU. Great way to get to know the Muslim religion!The guide is a Muslim converted British woman.I thought this visit gave me a much broader understanding of the Muslim religion. I did not share all the guide's beliefs but I thought it was anyway very interesting and well organize. The tour and talk commence every day at 10am but make sure to be there already at 9.40. Cost= 10 dirhams per person.Women should wear appropriate clothes this meaning covered shoulders and knees and head. Men should not wear shorts that do not cover the knees. If you don't wear conservative clothes they borrow you some just outside the mosque.Again, a well worth visit that broadens your understanding and knowledge of the Muslim religion according to the center's motto: open doors, open minds!

Learn about Emirati life. There are options to take breakfast, lunch or just a tour and I would recommend the tour plus lunch. Meeting at 10am, you are taken on an informative tour of Bastakiya, one of the few old area in Dubai, with a visit to the mosque included. Our guide was knowledgeable and happy to answer any questions. Then back to the cultural centre for a typical middle eastern meal, followed by a question and answer session. You need to book in advance, particularly for the lunch, but try to fit this trip in if you're visiting Dubai

Learnt a lot. Really good, informative 90 minute tour. Learnt lots about the origins of Dubai and the original settlement. Enjoyed the visit to the mosque and the young lady leading the tour was happy to answer all the questions. Dates were yummy and the coffee not at all what I expected. Would highly recommend

Nice lunch and QA session. This was a good opportunity to have an authentic gulf-style meal and ask your embarrassing questions. It could have been a bit more structured to provide more of a broad overview of Arab culture though.

Highly Recommend the Heritage Tour and Cultural Lunch!. We visted the cultural center on a Tuesday and enjoyed the Heritage Tour from 10:30-12 and then the lunch from 1-2:30. This was a fantastic way to see the Bastikiya Quarter or the old section of Dubai plus enjoy a delicious lunch. Both were very reasonably priced. On the Heritage Tour, they give you entry to a mosque that is otherwise closed to non-muslims. Both during the tour and during the lunch, they opened up the floor for questions of any kind. This was a great environment for us as Westerners to ask all sort of questions and for them to debunk some stereotypes about their religion and culture. They were very friendly and open to answering any questions no matter how outlandish.

Awesome Place to visit !!. It was an ultimate opportunity to get awareness about Emirati culture , getting answers of hard questions & having delicious traditional arab cuisine. It justified its tagline "Open doors & Open minds" !!

Good for an insight into the culture.. It was interesting, we did the breakfast at 10.00am, the food was good although a touch sweet. the guy talking was very good although i'm not sure he was being completly honest as Dubai Media were filming so I felt he was being reserved with his answers.

Best Cultural Experience in Dubai. This should be the first stop for anyone visiting Dubai. You can learn so mich about the Emirate people and Islam. It's a very welcoming environment where you can feel free to ask any question. I found it highly enlightening.

Open minds!. I participated in the Heritage Tour, which included a visit to the Bastakia Quarter, a mosque and a chat with refreshments afterward. It was 55AED and worth every penny. Very informative and a great chance to learn about Emirate culture, Muslim traditions. I love that you are encouraged to ask questions about anything (do men have four wives? why do women cover up? why don't you see many women on the streets in dubai?)The guides were two females, I can't recall their names but they were personable, friendly and knowledgable.Highly recommend, a fantastic chance to learn.

excellent place....very informative...conduct Arabic classes on Fridays and Saturdays. one can learn about Dubai, its history, culture everything under one roof at this center. All one has to do is call SMCCU and fix up a day and time for them to be shown around Saturday Mornings are interactive days.Very well organized and friendly team at SMCCU

In depth introduction to Muslim culture. It was an enriching experience, we were encouraged to ask as many questions as we wanted in a very open atmosphere. I did learned a lot about the rituals and culture, it was fascinating. It is a must if you are visiting Dubai.
Amazing !. I was very impressed. This is one of the most entertaining and enriching things I've done in Dubai, and it's free or just very very cheap!I fully recommend a visit to this centre!
Much to learn. A very well presented and interactive discussion on Islam. Definately recommend this when you visit Dubai

Open doors, open minds!. This is exactly what The attraction is, a very friendly way to show the Arabic Culture and way of life. All the visitors, while in Dubai, should come. I booked for the Hertage walk and the lunch, and bote were worthy.

worth it. it was a great opportunity to understand more about islam. it makes you think a little more about the local population and why they look and act the way they do. This centre is a good idea to promote understanding and tolerance. I'm glad I went.

Thoughtful Introduction to Islam. An excellent opportunity to learn about Islam and be inside a Mosque. We jest attend the Mosque visit. Tour starts on certain days at 10:00 am. The tour guide spoke perfect English and was from England, having converted to Islam. She was very knowledgeable in her explanation of Islam and in answering the open-ended questions. I learned a great deal from her. There was also an explanation of the Islam pray. The concept of Open doors Open Minds is an appropriate statement for this tour. Well worth the time to visit this place. I gained a better understanding of Islam, having had very limited knowledge before.

An Unmissable Cultural Experience!. This tour was an all-access pass to the realities of ancient and modern-day Emirate culture. The guides were open, friendly and hospitable. We were informed of, and entertained in the traditional ways of the Emirati by warm and good-humoured hosts who were willing to tackle the most cryptic and taboo of questions. This is a non-profit organisation, so the volunteers are doing this out of the goodness of their own hearts. I really saw a genuine sense of pride and reverence that they have for their heritage in recognition of their humble beginnings.This is a must-see for any tourist who wants a real glimpse into the way of life in the UAE or any expat who wants to delve a little deeper than the superficial bright lights and flashy toys that Dubai has to offer. Wonderful!

Great insight in Dubai culture. We booked a tour in the centre, was worth it! I learnt a lot about the history of Dubai, Islam religion and the daily life of people.I fully recommend a visit to this centre!

A must if you look for more than malls and tall buildings. We decided to book the 90 min heritage tour based on the reviews on tripadvisor. We were not disappointed! The tour was great and we were given lots of interesting details and information regarding the islamic culture and the ordinary life in the emirates. It's a pity that the tours are not everyday and there is only one session per day! Important: booking is required, but you can also book online on their website

Great place for those looking for more than just skyscrapers. We enjoyed a very nice lunch with traditional food and learned all about traditional and modern cultural norms in U.A.E. The facilitators had a great sense of humour as well as being informative
Outstanding. Bastakiya walking tour was extremely informative and entertaining. Well worth the time and money to learn about Islamic culture.

A must for every visitor.. An excellent and brief introduction to the life in Dubai. It was an absolute eye opener and so brilliantly done by our guide. Especially the visit to the mosque and discussion on religion and dress code.

A view into Past!. Visited SMCCU on 24 Dec with family and took a 90 min guided walking tour of Bastakia. Culturally not as informative as expected. Visitors were expected to seek information rather than the center providing the information. There are quite a few displays on traditional houses, family set-up with paintings of Bastakia done by school children probably in some recent competition and traditional dresses, but information is very limited. Coin and Philately museum were also deserted with limited information. Over all not as impressive as expected it to be. Nothing much to attract children attention.
Great Knowledge!. I came here because my cousin told me that it was a great place to gain knowledge about Dubai and the culture of U.A.E.
Stolling in old arabia. Like being cast back to olden and golden times of an era by gone. Culturally informative and some lovely little nooks and cranies to visit
Complete Cultural Experience. If you want to visit a mosque while in Dubai, you must visit this center. Sign up for the tour and also the traditional lunch if you can, it's an eye opening experience.

Very interesting.... We visited for the cultural lunch and I must say I was pleasantly surprised at how interesting I found this. Food and soft drinks were provided and there was enough for all and more! I came away with a great understanding of their religion and how they live their lives. You were able to ask any question you could think of without offending anyone. I would highly recommend this to anyone visiting Dubai. There were many people there who have been living in Dubai for years and only just visited and were amazed at what they had learnt. I do not know whether I would personally go again, but only as I believe I found out everything that I would have wanted to know!

A cultural bridge to the Gulf. A vital organization that bridges the western world to the regional culture and history. The Ramadan dinner was vital to enriching my understanding of Islam and the regional history and culture.

Wonderful opportunity. Wonderful opportunity to meet people who understand the culture of Dubai. We have been there are two different occasions and have enjoyed the conversations with the people who work and volunteer there.

Very educational. It gave a real insight into Emirati culture and customs. We were treated to a breakfast of Gemat and chick peas which I loved. I would highly recommend this to tourist and residents alike.

Cultural Breakfast A Must. With only 1.5 days in Dubai to explore, the Cultural Breakfast at the Center was the highlight! We learned so much, ate so well, and left with a more complete picture of the UAE. The presenters were amazing and engaged, creating a welcoming and enjoyable environment. A must do compared to all the other glitz and glamor of Dubai.

Interesting. Visited the mosque at 10am to listen to the talk. It cost 10DHS and they will happily provide scarves / clothing for those who are not dressed 'modestly' (i.e. shoulders and knees MUST be covered). Our session was held by an English lady that volunteers for SMCCU. She made it quite numerous and interesting, I really enjoyed taking the time to fit this into my trip as I now understand a lot more about Muslim culture.
A MUST visit!. Whether visiting Dubai or a new Expat- this is a MUST visit! You will gain such a better understanding of the culture here & everyone treats you with the most graceful of hospitality

A must!!! Great use of humour and fun- with a mix of serious discussion. Took some friends from England for the lunch experience! What can I say? It was fabulous, funny and enlightening! The explanation of black abayas being a cultural dress and how many other countries have different colours, different burgaa, different scarfs and how they wear them. Much like any country really, when you think of fashion- there are many types. We had a lovely Emirati lady join us and we discussed as a group family values, women's roles which was well put by our host- women are to be elevated. I think the biggest thing my friends got out of the experience is that Islam is a peaceful way of life and in no way is it a representation of the radical on fundamentalism we hear, see and read about in the news. Too bad the news doesn't report on this very peaceful way of life. The food was magnificent!! We all enjoyed it so much so, I am returning with my next set of guests from the UK. Thank you!

Open doors - open minds. We had an interesting and a wonderful evening here during the Ramadan 2012. We learned so much in one evening!Thanks to the staff who were very good at explaining with a twist of fantastic humour!I can highly recommend this to everybody visiting Dubai. The draw back are the opening hours. The place is only open during working hours, not after work and not normally during the evenings.

Interesting. We had the Bedouin breakfast and the talk we had has allowed us to know better the culture and the traditions of the bedouin, the islamic approach to the life and the women life.Interesting also the hospitality of the bedouin. It is worth to spend sometime there.
Very Interesting!. Really helpful staff and also interesting to learn about the culture of Islam. Situated near the Souks so worth a visit after you have been there!

Best cultural activity in Dubai. This centre runs 10am tours of a mosque in Jumerai and breakfast/lunches several days a week. The basic objective is to present the basic ideas in muslim faith and the traditional way of living in Dubai. It is a very interesting experience and the "volunteers" answer any question you might have. Recommendation: for breakfast/lunches, book them well in advance as they are fully booked

DON'T MISS THIS!!!!!!. Don't miss a visit to the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding. If your schedule allows, make sure you make it to their breakfast or lunch. It was probably the very best part of a week long visit to Dubai. During the discussion time, you can ask ANY question about religion, culture, or even politics, and get a answer.

The World Would Be a Better Place if There Were More Centres Like This. Wonderful Experience.. My friend and I went to the Sheik Mohammad Centre for Cultural Understanding while we were in Dubai in September 2012 after I read about it on the Trip Advisor site. Open doors, Open minds – nothing could be truer. We had lunch at the centre and the spread provided was delicious [and at AED 70, the best value meal that one could ever find in Dubai without a doubt]. In addition to the great food, I really enjoyed myself as it was not only educational but entertaining as well. To get the best from this activity one must leave preconceptions at the front door and remember that it is the centre who have ‘opened their doors’ and it is us as their guests who should ‘open our minds’. Our host addressed many of the negative perceptions of their culture subtly, with humour and without a hint of criticism of any other group, race or religion. As he spoke, I shuddered inwardly as I remembered a time when I had preconceptions that anyone who didn’t live life in the same manner that I did was the one who had a problem. If one chooses to listen and reflect on the basics, he and his family have the same types of issues and positives that we have. I must comment - one issue for some is that the men wear white and the women wear black. Hey, get with the program, black is my colour of choice !!!!!! . I have a wardrobe that rates ten to one in favour of black. My suitcase was full of it.I hope that visitors to Dubai will visit the centre with an open mind. It is through such open forums that we as human beings can begin to understand and appreciate each other as people with differences as well as many things that are the same. No-one is asking anyone to change, simply to understand. Even if the meal had not been included, I would have paid the money for the entertainment, laughs and the education value and still considered that I had excellent value. I thank SMCCU for their hospitality and grace and hope that future visitors will enjoy it as much as I did. The world would be a better place if there were more interaction between cultures of the type that occurs here.
Off the beaten track. Did the private tour which was good but would have been better with other people. most of the buildings do not open until 2pm so take this into consideration

Great to Experience Breakfast - dismissal of human rights issues disturbing. I love experiences where you get to talk to locals and gain appreciation of their culture. I came with an open mind & not really aware of many of the issues of the UAE. I left deeply disturbed. Our Emirati host encouraged us to throw the hard topics at him - treatment of women, why women wear black which is hotter while men wear white & public beatings for offences such adultery. The 'open' discussion on hard topics were addressed in a comedic manner - which made it feel like it should come with a '2 drink minimum'. We were given the opportunity to try on the abaya & encouraged to feel how lightweight it was. When the American tourist commented that she couldn't breathe when she put the mask over her face our host told her she would 'get used to it'. You just said a lot in that sentence, sir. Appraise yourself of the details on treatment of women (including tourists) and you may not want to sit down to eat. When they rolled out an American now living in the UAE at the end to sell us on the burka being her preference - it all felt so contrived.
Interesting. My husband and I loved this lunch and thought it was interesting and great food. Staff very helpful. Great value.

Great insight into the culture. Arrive wearing what you're comfortable with - the centre will provide you an abaya to wear for modesty! We visited the centre on our first day in Dubai, and it was a fantastic way to introduce ourselves to the religion, culture and local custom. It made it a lot easier when seeing locals later on in our tour, and understanding why they did what they do.Inside the mosque is really pretty, and the host (can't remember her name!) was fantastic. I arrived not knowing anything about the Muslim way - aside from what you hear on the news - but this tour really helped me to understand a lot more. Really interesting.A great introduction, I recommend.

Awesome way to understand customs in the emirates. I was invited to this activity and I liked it from the beginning to the end, not really for the food but more for the stories.Openness of the host was unbelievableThis activity is very cheap 70AED or so for the food and the discussions.awesome is the only word I have

Informative, friendly and welcoming.. I went to SMCCUs talk and tour at the Grand Mosque in Dubai. It starts at 10am every sun, tue, thur and sat and reservation is not needed. It costs 10 Dirhams (1.68GBP 2.72USD) and lasts for about 1 hour 15 minutes. You are welcomed into the mosque (you should wear suitable clothing -covering legs, arms and definitely chests, but traditional attire is provided if you can't refrain from wearing shorts to the mosque. Women are asked to cover their hair. You need to remove your shoes but aren't required to go through the ablution process. The talk was given by a British woman who converted to Islam 20 years ago. She gives a basic summary of Islam and talks of some Muslim traditions and religious practices. She prays, talks you through the process of Muslim prayer and discusses Muslim attire. At the end she answers any questions at all. Throughout the whole talk she is extremely open and all questions are answered and photos and videos can be taken at any point. When I went the had a free shuttle bus to their offices for a traditional Arabic lunch.

must do.... The tour here is great and one which you would not normally get to do asnd ask questions from an educated guide. I am very glad I had the opportunity to do this tour and would definately recommend it.

Jumeirah Mosque visit. We where able to visit famous Jumeirah mosque with a guide from SMCCU for just 10Dhs cca. 2 €. It was really great experience with light intro to Islam religion and it's pillars.
The lady spoke about an hour about Islam with very open way.
Strongly recommend.

A good guided tour of the Jumeirah mosque!. I asked a lot of questions - do not hesitate - it helps you clear some prejudices! Ask ahead about dressing code - women need to cover their heads, shoulders and knees, and man not to wear short trousers. Be aware of the heat too while waiting and visiting from outside.

Informative. It is a good place to taste local emirati food, visit the mosque and asked questions on the local culture. It is preferable to visit in the later months of the year, because the tour is outdoors (and may be a bit hot otherwise). It is a nice contrast to the shiny new Dubai. If you are in the area, a ride on the abra (traditional ferry) is a must.

NOT TO BE MISSED!!. This is a must do while in Dubai. The setting is a beautiful converted house and the guests sit on pillows around the food. Our hosts, Dahlia and Youssef were extremely friendly and knowledgable. They spoke about history, culture and religion and even shared personal stories. They answered all questions openly and thoughtfully. The lunch runs 90 minutes which is perfect. The food was home cooked and tins were brought out at the end so guests could take the leftovers with them. It is inexpensive relative to other Dubai activities and well worth it. We travelled with another family and there were 4 kids ranging in age from 11-15 and we all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.Do yourself a favor and visit the SMCCU, you'll be glad you did!
Dubai History. This is a great way to know more about the origins and culture of Dubai. Its richness and openness is a very interesting culture to learn.

A must do !!. We chose to have tour , and a typical arabic lunch - this included a visit to the mosque and a question answer sesion. We did have to pay and to start with I thought it was expensive but for what we had and the day it gave us I would pay it again and if you can only go to one place do this.Friendly and so welcoming , I had so many questions about the faith , history and religion , dress etc - All answered and all questions welcome . I even got to dress in typical costume.I cant rate this highly enough for people who have "open minds " and want to learn about the faiths and countries they visit.Lunch was superb , they even gave us pots to take some home.Good for all ,however young children may get bored if you stay for to long.

A good place to learn about the UAE and Islam in general.. I went there as a part of a group and was impressed with the knowledge that the guide (American) was able to share. She was able to answer varied questions that pertained from the early days of the UAE to how the population thrived in the extreme temperature without airconditioning etc...An informative tour to the mosque was included.Lunch is also an option.

Cultural Treat. Dubai can sometimes feel like shopping mall paradise, but there are little gems like this cultural centre which really enhances a trip to Dubai. You appreciate an understanding of cultures and history. The staff are always very helpful and polite. You are always welcomed as a guest.

This is a Must See - Go for Lunch!. Excellent centre for gaining an understanding and appreciation of the relegion and culture of the UAE, in a very comfortable, accepting environment.By the time I leave Dubai I'll have enjoyed the walking tour, breakfast, lunch and Iftar (breaking of Ramadan fasting meal). I highly recommend lunch!The volunteers are extremely knowledgeable, and you can be completely at ease to ask all the questions you've been dying to ask!
good place to see what the cultural difference we have. nice to see place you will feel the real arab hospitality and real culture

A must do experience in Dubai. I highly recommend this experience for all visitors and UAE expats. Its a great way to understand more about Dubai and its people. I could have sat their all afternoon talking to our host. Plus the food was oustanding!

Ups and downs. Went for one of their luncheons and cultural dialogues. I can't really complain about the know-it-alls who kept interrupting, or the axe-grinders who kept trying to shift the conversation to their own pet issues.So I'll turn to the docents. They're good with the standard fare about why Arab women dress the way they do, etc. But cultural understanding is not furthered by dismissing key differences among world religions or traditions held by non-Emirati cultures, or lambasting the average Westerner for arriving at honest misconceptions while trying to digest media reports from the other side of the planet. If you want harmony, you can't stifle: every sound has to be heard, and the discordant ones given their proper place. Some good information, but disappointed by the tone. By the way, the food was REALLY good.

One of the best experiences in Dubai!. Lived in Dubai for 4 years and I always recommend SMCCU. They do amazing cultural breakfast and lunches where you get to chat to locals, ask questions and learn about the REAL Dubai, arab culture and islam. Also try their tour of Jumeirah mosque, just wonderful.

Witty tales in a nice surrounding. We tried the breakfast they offer a few times a week. What a nice experience. Our host Nasif was witty and informative. The more questions the guests ask the more they can learn about history, customs and culture of the Emirates. Breakfast consisted of yummy Arabian coffee, dates, chickpeas, vermicelli, egg and raisins and different sweets with date syrup or dips. Tip: Walk from there to the old Souk and catch an Abra to ferry you across the creek where you can connect to the Metro to return to other parts of town. Don't expect the taxi driver to find the location, get out at the British consulate and walk from there.

open doors, open minds!. We booked the 'Bastakiya Heritage Tour'. We had the chance to visit the Bastakiya Mosque and get explanations about everything inside it and the muslims religious habits. After a walk through the Bastakiya, we went back to the SMCCU for a conversation. It is a great opportunity for cultural understanding - about the emirati lifestyle and about the Islam. Before you go, take a time to think about questions that you would like to throw to an Emirati that is ready to give you the answers. The guide (Wallid) is very friendly and talkative. I intend to go there again and next time try to take part in the tour with lunch.

Excellent place to learn about local culture. We booked a 'cultural lunch' via their web site for 70AED per person. It was a great way to know a bit more of how the traditional Emirati eats. We all sit on the cushions and eat on the floor. The host makes us feel really welcome and stay with us and chat with us anything we wanted to know about the Emirate culture. (The lunch last about 1.5 - 2 hours and it has 3 types of rice dishes, a meat & 2 fish dishes) I think the food are excellent and been told it will be different everytime, depends on season. We have also tried Arabian coffee and dates. lunch boxes are available at the end, and people can take the leftover food away (which I think is the traditional thing to do). We also got a chance to try out their costume. Great experience.Top tip: We went to Jumeirah Mosque visit in the same morning (Sunday) and had a free mini bus lift from there to the SMCCU centre.

Not to be missed. If you go to Dubai do not miss the oportunity to know more about muslim and uae culture. We did the Heritage Tour with Wallid (great guide) and he was very good. Not to be missed if you are in Dubai!!!!

Must do in Dubai. I went to visit the cultural centre alone and had the lunch. It was very interesting. The man than was hosting the lunch was funny and informative in a informal way. It was very easy to get to by metro and the area was very different to the rest of Dubai. The food at the lunch was very tasty and we were offered left overs to take home. Well worth the money. It is an attraction for the young and old alike. Add this to the list of must see things in Dubai
nice, interesting, warm welcome. We have a lunch. This has been a perfect and memorable event:a must during a stay in UAE.

Must-do. For a greater understanding this experience is a must. Try the Bastakiya Heritage Tour which lasts for 90 minutes and has a question and answer session at the end. All questions are encouraged.

SMCCU. We had a walk about here, then lunch with one of the locals who is an expert on Dubai. Interesting history on the locals and their food,dress,why they do what they do. The culture was explained, but even more amazing is that the locals only make up 20% of the 8million population of Dubai, the rest are foreigners working and living there.
Well worth a visit!. If you like History (I teach this subject~) then this is an absolute must go, really facinating and very helpful staff.

One of the few places to experience Emirati life style. SMCCU is amust do if you want to learn about Emirati life style. The entrance fee includes a traditional breakfast or lunch. Food is served on the floor and all guests helps themselves. The host is usually a Western convert. When I visited the place there was an American lady who converted to Islam and became the second wife of an Emirati man. We could ask anything and everything about their life style, religion food , family.. She was very informative, honest and kind.. Plus the location is very near historical Bastakiya district and Dubai Museum as well as Majlis Gallery. So its worth combining it with other atrractions in the area.

A must for any traveller. The experience was excellent and the informal lecture on Islam and cultural understanding was so interesting and really did dismiss some of the misguided interpretations received from the media. I would defiantly encourage anyone visiting the region to take the time to go to the SMCCU. The cultural tour of the Jumeriah Mosque has a question and answer session which is very open and honest and really I could not recommend the occasion more.

Very informative. We thoroughly enjoyed a walking tour of 'Al Bastikiya' followed by an additional tour called the 'breakfast'. We highly recommend both. a great way to learn a little more about the culture, foods, religion etc.

Cultural Breakfast. I highly recommend this to anyone visiting Dubai. It's great to see the architecture. You sit on big pillows and have an Arabian style breakfast. The meat is fantastic...reminded me of Goulash. I've been there twice and the speaker has been very entertaining each time. Their policy is open doors, open minds.
Interesting. Made very welcome. Very good and informative discussion about the Mosque and Muslim.
Give it a go. A bit more understanding between religions is a great thing. Worth a visit and you will be doing something educational in Dubai (and thats not easy)

Go for more than breakfast, then It will work. We had breakfast at SMCCU.It is good experience but nothing more than that. Speaker was good, but It was something always left behind. Can blame myself tho that did not throw some more open questions.Just a breakfast is not enough. Have a look for more advanced tours.

SMCCU Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding. When visiting Dubai for the first time, please take time out and go to visit the Center to get a better understanding of the area's culture - you won't be dissapointed!

Cultural walk. It was not as expected. Supposed to be a walk around old Dubai, but was only around a reconstruction of how old Dubai had been. Had lunch there with a question and answer session. More of a brainwashing session.

To Experience the Open Book Learning. I booked this cultural lunch 3 weeks before my trip to Dubai. We paid the fee when we arrived the day for the lunch. It’s not necessary to pre-pay it, very convenient. The SMCCU is located at a cultural area - Baskitaya, nearby there’re some little shops for selling arts, craftsmen, paintings, etc. After/ before the cultural lunch, you could walk around the nearby area for exploring the heritage of Dubai. Oh! Also the Dubai museum and Heritage house are nearby too! As you can see from many comments below, through the lunch, you could get to know better of the background of Arabian culture. I admire this idea for cultural exchange. ‘Dining’ plays an important role in daily life. Through dining to understand a culture is faster and easier than reading books. It’s definitely an open book activity, I believe many foreigners are curious enough to know the mysterious Arabian culture. This is a right place to know it better with no shy! It worths the visit, it only costs 70AED per person but make you a valuable and meaningful afternoon.

Fantastic way to learn about history, religion and everyday life in Dubai. We went there a Saturday morning with our children aged 3 and 5. In order to be part of the Heritage tour, we had to book a few days in advance. We started our tour with a stop in a mosque, where our excellent guide Waleed told us about their religion, praying, mosque history and whatever we would like to know. After here, we walked for an hour to see replica houses from ancient times, learning about how they lived their lives in the old days. The very good history telling from our guide made this very interesting also for our children.We ended with a Q&A session, where we were offered arabic coffee and dates. The setting was laidback, and our guide allowed us to ask about anything we wanted! We learned about their tradition way of dressing, differencies in sex roles and rules for dating/marrying :-) When the questions about Dubai's investment rate and need to borrow money from Abu Dhabi during the financial crises and about democracy in UAE, the answers sounded more "official". But we enjoyed the opportunity to ask about anything, and the fact that the SMCCU give us their best answers from a local point of view.Our tour was supposed to last from 10.30-12.00, but it ended around 1.00 pm thanks to our fantastic guide and nice group of people!We recommend visitors to have lunch at the nice Basta Art Cafe after this tour.
Great place!. The SMCCU offers traditional Emirati food and you have the opportunity to ask as many questions as you want about the local customs and tradition. A must do

A must not only for people visiting. I have visited the Jumerah mosque and went for breakfast and lunch at the SMCCU and each time I had the most amazing time. Nasif is one of the best story tellers and speakers you will encounter - very engaging, down to earth and entertaining. It is best to book in advance as they tend to be very busy and do not forget your list of questions - they are always happy to answer!
Informative and interesting. A great opportunity to visit a mosque, have many of the Islamic practices explained and ask questions. A must do.
Interesting. Informative, good breakfast and fun. Learned helpful things about Muslim culture which benefited us during our stay
excellent centre. This is a must-do when in Dubai.It is fascinating and wonderfully well- organized.You learn so much and embrace the culture of this extraordinary emirate.

A must to be in while first time in Arabic world. No available place there when we tried to book but they were kind enough to let us know to look around the center An exquisite experience if you want to understand and indulge local traditions. Hope to find a place next time...
sheikh Mohammed great centre. that our great leader wants all nations to come togther and live life in peace and in happiness. support others in need, with open arms and a big heart!

Absolutely Fantastic. I'll admit, I kind of rolled my eyes when I was looking for things to do in Dubai and stumbled across this on Trip Advisor. I thought, "If this is the best Dubai can do, I'm in trouble." So I booked a heritage tour for my first morning in Dubai, figuring that it would at least be an easy transition into my vacation.The heritage tour was wonderful. Our group and two guides spent about an hour and a half wandering around the Bastakiya district looking at replica houses, touring a mosque, and hearing about the history of Dubai. As a Westerner with little to no experience in Islamic history or Middle Eastern cultures, it was an eye-opening experience. The guides were candid about their way of life and did not bat an eye when touchy questions were raised. They handled our curiosities with grace and humor, while giving an insight into Emirati life, something you'll likely miss if you just come for the modern attractions.Following the tour, our guides sat down with our group for coffee and dates and another Q&A session. Again, their answers were relevant and easily accessible to all audiences. The information and insight they provided helped to broaden our minds at the beginning of our vacation, which I believe enhanced our Dubai experience.If you do one thing in Dubai, take a tour with the SMCCU.

Valuable information and a worth-while tour. I took the Bastakiya 60-minute walking tour. Our guide was an Emirati citizen and told us all about the history of the area and educated us about his culture. It was fascinating, and I definitely recommend this to anyone who goes to Dubai.
Highlight of my trip. The cultural breakfast or lunch is a great chance to taste home cooked Emirati food and a good chance to interact with the Emirati hosts who are full of interesting information.

Very informative. The guided tour was short but interesting, but the best thing about the cultural centre is the question and answer session, where you can ask anything about Emirati life. It blows away your preconceptions, and is a great idea to encourage non muslims to understand and accept the differences in culture. Unfortunately when we were there they had a bunch of American students staying for lunch so we couldn't stay as long as we would have liked as the conversation was just getting really interesting, so we would definitely go back if we ever visit Dubai again. The Arabic coffee and dates were a nice touch too :)

I learned so much!. This is a visit that every visitor should do in Dubai. You learn so much about Emirati and Muslim culture. The atmosphere is very open so you feel can ask any questions. Being able to participate in the meal and taste the foods was also very educational.

To do , great team and great learnings. We had a great morning at the Center for Cultural Understanding breakfast. We had answers to any questions, the team was so friendly and the home cooked food delicious. Was great to discover Emirati cuisine.
Do it... no really, do it. Its an eye opener and very interesting, ladies wear suitable attire, but you can borrow/ but headscalves there. For kids? Yes, definitely, travel broadens the mind!
Very interesting. If you are interested in a little cultural understanding you will appreciate it to it's fullest.

Great Experience-Must do!`. This is simply a visitor's best chance to actually learn about the U.A.E. and a bit about the Muslim faith. You must pre-book however; I noticed that the few negative comments on this site are from people who just showed up at the site and didn't really participate in any program. Just walking around this area would be boring. We booked the Bastikaya Mosque & Walking tour which lasted about 90 minutes. During the Mosque visit, women must have shoulders, knees, and hair covered. If they are not, they will loan you a headscarf or even an abaya if you want. It's only a short presentation; it's mostly Q&A. You can ask ANY question, they've heard it all before. I found some of our group's questions painfully ignorant and even perhaps racist but the 2 guides remained good-natured and informative nonetheless. The center is also right by the waterfront where you can see traditional boats. Put aside any ignorance about all Arab countries being the same; they may share a language and a basic faith but are about as alike as Christian Democracies are--America, Mexico, Kenya for example. Learn about the UAE for yourself. One tip is to book the morning tour followed by lunch for the full experience. This is truly the best thing you can do in Dubai! Almost everything else is glitz, shopping, sand or beach related.

Cultural activities. Good to find more outlets for learning about Dubai History and Culture. I love going there and am very appreciative of the lengths the Emeratis have gone to to make visitors welcome in their Homeland.

Cultural Understanding is Critical. Traveling in the UAE you are unlikely to have any contact with the local Emirati who comprise only @ 18% of the population. Thus, the Centre provides a rare opportunity for interaction and questions and answer periods. The walking tour is okay and should be done if you cannot get in for the meals.

Great opportunity to learn local culture. The best part of the tour we took was the opportunity to ask any questions. I can't say it was anything new for me religion wise, but the chance to talk to locals ( two tour guides) and ask them sometimes even personal questions (about their families, marriage) was great. For example - one tour guide told us how his mom is trying to find a wife for him, but so far he didn't really like any of them, another told us about his engagement and about his uncle who has two wifes. That's the stuff I personally find the most interesting: the everyday life of local people. So if you decided to go - don't be afraid to ask questions and pick their minds. As a tourist in any foreign country you don't get opportunities like this a lot, especially in Muslim countries, where privacy is very, very important.

Insight into Emirati culture. You definitely need to visit this place and join one of the tours/ sessions. There is a lot of misunderstanding about the culture and traditions of Arabian culture. A tour here really gives you a quick insight into the Emirati culture and tradition

All questions allowed. I think the SMCCU really delivers on its tag line "open doors, open minds". The atmosphere of the place is really nice and everyone is so friendly. Information is delivered in a very easily digestible format with a high emphasis on having fun. Content may not always be things you have not heard before but the fact that you can ask anything that you want makes the discussions very interesting and you finally get an answer to all those questions that you have been putting off asking anyone else!Defenetly a place for tourists and expapta alike. The guy rating the centre as terrible does not know what he is talking about. Several attendees when I attended the cultural breakfast were there for the second time and now brought new guests.

A Must for First -Time Visitors to the Middle East. Guides are enthusiastic and open - ask them anything! With locals comprising only 10% of the population in Dubai, this may be the closest you come to touching local culture. Don't miss it.

Jumeriah Mosque Tour. The mosque tour was totally worth it! They tell you all about the Islamic culture. The tour days and timings can be found on the SMCCU site. The 75-minute tour does not require reservation and has a minimal fee. The mosque is very beautiful and is open to non-Muslims as well. The tour was given by two brit expats, who were wonderfully nice and easy to understand. They were very informative. I loved it.It is preferred to cover your skin. They provide you with head coverings to cover your head and if you are showing too much skin. On a separate trip, we also went to the SMCCU center. They are open for public viewing and let you go inside. It is around the Bastakiya area. Good to visit.
Cultural. A way to see the vision of the last king. Amazing! and for me very different to the rest of the world.
Great place to start you visit. We went for breakfast and it was a lot of really nice food. They are really friendly and open to answer all types of questions. Nice intro to the UAE life and culture.

Educate yourself; it's worth it !. Great 'helpers' who know what they're doing. No question too difficult. Always welcoming and so friendly. We always take guests here to educate them about UAE culture. Recommended.

Top notch!. This is on our top 5 list of Dubai. I regret that I don't remember the name of our guide but he was soooooooo friendly and openminded. The info we got really helped us understand Islam, Dubai and ther Emirates.So pleased!

Must Experienced. This was my second visit to the center, the first time was for Ifthar during Ramadan. As my family was visiting for the first time from overseas and I wanted them to experience something else than the malls & souks, so I booked a cultural tour and breakfast. If you are visiting Dubai as a tourist or even living here, this maybe the only place where you can meet Emiratis who will speak to you about their culture, history, Islam and any subjects that you want to bring up. Nasif & Dhalia, 2 of the volunteers at the center are great hosts, great entertainers and genuinely open to listen and talk to you. This is another Dubai... Despite the barrier language my parents loved the entire time and my brother and girl friend discovered a bit more of the Emirati way of life and history. And this might be or is the only place where you can experience/eat traditional Emirati food. If you are planning your trip to Dubai and you are curious to learn more about the Emirati culture, this is the place for you. Are you "Open Minds"?

Excellent business breakfast. We took some customers for a business breakfast to the SMCCU. I have to say it was one of the nicest experiences in Dubai. The hosts were very charismatic and open minded. They really show the best of Emirati culture. After living in Dubai for a few years I still learned something new. Can whole heartedly recommend to anybody who is interested in local culture, traditions, religion. Dubai is so much more then beach and mall if you know where to look:)

Excellent! A must-do for visitors to Dubai. We attended the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding lunch and tour of the Bastakiya.We all thoroughly enjoyed the trip and said what a great day it was. Our guide was so knowledgeable and friendly and put us at ease to ask lots of questions about Islam and culture in the UAE. Lunch was fabulous and it was really nice to experience Emirati food. The tour of the Bastakiya was great and we were really pleased to get the opportunity to go inside a mosque.I can't say enough good things about the SMCCU - this should definitely be on the must-do list for visitors to Dubai.

Good cultural lunch. One of the few authentic experiences in Dubai.. The center for cultural understanding encompasses tours as well as the cultural lunch that I went to with my family. I booked online which seemed to be essential as the lunch was full and they had to turn some people away. The afternoon begins with a lunch served buffet style featuring probably the only authentic Emirati food that is easily available for tourists in a city mainly designed to replicate something else. The food was excellent and a good value. The remaining 45 minutes consisted of a male and female discussing common misunderstandings about being Emirati. The positive was that the man, in particular, was so passionate about relations between Arabs and non-Arabs that it was hard not to leave with an overwhelming sense that any conflict was borne out of miscommuncations. On the other hand, his passion also led him to launch into a seeming diatribe at times and made it more difficult to truly discuss more controversial topics. The one and a half to two hours were a little hard on my back sitting in Emirati style on the ground without back support although I could have chosen to sit on one of the few benches. I was also surprised that a third of the attendees lived in Dubai.

Unique and worthwhile experience. You can learn so much about Dubai and life there by taking the tours and participating in a cultural breakfast or lunch. If you want to know about Dubai beyond the skyscrapers this is your answer.
Good talk. Went for breakfast talk. Didn't like breakfast - nothing wrong with it just not to my liking.

Great lecture.. Very informative tour of the Mosque. As a Christian I have a better understanding of Islam. However, outside the mosque the little businesses are charging high prices for things such as Arabic Calligraphy. Go elsewhere. But do the tour of the mosque and get the lecture.

A cultural and historical treat. An opportunity to get an inside view of the history of the Bastakyia area, visit the lovely mosque and participate in a question and answer session with coffee and dates .

So much fun!. My expectations of Dubai was glass skysrapers, iconic buildings and desert. I didn't think about emirati traditions, nor did the kids. Our hotel advised us to go to here, and we are glad we did. What a wonderful and interesting place to visit. We valued this experience, and even though the food wasn't to my taste, I would recommend it to everyone to go. It is a must visit!
fantastic. to understand and to know a foreign cuture so different from our in Europe. If you are interested not only in beach, sun and mall is highly recommended.

Sincere Bridge to Understanding. We took a tour offered by the staff and had lunch at this Centre. if you want to get below the tourist attractions and understand some of the Arab culture, try this experience. There are both volunteer and professional staff at the Centre. We learned about the muslim religion, toured the mosque and had an arab lunch. This was the highlight of our visit to Dubai. The experience was as "unslick" as it is possible to be. The people were sincere but not preachy. I highly recommend this experience. We reserved in advance through their website. The cost was minimal.

Intelligence and interest. Definitely should be on every visitor's to do list along with a trip to Jumeirah Mosque. The team are sensational and fascinating. Try and take in a breakfast or a lunch or even iftar (during ramadam). Definitely the best place to visit.

Very interesting. We did two really interesting ventures here. We went on a walk around the old town where you can see the how the town was in earlier days. This was run by a knowledgeabe guide who also took us into the mosque and explained how the worship was run. We also went to the luncheon where the Director spoke and answered questions, plus we had the most delicious middle eastern food that was eaten whilst he talked. If you want something different to the shopping malls then this is a must visit. They also run a similar breakfast, both of which you can book ahead of time.

Find the deeper side of Dubai.... Wonderful walking tour. Vibrant and passionate young lady showed us around and opened up about being a Local Dubai Muslim. Was a warm uplifting and educational experience. See the deeper heart of Dubai... take time out to do this 1.5hr walk.
Interesting visit to Jumeirah mosque. Interesting to hear more about islam and muslim culture
Lunch. We had a great lunch here. The conversation was lively and the food was very good.

Great insight to Arab Culture. It wasa great lunch of Arad specialties in a restored home with a fascinating talk from the Arab host as we learned about traditions of Bedouin culture adn the history of the burka.

Excellent Experience, Would Highly Recommend. We attended the Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding breakfast. I really wasn't sure what to expect because there weren't a lot of tripadvisor reviews or information online. It exceeded my expectations and I would highly recommend the breakfast, or anything else put on by the SMCCU.We arrived for the 10am breakfast, unsure what we were getting ourselves into. We were greeted, asked to remove our shoes, then taken into what would have been the courtyard/living room of an old Dubai home that's been converted into a cultural center.There were probably 25-30 guests at our particular breakfast. Two volunteers (one man in his early 50s and another young lady in her early 20s) led an informal discussion of culture, religion and politics and encourages guests to ask any questions that will help them gain a better understanding. Being from a primarily Christian, homogenous area of the US, it was so interesting to me to hear these volunteers speak so openly about Muslim stereotypes with the hopes of spreading a mutual understanding and respect. So if you are looking for something out of the ordinary and appreciate the opportunity to experience cultures different from your own, I would highly encourage you visiting the SMCCU.
Definitely worth a look. Woth the effort to get an understanding of what Dubai was "before" The museum is also close to the markets, ferries and creeks.

Things you always wanted to ask about the emirati culture and religion. When I travel to a country, I try to get to know the local culture and typical food. In a country like UAE where 90% of the population is constituted by foreigners, that's a bit of a challenge. In the Sheik Mohamed Centre we have the opportunity to know more about the typical emirati food. You can schedule to have breakfasts and lunches with typical food and during ramadam they have iftar dinners (big dinners to break fasting). The prices and schedule are on the web site.While we are eating and drinking, they explain lots of things about customs, the reason for those traditions and about the religion. For me it was very interesting to talk about my doubts without the fear of offending anyone, and they explain things in a very rational way, always trying to make it easier for foreigners to understand their culture.Information about the culture, history, the way they dress, women condition, Muslim religion, food ... its a very friendly environment to talk about everything and learn a lot.I really recommend this experience for travelers from all ages, because I believe that if we have more information , we can be less affected by prejudice and news broadcast (ti's always bad news that arrive to us from other countries).Just plan ahead because they only have the meal meetings in a couple of days a week. Breakfasts are hosted every Monday and Wednesday at 10.00am, and lunches are hosted every Sunday and Tuesday at 1.00pm, and advance booking is required.The centre also has other atractions like tours in Batakya area and the visit of the Mosque. I hope to be able to try those other activities next time I'm in Dubai.

Took in Three Tours - Well Worth It. Was in Dubai in January on a business trip and had limited time for sight-seeing. Discovered the tours and cultural exchanges offer by the Sheik Mohammed Center for Cultural Understanding and am very pleased that I spent what time I had for touring with them. Booked three events on a Sunday (not all tours are offered on each day, so do your homework) -- Mosque Visit, Tour of the Bastakiya Quarter, and the Luncheon/Discussion. Started with the Mosque tour on Sunday morning. Was joined by about 75 others on the program, which featured a full explanation of Islamic prayer practices and the features of the Mosque. The program coordinators then answered any questions posed from the audience. It was very informal and quite illuminating -- very interesting. I then caught a cab to the Center's office, located in the Basakiay Quarter, where both the tour and luncheon are held. The tour was led by two young residents of Dubai, dressed in traditional clothing - The tour takes you through the last remaining remnants of old Dubai, providing information on the city's history and traditional architecture. Then, it was on to the Center's headquarters for the luncheon, featuring traditional UAE fare and held in the building's courtyard. Here, we heard from one of the directors of the Center, who wore traditoinal clothing and discussed both men and women's clothing and roles in society. Many of the topics covered at the Mosque were discussed here, however, it was still all very interesting. The food was quite good and the discussion very helpful to a visitor from the US. The staff here is very helpful and will provide information on other things to do in "Dubai. I was able to leave the Center and take a 10 minute walk to the abra pier where I took a very inexpensive ride to other side of the creek, where I visited the Gold and Spice Souks. The SMCCU is a good value and will help you understand life and society in the UAE. I recommend taking part in their tours and activities. Very reasonably priced and informative.

A MUST do!. I've lived in Dubai for 3 years now and the iftar dinner last night at SMCCU was one of the best things I've done here! Our hosts at the centre, all locals, were so friendly and hospitable! They sat with us for dinner and were more than happy to talk about their customs, religion, lifestyle, cuisine, fashion... They encouraged us to ask inconvenient questions and there was no taboo subject! All of them had a fabulous sense of humour, but some of them are so funny that they should be moonlighting as standup comedians :) After dinner we were taken to the mosque nearby (my first time in a mosque!), on a quick tour around the Bastakiya and we came back to the villa for deserts, tea, coffee, more conversations, better cultural understanding and heaps of laughter.An amazing experience that I would highly recommend to anyone visiting Dubai! Last night we learnt more about the place we live in than in all the years we've spent here...

Not just for visitors or new residents!. I've lived in Dubai six years and found my breakfast experience at the Cultural center was extremely informative and definitely worth attending. The host was very gracious and forthcoming in his information concerning the UAE culture and traditions. He geared it to his audience (who were mainly Americans and all women) and made us feel welcomed and did not prejudge our conceptions of his country. His friendliness, humor and the casual environment made us feel 'at home' and relaxed. I would recommend this adventure for all, whether long time residents, tourists or newcomers. Families too!

Best experience in Dubai. The Sheikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding is like an oasis of calm and reality in Dubai. This centre is probably the only place in Dubai that a tourist can see what 'real' Emirati culture is about, rather than just the malls, beach, bars & restaurants. It's also probably the only place you can interact with Emiraitis and ask all the questions you're desperate to know the answers to. They have cultural lunches and breakfasts, guided walking tours of the Bastakiya area, guided visits to Jumeirah Mosque and Question & Answer sessions, all mainly hosted by Emiratis. All the activities need to be booked in advance but a quick phone call or email sorts that out ([--]or [--]). We loved our visit to the centre and would encourage everyone to go and sample the real Dubai!

Great experience. The Shaikh Mohammed Centre for Cultural Understanding in the historic Bastakiya Quarter of Dubai offers walking tours of the area, cultural breakfasts and lunches, and question-and-answer sessions. These are open to anyone, and offer insights into Arabic food and customs. Booking is required.On a return visit to Dubai in late December, I took my extended family (aged 11 to 78) to SMCCU for the walking tour and cultural lunch. A volunteer guide, Waleed, took us for the stroll around the historic buildings, then our lunch was hosted by a delightful Emirati woman, Salama. There were about 15 in the group for lunch.Our hostess served tea and dates and spoke about Emirati hospitality customs, then explained the traditional diets of Emiratis and the array of luncheon dishes before us. After lunch, our hostess opened up the question-and-answer session, telling us to feel free in our questions. She spoke quite openly about all sorts of topics raised by the luncheon guests and gave us a wonderful insight into many aspects of Emirati life and traditions. All members of my family enjoyed this excursion and the older members thought it was a higlight of our Dubai trip. I highly recommend this as something different to do in Dubai.
